content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Path of exile Developer: Grinding Gear Games (GGG)Grade 9/10Review updated 3.11.2015 to take into account recent patches and expansionsFirst short review for those too well accustomed to modern hectic society:  Great game, although not flawless. Most importantly Path of exile is one of the most fair free to play games available.  As such there really is no good reason to not to try it.Good/bad:+ One of the most fair free to play games + Gameplay+ Variety of viable character builds+ Graphics+ Economy (from stability point of view)- Legacy items- More content would be appreciated (more coming but slowly)- Trading is difficultFull review:Before going to actual gameplay I want to emphasize the fact how fair this game is for a free to play game. Usually free to play games are more or less pay to win games but Path of exile is almost complete exception to this. Only pay to win feature of Path of exile is that with real money player can buy more stash tabs to which store stuff that can be shared by player’s characters in the same league.The extra stash tabs naturally do give minor advantage but this really starts to have an effect only when the player has played the game for hundreds of hours.  Thus the money grabbing is aimed at those players who already have played and enjoyed the game a lot and thus one could claim that these players ought to pay a little to support such an enjoyable game. Even then the payment is one time as those bought tabs are permanent. Most importantly however the extra stash tabs are definitely not mandatory even after hundreds of hours of gameplay. Next to the game itself. I am not expert when it comes to Action RPG games. As a prime example I never played Diablo 2 for which many people claim Path of exile to be better successor than Diablo 3 (which I haven’t played either). I would however claim Path of exile to be very good game. The main reason for this is the gameplay itself. It feels satiffying and the enemies are difficult but not too impossible. With many different viable builds in the game (more on this on nextt paragraph) can be replayed many times with different experience. with different characters (more on this later. As free game, you can easily go and verify this if you don't believe me.Another good thing is the skill tree, which is identical for all the classes. (classes only have different starting positions in the tree). This allows creating very interesting builds for your characters and actually surprisingly many of them are viable. With viable I mean reaching the end game. Naturally the amount of end game builds is bit smaller but even it is surprisingly large (especially according to what I have heard to be the case in other action RPG games. The different builds also seem to relatively balanced except temporary anomalies created by game updates. These are fixed usually sooner or later.Graphics are great which is always nice. The minimum graphical settings in this game are however quite high so low end PC owners may be in need of upgrade for playing this game (but as free game, try before upgrading)As he last notable good thing (writing more would make this review way too long) I am going to mention economy. All I can personally say is that it seems to work. Why this is important is that I have heard that in many other RPG games the economy does not work but instead for example the inflation of prices becomes ridiculous and starts to affect the game negatively.<The complaints about desynchronisation were here. Now GGG has finally introduced lockstep mode --> By default hit and movement detection works now like in MOBA's and RTS games, which is much much better than the original implementation. Desycnhronization issues are now problem only for those living really far from servers>The main flaw of the game is legacy items in permanent leagues. Legacy items are items that are no longer obtainable other than by trading from other players who already own them (with extremely high price of course). Unfortunately most of the legacy items were created by weakening the normally obtainable versions of these items. As result people who have these legacy versions are in practice equipped with items that are too powerful (balance wise) and obtaining these items is difficult for new players.Legacy items are not a problem in temporary leagues but some people like myself who would like to play in permanent leagues are forced to choose between two bad options: living with legacy items or playing temporary leagues.Second problem of Path of exile is lack story content. At the time of writing this the game has 4 chapters, which player has to pass in three difficulties before the "end game". More acts are coming but the progress is painfully slow. It should be noted that the end game is well done and that lessens this problem. When 5th chapter comes I will consider the amount of content acceptable. Third problem is that trading is impractical. The intended way to sell or buy items happens through trade chat, which is horribly flooded and yet very likely the people who would be willing to sell or buy what you want are not there when you are. There however are for example third party websites for listing items which helps a lot but GGG should really do something to fix this in-game.To summarize. The game definitely has some flaws but the good sides very clearly overcome these problems. As a very fair free to play game there is therefore no reason for not trying this game.

												An awesome hack & slash game, some say the true Successor of Diablo 2.One of the few f2p games that contains so much content and replayability, it's a wonder it's not a full price retail game.The setting is strongly exotic, New Zealand-like, with many resemblances to Maori culture.The classes are quite definitive, but at the same time the game doesn't throw strict restriction on build paths and it makes for a pretty free selection of roles for your chars.The "talent tree" speaks for itself, the jokes about it's vastness are quite the thing amongst hack and slash gamers, but be advised, they are not that far from the truth.The skill system using gems is nice, fresh touch to the genre, the combat is rewarding, occasionally even challenging.Once you get into the game, the numerous temporary events (races and leagues) add one more unique touch to a game that is pretty innovative, even without them.The optimization is quite sufficient, it ran surprisingly smoothly on a kinda old rig.Definite recommendation to any hack & slash fan, or even to those new to the genre.

Posted: June 29, 2015
												Let me start off by saying this is a fantastic ARPG.  I love the classes, the items, the spells, the customization with the passive skill tree, the viability of many builds.  I love this game.  But this game suffers from a fundamental, glaring, insulting and infuriating flaw (well, flaws, but more about that later).It desyncs constantly.  This may not be a big deal in early levels when mobs are fairly easy and the named/elite champs you fight aren't rocking proximity shields and damage reflection.  But when you're 60+, dealing with a room full of mobs that can literally 2-shot you if they get too close, it's borderline unplayable.  The difficulty factor would be perfect (probably a little too easy for archers) if it wasn't for these sneaky ninja-mobs that just show up and beat the living hell out of you.Another flaw (imo) is the gem system.  In games like Diablo, gems/runes are used to augment abilities or add buffs/bonuses.  In PoE, however, gems are both your skills and your buffs/augments.  On my 61 Ranger I have maybe 13 gems, 6 of which are skills and 3 of which are buffs.  That leaves me with 4 or 5 support gems, not a big deal.  The problem is that in order to upgrade a piece of equipment, I have to find one that is an ilvl upgrade, has a specific number of sockets in specific colors and in a specifically-linked configuration, is a rare or better, and has to have good modifiers.  The alternative is finding a random piece of equipment and burning mats to change the number/color/linkage/quality/attributes/bonuses.  This makes the game feel like a grind-fest.   And even then, I'd forgive this aspect if I didn't constantly desync.I want to love this game.  I've spent quite a lot of time playing, but I simply cannot play it anymore.  The desync issue is out of control, and absolutely breaks this game.

												This game in a nutshell: Great game, but....It is what Diablo 3 should be, but has the biggest problem of Diablo 3 at release you always need to be connected. That is already a problem itself, but the game has a HUGE problem of desync. You can't move when you are surrounded by mobs or you may risk a desync. You can't use movement skills when near corners or you may risk a desync. That gets really annoying and completely remove some possible builds of the game. Why? You can't go glass cannon and rely in your skill to stay alive when the server can just say it didn't like what you were doing and throw you back 2 secs in the past, a place that now is surrounded by enemies.There's no "class". Every character can use all items and skills in the game. In fact skills are actual gems, that you equip in items. Nice idea... but the characters lose identity. Instead of picking the character they should allow you to make your own customization.And what is worse.The game has a clean HUD, BUT it has 0 notification. miss, damage taken, damage done or whatever. You have 0 notifications if your character that is swinging the weapon in the air is missing, got desynced or is just out of range.For what i googled people were complaining since release but the devs want to keep the game "clean". Instead of allowing the player to turn notification on and off, they play the game "daddy know better" and make a game with alot of potential into something that you end with mixed feelings about.TL:DR The game is good, but there's issues that will make you made. At lower difficulties you will not notice, but later on you will feel and hate it, ALOT.Edit: I forgot a important point.Back into the "no class" thing. While it looks nice and all, it kills melee characters. Why? Ranged characters can have the same armor, life, evasion and damage that you while being ranged, there's no mechanic that a melee character can do that one ranged can't do. Add that with Monsters that have skills that kite, blind, freeze, release cloud of poison/fire/ice/lightning or even, in most of the bosses, oneshot your character there's NO reason to play a melee character unless you want to prove something. And i'm serious. Playing melee is at least 3x harder than a ranged character.And again the devs play the "daddy know better" game.

												Possibly a best Hack and Slash Action RPG game that is free to play without any pay to win things.I have logged lots of hours, played it religiously I am well aware of it's pros and cons without being biased like many of the fans are. Posted: October 21, 2014
												500 hours in and no end in sight, speaks for itself. If you like ARPG, Path of Exile is the must play to end all must plays.ProsEconomic design is intricate and thrivingSkill and character progression has depth beyond measureArt, sound, and animation is beautifulCustomizable player housingPerfect league and ladder designFrequent large content updatesTrue free to play, no pay walls periodConsMy singular issue with the game is how anticheat is handled. The methods used are extremely overbearing. All actions are controlled by a prediction system at the server level, and it is frequently confused. The result feels like lag but is actually the server forcing erronious corrections on your client. This has a large negative impact on the game.Overall, 9/10. If they rethought and redesigned their anticheat system it would be 11/10.Version 2.0 Edit:Thought I'd update this and say they have now greatly improved, if not entirely fixed my concerns with the predictive server syncing. They've improved this from a few different angles. Firstly they've diversified their datacenter locations so you're much more likely to be on a low latency server. Secondly they've added a new primary data sync mode called lockstep which does not desync but only works well on low latency connections. Thirdly they've improved the overall responsiveness and accuracy of the predictive sync mode for high latency players. I was not the only one who felt the old predictive mode stifled this game's quality feel. They've heard our concerns and went to incredible lengths to do right for us. Game is now a serious, solid 11/10.

The real sequel to Diablo 2.Diablo was fun. Diablo 2 was amazing, years past it's prime. Median mod brought life back to it as it aged. Diablo 3 was announced and everyone celebrated but as more and more came out about it gamer's hopes were dashed. All the brilliance that Blizzard North had created in the franchise, the things that made Diablo what it was, left the company with the people who originally made it. Thanks to some active, gamer-friendly, chatty developers in New Zealand, Path of Exile is as close as what would have been as crowdfunding and copyrights allow.Pros: Free to play, reasonable system requirements, Diablo 3, wonderous innovations to the genre, very deep, infinite endgame, friendly chat-available developers, great events and leagues.Cons: No classic Diablo story or characters, no offline/LAN play, complex trading economy, higher learning curve than more popular titles. No full tutorial.Other: BRUTAL sometimes offensive and very "mature" community in chat. Not a game, nor community for children or people with delicate sensibilities. Remember classic Battle.net? It's like that but ruder and smarter. I entirely prefer the "free speech" approach but some, maybe most, may not.I don't think there's anything Diablo 3 got right that Path of Exile got wrong. The only issue I personally have with the game is the complexity of attempting to trade for gear and currency items that I need. WHEN you play the game, make sure to pay close attention to what little instructional help it provides, because you don't get much.

Posted: July 22, 2015
												I've been playing this for over 3,000 hours, and I don't think I'll stop anytime soon. Sure, I might take a break to play something else, but Path of Exile has a way of drawing me back in. This is the best of free to play, in that everything you can buy is purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra stash tabs and character slots, but I've yet to hit the default character limit of 24). Having played Diablo 2, years ago, and having gotten tired of a game that I enjoyed being neglected by its developer, Path of Exile makes me happy in ways that game never did, with constant updates, fixes, and new content that continually expand the game and make it feel like there's always something new to try.I won't lie - the learning curve can be steep, and your first character or two will ultimately be ill equipped to handle the highest difficulty level, e.g. the third play through at high level. That's when you have to look up build guides on the forums, for tested builds that can survive the punishment that is Merciless difficulty and thrive. The passive skill tree is enormous and sprawling, and takes time to memorize and navigate, and many mechanics can be confusing until later on.All that said, when you start to get the hang of it, and you've conquered the basics, a whole new level of possibilities open up. It's hard to describe, but I'd like it to learning to ride a bike - once you get the basics, you can experiment with the more advanced stuff.Lastly, the developers are really good at replying to questions and suggestions, whether it's by email or on their forums. I have yet to play another game with this level of support.All in all, this is my favourite ARPG, and will likely remain so for years to come.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Henk Lostsword isn't your average exile.  He's on a path.  Is he on a path of good or of bad?  Well, that's up to you.It's easy to criticize this game for what it is not.  It's not Diablo, despite what others may tell you, and the differences can be a letdown to some.  It's not a first-person shooter, nor is it a side-scrolling beat 'em up.  It's not particularly novel in its handling of top down, hack-slash-and-loot gameplay.  It's not an episode of "Cheers" re-recorded on VHS with a two minute portion of "Scarecrow and Mrs. King" still left at the beginning that you have to wait through.  It's not a warm buttered scone on a Tuesday morning.  What the game is, is a solid beefsome electronic hoppy experience with a bold hearty finish and a wide variety of gameplay options to delight gamers of any age group or gender identity.You play as one of two types of mystical beings from the Immortal Cube, a land beyond time and space where immaterial aberrations sleep until it is their time to manifest as Daemons in the mortal realm.  One playable Daemon type is the Whiteshadow, who benefits from high Space and low Time; a natural healer and tank, who pulls damage and watches over the party's HP during critical combat encounters.  The other playable Dragoon is Melissa: She's a hacker from a near-future Australia, during a cyberwar that threatens to destroy both Western and Asian infrastructure.  Exiled from her home country as the world is divided into two key factions, she takes refuge on a series of interconnected rogue naval vessels in international waters and plans her digital assault from her "pirate flotilla".So here's the deal: Each piece of equipment that the party obtains has "battle magic slots", refered to in the game's media as BMS.  Each BMS lets you assign a new battle magic to your mech.  Some of the slots are linked together, allowing for Fusion Magic and other neat ways to upgrade your Core Stats.  Coming up with creative ways to augment and empower your spells is critical to your success, as the game's many different challenges diminish the successes of raw number stacking.  Adaptation Gems, when slotted in the correct gear, can make this task easier, by automatically mutating your battle magic to the necessary Color that will deal the most damage.  I had the most fun using Adaptation Gems and series of low level Fusions, linked together so I didn't have to worry about picking which magic to use.  This allowed me to focus on the dodge and roll techniques crucial to the game's action.  But there's definitely a play style for the calculating tacticians, too, where deliberate decision-making and pre-battle planning can give your mech an unbeatable advantage.Get this♥♥♥♥♥♥The game's level pacing is excellent.  Every fifteen to thirty minutes of gameplay, you increase in level and get to add a new Spirit Sphere to your Mana Web.  Every four of those causes one of your Core Stats to increment, allowing you to hold a new piece of gear associated with that stat.  What starts as a simple game becomes intriguingly complex after just a few hours of gameplay, and those decisions are neatly folded into your gameplay before other considerations arise later on.  But if you make a bad choice early on, don't fret!  Take-Em-Bax, a special Game Token provided in the in-game store, allows you to reassign any one skill that you regret assigning.  Take-Em-Bax cost a mere $0.75 per skill, allowing you to build a fresh new character at level 100 for about $8.  The cosmetics available in the store, however, have price tags that are a little too lofty for my liking.  You Rockafellers out there may disagree.The hacking minigame still needs work, as does the lockpicking drudgery (I found myself using triangle to "skip action sequence" at least five separate times), but the other aspects of gameplay fall neatly into place without disrupting the continuous "movie-like" quality of the game.  While not the most visually-stunning game of 2014, it has the best audio by far and has committed much of its budget to its all-star cast, including Joan Jett voicing one of the game's more memorable NPCs.All things considered, I give this game 500 value points for art, 800 for gameplay, and another 150 bonus, and 15 points.  Pick this game up if you have some wealth, ♥♥♥♥o.  If not, why not get paid already?  People respect you and they respect your talents.  Just apply what you do here to your career, to your family, to everything you do.  You are important.  But you sell yourself short too often--we all see it.How do you know they won't hire you if you don't try?  Just put out the application and say "♥♥♥♥ it" if it doesn't pan out.  You do this five or ten times, you're getting hired somewhere.  No one lands that dream job first thing.  The baby boomer's ideal of the American dream is over.  Jobs are scarce, so learn to make your goals a little more realistic.  Start reasonable and work your way up.  Before you know it, you've got $30 in your pocket--and that's enough to get started on your very own Pathof Exile.

Too bad, the game had so much to offer.If you play this game entirely solo, you will not be able to advance on the hardest difficulty since you have to trade with players to get the best gear using the game's flawed bartering system. And since the playerbase is a huge mass of elitists the higher up and further you progress, the more cancer you will have to deal with.Upvote for anything before the midgame, downvote for anything afterwards, downvote overall since the game's design encourages this kind of interaction.Edit: One other thing. The game has the biggest skill system of all time. It's massive, and it's fun to experiment with. However, there is no way to full reset your entire skill tree, other than by getting extremely rare orbs that only remove a single skill selection that you recently picked at a time. Given how massive the tree is, this means if you plot out a massive map of where all your skills go, but you later find out your plot had a poor selection anywhere near the beginning, you have essentially no way to undo all the way back to the mistake and fix it. Furthermore, if you get bored of one particularly long line of skill progression, you have almost no way to undo back to the beginning and reset your entire tree and re-allocate it.For many in the cancerous community, this is just great! They have no lives and are willing to spend 60 hours getting to max level and then restarting a whole new character just to try out an alternate build. For people like me with a job, this means you will either be perpetually stuck in the first 30-60ish levels of a character build as you reset a whole new character to try a new skill build, or you can only play one character for 85 hours before finding out all your effort was wasted and your character sucks.If Diablo 3 can have a way smaller skill system with the ability to full reset a character, so can this game. I am not buying the playerbase's excuses for the devs reasoning for intentionally leaving this out.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This game is irritatingly addictive.  I spent the weekend I got it playing it, instead of doing work I had intended to do.This is an ARPG, and as such, there's not a whole lot of innovation when it comes to the actualy gameplay.  Overhead view, point a spam your mousebutton, pick up loot.  This isn't to say it doesn't do this well, as I found the experience to be enjoyable.  Intuitive controls, good challenge level (i.e., I'm not throwing my mouse in frustration of how hard it is, but I do sometimes have to think tactically, and retreat to defeat the horde against me).Where this game earns its points is in its passive skill tree, it's gem-based skills (think materia from FFVII), and its in-game economy.The passive skill tree can be a little overwhelming at first, since there is a LOT.  Once you spend a little time perusing it, and understanding how it works, it can start to seem kind of dull (how many times can you get a +10 to dex before you're looking for a little more, though there are other nodes to work with!).  Then, it hits you.  I can completely customize this character, and how it plays.  Want to be a duel-weilding lighning specialist?  Can do.  Fire-based summoner?  Alright, we can do that.  Want to just TANK with a really big axe?  We can do that, too.  The possibilities for different builds are bountiful.Combine the skill tree with experience-gaining leveling skill orbs that can be socketed into items, and you have a great combination for customization.The economy is another place where the devs took a different route than many others.  Money doesn't exist in this game.  Instead, you have barter system.  Normal items give you pieces of Wisdom scrolls (read: identify item), which eventually form into a whole scroll.  Whole scrolls also drop as loot, so this isn't your only means of ID'g an item.  Magical itmes might be worth augmentation shards, or transmutation shards, or other items.  While there is a formula to what the vendors give in exchange for what, it does teach you to think about loot grabs differently than other games.  In Diablo, or Torchlight for example, eventually normal items got left behind for magical, and even those eventaully weren't worth the inventory space.  In PoE, every item gets looked at individually.  Are you in need of ID scrolls?  Start picking up low-space normals.  Are you looking for a specific socket pattern for a weapon you want to try to craft?  Each item could be that thing you want!  Even that normal sword that, in other ARPGs would get left behind!  I personally found this to be a refreshing change of pace.Even the meta-economy gets a little more interesting with no money.  What exactly is that unique piece of armor worth to you?The best part of this game is its price.  Free.  And actually FREE.  Not, "free to sign up, but in order to beat this boss you need to spend $5 to get this one item you will only use once."  GGG has made a commitment to makig this game truly free.  While there are microtransactions available, they are purely cosmetic, offer no advantage, and are completely voluntary.  I am more likely to spend money on these, because they aren't forced on me, than I am any "need to buy to progress" stuff.  If you are enjoying the game, I suggest grabbing some of this as it helps the devs continue to make great games, and you get nifty effects for your character (like flaming footprints, or glowing blue weapons!) I haven't done any parties or PvP yet, so I can't comment on those mechanics, but I plan to check those out a little more as the time goes on.So far, great game.  The first expansion is being released in a few days from this review, and I can't wait to see what these guys come up with!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												The core game is pretty good with lots of character diversity and future potential, however the end game is currently rather lack luster having a high barrier to entry putting you largely at the mercy of the gods of RNG, who are never kind. This game suffers from some of the worst RNG issues i've ever seen, and generally is designed to cater to the super hardcore element. The cosmetic microtransactions which fund the game are extremely expensive however there is no pay to win, unless you count buying extra stash space which to be honest is kind of necessary for any serious player; expect to dump $50-$100 on stash tabs if you get sucked into this game just to have room for your basic needs. The amount of storage space you get for free is rather pitiful; my advice is to wait for a stash tab bundle sale as they seem to happen on average once a month. The biggest thing holding this game back is the antiquated trade system. Because of the bad RNG issue the only way to truely progress into end game is to trade for the things you need, if you try and play only self found you will get no where in end game very slowly. The developer promissed a robust trade system through their website back in beta but have so far failed to deliver and don't seem to have it as a development priority; the game suffers immensely because of this.I'd recommend POE If you were a fan of diablo 2 and thought diablo 3 was terrible, you will probably enjoy this game. If you are the kind of person who can't handle complex character development then you will definately hate this game.

												This game is a bit of an oddity... when you begin to play, the content and possibilities are so far beyond comprehension. So you will basically create couple (2 - 5) characters that are completely unplayable because you don't know what you're doing. Eventually you get the idea behind creating characters that should be viable, and then create a couple (2-5) characters that are viable until the late stages of the game and only then become unviable to play... Eventually you get frustrated and go see a tutorial and realize none of your characters actually had any potential because you weren't familiar with aspects such as douple dipping, defences and minmaxing one aspect of the game to its fullest potential. Then you create a recommended character, grind and farm for weeks and then you realize that the freedom you originally thought you had in creating characters was lost somewhere. Having played ~1300 hours of this, I still don't know how to make unique characters that can finish the entire game - that said, maybe I am just a slow learner. Perhaps the next ~1300 hours are the key of understanding...

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Path of Exile is actually one of the BEST MMOs I've ever played. The combat itself isn't really different from any other MMORPG's, but the gem system and how they give you skills is definitely pretty unique. You aren't bombarded by microtransactions, if at all, and I like how it works on an instance system.So far the game hasn't been overly hard, but I've died here and there. There are a few especially hard parts that I really liked, like the final boss of Act 1.The community is definitely a big part of the game. Most people in chat are kind enough to give new players help, and having the trade chat helps people trade stuff for other stuff.What I really love is the flexibility of each character, due to the passive skills. It's totally viable to make your duelist magic-focused, ranged, or even all-around. Graphics-wise, the game looks pretty great. The places in game are beautiful, especially the forest areas in Act 2 and the town in Act 3. It's also pretty aesthetically pleasing, and has a nice vibrant mood to it.The only complaints I have are how long it takes for the game to load up sometimes, but that's probably because of my mediocre laptop. The story is a little negligible and none of the NPCs so far have really been memorable, but they're nice to have around anyways.Overall, yes, you should try this game. It's free to play, so you've got nothing to lose by at least trying it out, but if you like other games like Torchlight or Diablo, then you'll definitely like this game too.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Path of Exile is one of those games that I really wish I would have put a lot more time into sooner. It is one of those rare free to play games that doesn't attempt to cram microtransactions down your throat at every turn. It is also rare in that character building is insanely in-depth. It is actually possible to get lost looking at the skill grid because of how huge it is, and it really leaves you with a great variety of different ways to build each character. Do you want to be a tank? A necromancer that can summon armies of undead? An archer that can fill the screen with arrows? You can do all of that and so much more.A word of warning, however: This game is quite difficult if you are not a veteran of similar games. But if you can adapt to the learning curve, it is definitely a game that will reward you for your efforts and time spent.

												Woops, I didn't write a review on this one?Thus I, too, am to blame this gem didn't/doesn't get the audience it deserves.Yes, I also don't trust Free-to-Play games. I don't like the business model and I don't like the way their gameplay mechanics  function.This, however, is one of the few games which are TRUELY free-to-play. This game is so fair you almost feel bad if you don't pay anything (maybe that's how they get you to spend your money... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!). The things you can buy are purely decorative except for cheap extra space in your item chest (but it's already so big you don't even need it if you just play through the game once or twice).So yeah, what you get absolutely for free here is a full game and there's nothing that feels cheap about it. It does have a rather classical feel, though. Actually, this is the only other game which gave me that Diablo II feeling. It's not the same and Path of Exile has a lot of good gameplay ideas and a whole fantasy world of its own, so don't expect a clone.It's been a while now that I've played through it and I cannot really point out any details about what I liked especially and what bothered me, but I do remember I had a good time with this and if you liked Diablo II you should really give this one a try. Because it has had some big updates and new content since I've stopped playing I might pick it up again soon. Maybe playing alongside you guys because co-op playing works quite well also :)

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												*This review was for the "Sacrifice of Vaal" It has since been updated (A lot) and I look forward to updating the review*Hello Close friends and strangers of the internet, I'm back from Melbourne and, after 16 hours of gaming in the back seat of my car, feel the need to review the game "Path of Exile." Let's get startedI'd like to preface this review by saying that This Game Is Free. You've got nothing to lose by installing it."Path of Exile" is a Massive Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game (I could have said "MMO RPG" but I sound like a legitimate game critic when I say it like that) Which I'm sure is a genre that we've all had our experiences in (Runescape, Rift Ect.) I have to say out of all the games I've played in this genre, this one is done very well. The mechanics are commendable but not overly different, the storyline and variation of the missions, average. The graphics aren't fantastic, but hey, it's a free game. What do you expect? I'm yet to try out the Co-op (Mainly because I have a serious lack of friends) But the duelling system is fairly balanced and fair and overall, games like this are just generally addictingNow, I know your probably losing interest because this is sounding like every other MMO RPG but hold on, I'm getting to the good stuffThe best thing about this game is easily the passive skill tree. I know that sounds underwhelming but trust me, It could take days to plot a good path through this thing, I'm just trying to guess which direction I should head but in reality, this skill tree is so big it doesn't even fit on my computer screen. It's taken me 10 hours to figure out how the class and items work together (shown directly below.)Forgive me if I’ve gotten this wrong, I've only played through the first act as a witch (Yeah, I'm still a noob)I like to think of the class system as a colour wheel. There are 3 primary classes (one focused on intelligence, one on strength and one on dexterity) and 3 secondary classes, each one composed of 2 others (The duellist focuses on Strength and dexterity, the cleric focuses on strength and intelligence and the thief focuses on dexterity and intelligence.) These different classes all dictate where you start on the passive skill tree, shaped like a colour wheel. Most of the powerful items are clearly designed for a certain class as the all require a combination of the three traits (Intelligence, strength and dexterity) One that only requires intelligence is obviously designed for the person who is starts in the middle of the "Intelligence" area in the passive skill tree Whereas an item that requires dexterity and strength is made for the class which is a combo of dexterity and strength.Wow, that probably confused the F*ck out of you guys, it's really difficult to explain, it's so complex you could spend hours researching it.The items all have combinations of 3 different traits (Wow, the developers must've really liked the number 3!) Evasion, energy shield and amour. Evasion determines how likely you are to dodge an attack, Amour determines how much of the damage is block and energy shield reminds me a lot of the "overshield" from Halo or Mass Effect. It exists and if attacked, the energy shield is drained rather than your health. When the energy shield is depleted, you will have no defences other than your amour and evasion skills. The energy shield will restore after a period of not being attacked. However, your health will regenerate very slowly regardless of which items you wear. Each of the traits the amour has (Evasion, Amour and Energy shield) Link up to the traits the class has (Dexterity for Evasion, Amour for strength and Energy shield for intelligence) This is not a set rule but most items will have a requirement to meet.Are you still following me? If you're not, it's okay. Even If I confused you, you’re probably noticing how in-depth this game is.Finally, slots of amour have different coloured gem slots. There are three different coloured gems (So many ♥♥♥♥ING THREES!) And 3 different coloured gems (AHHHHHHH) which all link up to the 3 traits of the classes (I think I'm developing a "3" fetish) The red gems are usually for Melee combat, the green ones are for archery and the blue ones for magic. Some monsters resist certain types of these abilities, some resist fire, frost or lightning. Some monsters also can summon smaller units, perform similar abilities to what the player can perform and some monsters have energy shields.Okay, I'm done. Thanks for reading if you made it this far. Click the like button if you did. I swear, it took ages to write this out and last review I did, not a single person liked it :(. I strongly recommend this game for all people who love a good MMO RPG. I would love to have one of my close friend (Jacob, Brodie, Dom, Josh, Lachlan, Sam, I'm looking at you guys.) to pick up this game so that I wouldn't have to continue this crazily confusing experience alone. All in all, because it's a free game I'm giving it an 8.5/10

												There's alot of pro and cons for this game.-Better stat/skill system than the 100s of RPG's I played so far.-True f2p, no pay to win stuff.-Great graphics.-Extremely long-term game, you can probably play for 100 hours+ and still want to try new builds.-Tons of updates and player-made uniques.There's also a few bad things about the game...-You spend more time thinking about builds than playing the game, this is very true if you want a ''perfect'' character, because you need to plan everything or buy regrets orbs/ reset your bandits quest rewards ( Via in game currency. )Overall this game is 100% worth trying, It has a good Diablo feeling and the way trading works is with Orbs/Items trading, there's no gold.Also this game is about to get Act V added to it, I can't wait!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Diablo fans rejoice!  Path of Exile is without a doubt the prodigal successor to a franchise that's getting harder to innovate and draw people in every year.  PoE just nails it, all of it!  From the gothic art style and the mood defining music to the near endless list of innovations that make this game so great and really set it apart in an extremely positive way from any other action RPG.  If you haven't gotten yourself lost in Wraeclast, do yourself a favor and install this game immediately.Some of the highlights with this game     - Nearly limitless amount of itemization     - Really unique mana/health replenishment system (Flasks that refill and have special properties)     - Huge amount of skill combinations involving gems that can be linked in nearly limitless ways     - A passive skill tree that has millions (yes millions!) of different useful and interesting combos     - Huge community that is backed by a passionate developer team that even today continues to support and improve gameplay     - Excellent endgame that is still being developed (maps, hideouts, etc.)     - 6 player co-op     - Leagues and race events that can earn you prizes     - hundreds and hundred of useful uniques that change the way you play in a variety of ways...and the list goes on!

												Think of the elements that made Diablo II great, meddle it with Torchlight and add some new stuff: the result is Path of Exile, a game that is far too good to be a free to play game. You don't even need to play anything to become superior to the other players: the microtransactions are moslty cosmetics. There are paid games out there that don't have 10% of PoE's quality. Everything in this game is perfect; only the story is a little confusing and uninspiring, but the lore is pleasant. From the reliable community to the constant patches, this is a very friendly game, both for you and for your low-end PC. Without prolonging this review a lot more, let me just say that it took me about 20 hours to do a single playthough, which is a lot more than some AAA titles present. If you like ARPG, or just RPG, or even just a action game, there is no excuse for not to, at least, try this wonderful game. I give it a 92 out of 100. Best free to play game of 2013 and probably one of the best free to play games out there.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Path of Exile is a truly free to play dungeon crawler that will make someone watching a video clip think it is from the "Diablo" series. It isn't Diablo but it is in my opinion a better game than the Diablo series. There are six playable characters at the start and once the game has been beaten once and a side mission at the end of the game (that is along the required walking path but is optional) unlocks the seventh class.All skills are based on gems that are tied to either Intelligence (Blue), Strength (Red), or Dexterity (Green). While gems of a certain color do highly favor one syle of gameplay (red = melee attacks most of the time) their are exceptions such as a red gem unlocking a "Totem", basically a distraction device skill. Items have sockets to place the gems in. While you can use more than 8 skills, the UI sets up the bindable skill keys to Mouse Left Click, Mouse Middle Click, Mouse Right Click, Q, W, E, R, T keys. So when playing 8 skills are generally available with Mouse Left Click usually being bound to a hybrid of basic weapon melee attack and movement. Gems level up from the same experience your character gains. The gems just level up at different rates from your character class. The gems also have the same type of restrictions that items do such as minimum level and minimum stats (intelligence, strength, and dexterity) in order to equip them. This means that you could play as a Witch (Pure intelligence character build) and socket a red gem for a skill you'll never use. The gem will gain levels but it would be a better choice to stash the red gem for another character to use.Gems/skills are modified by the extensive passive leveling system. Each level up and some quests give points to follow along the giant path available to you. The leveling "board" for lack of a better term is the same for all characters but different characters start at different places on the board. Here is a link for the seventh class, the Scion, who starts in the very middle of the board. https://poebuilder.com/character/AAAAAgAA The most interesting part of this game is that it does not have gold as a currency. There are something like 40 different currency items but they are acquired by trading in equipment. So everything you sell will come back as a currency that benefits in game as well as allowing trading with other players to be a lot more varied. Static prices don't really exist and almost all items that can be bought from NPCs are there for a specific reason.This leads to the one flaw in the game, inventory management. Trading with NPC vendors requires knowing some "recipes", certain combinations of items that give back the best payment. You start the game with 4 pages in your cross-character "stash" and the same inventory size for every character. There is no increasing character inventory size. You can increase your stash size but that does cost real life money. A 4 page stash means making stockpiles to fulfill recipe requirements and frequently selling. With more tabs a user could get better returns on their equipment. I'd like more stash pages but the game doesn't require having 4 to be a good player. It just severally restricts how many items you can horde. Hording wouldn't be a problem if there was any type of inventory sorting but there is not. Unfortunately at latter game interverals art assets get reused so it can be difficult to tell between the low level item you want to trade versus the high level item you've been saving. In conclusion, I recommend the game. Just be sure to learn the economic system of the game before you start playing it.

Posted: December 15, 2013
												12/15/2013 - This is a great action RPG that I consider to be on the same level as genre epics like Diablo, Torchlight, and Titan Quest in regards to gameplay, fun, design, and visuals.  I'm sure you'll find the same praise in most of the Steam and online reviews.  However, I cannot wholly recommend the game because of the continuous problems with lag or as the community often refers to it:  desync.  No, it's not a problem with my computer or connection.  It's widespread and encountered often.  I've lost 2 hardcore characters to desync; it's not fun when all the time you invested into your character is thrown away due to lag.  The problem is that everything has to run online through their server (no offline play), and due to how well they developed the game, there are too many people playing on the server resources currently in place.  If they made it so that you could play a character offline or seriously revamped the network code and server resources, this would be a perfect game.  In its current state, as good as the game is, I find it too frustrating to consistently enjoy.  The devs are very good about listening to the community and improving/updating the game, so hopefully it's only a matter of time before the desync issues are fixed.

												Their Customer support is probably the worst you've experienced in any game.  My email address that I used to register the game can no longer receive mail.  To change my email address I had to first provide them with...- The account name, date, time and location the account was created- The IP address you created the account from, or if this is not possible, the IP address you last played from... odd requests to begin with for an email address change.  I was actually able to provide these things...Follow-up- Can you please let us know whether you have made any purchases on the account from the online store.I have not...Follow-up- Could you please create a throwaway account (preferably using another email address), create a character on it and start the first level, then provide us with the account name or email address that you used?- Could you also please send us your client.txt file? It can be found under the Path of Exile\logs directory, and you may have to .zip it as it can be quite large.I could not perform this request without downloading a non-steam version.  Continuing to play this game was not worth this effort to me.  I believe they were starting to send me on a run around as I have not purchased anything from them.--- As for the game in GeneralPros:The game was generally fun.The talent tree is huge, and allows for super customization, which may actually be a con for any casual player.  Cons:The graphics are not great by any means.  You cant tab out and back in while in fullscreen mode without the game crashing, as far as I know that has been an issue for years.  Here is a thread from 2013...https://www.pathofexile.com/forum/view-thread/654101You can eventually reach a Hard stop where you character cannot progress any further.  This does not seem to be as much of an issue in rival games like Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2.  In addition to this, there is no good respec option if you surpass a certain level.  You can only back out one point at a time with a rather rare item drop.

												I wish there was an option between "recommended" and "not recommended" because that's the choice I would pick. After weighing all the pros and cons I have to "not recommend" this game in the end. Anyway, let's get into some details.ARPGs are something I love to spend countless hours in. I love the grind and getting those sweet loot drops and then repeating this process over and over again until every slot is GG/BiS gear. I love trying different builds and min/maxing my stats as much as possible. All of this is possible in PoE. In fact, PoE is one of the most hardcore ARPGs out there. Many people have compared it favorably to D2. The build diversity in this game is absolutely insane due to the passive tree and skill gems, along with how these skill gems interact with each other by linking them in armor and weapons. If you want depth you absolutely will find it in this game - in fact at first I was quite overwhelmed. For example, when discussing "crits" in this game you need to keep in mind the difference between local critical chance on weapon attacks, critical chance on spells, global critical chance, and critical damage multipliers (which I guess can be both local and global and can either be on attacks and/or spells). It is not like D3 in which critical chance is a flat additive percentage for everything. Anyway, this is only one example. The game is very nuanced and Google is your best friend if you don't understand something.So yeah, I love all the depth in the game, so why am I not recommending this? Simple. The endgame trading is absolutely horrendous. I reached the beginning of endgame (level 70) and I should just grind low level maps or areas like merciless Dried Lake for loot and currency. Well...that doesn't really work. In order to get the best items for your build you NEED to trade. But since there's no gold in the game it's difficult to judge whether an item is worth 1 Chaos or 2 Chaos or whatever other currency. This is especially true for new players like me who want to get started in trading but the entire buisness is already monopolized by the streamers and other "pro players". The loot drops are terrible - the chance of finding a rare or unique that's worth a few Chaos or Exalted is extremely low. Maybe if you do a pure MF build it'll be better, but my point is, I just want to use my build and farm enemies and find good endgame gear. There would be no point in build diversity if you have to use a MF build just to have a chance of finding some BiS stuff.So here I am, at endgame with a few Chaos orbs and zero Exalted. I want to buy some items by using poe.trade (community trade site) but most people are not online and/or they are fake accounts. Using trade chat is a joke - just full of spammers and people trying to lowball you for profit. And how am I suppose to sell anything? Use poe.trade? Set up a shop on the forums? Very tedious and troublesome because not only do I have to jump through hoops to do it, there's no gurantee anyone will buy my stuff or offer fair prices. I want to play an ARPG not "trade simulator extreme edition".tl;dr - The biggest turn off for me is the endgame trading. It's absolutely garbage and DAS (dumb as♥♥♥♥♥♥. The rest of the game is quite good and I did enjoy it. But we all know for games like this the endgame will either make or break the game. I hope the developers will add in a streamlined in-game trading system in the near future, but until then, I will not be coming back.

												This game is fantastic! It reminds a lot the gameplay of Diablo franchise, being a classic point & click action-RPG. If you're a fan of Diablo, you should definitely play it.As a low point of the game, the history is not as enganging as Diablo was. I still remember the first time I played it, the felling of going down to Hell to kill Diablo itself kept me going on. Do not expect something that remarkable on Path of Exile.The are some innovation on this game. The first is the fact that your potions replenish as you kill enemies. This saves you to keep returning to town to buy extra health/mana potions and make the game more dynamic. Also, you don't have money/gold in this game. The game currency are the items that you use to improve your weaponry/armory (as orbs or scrolls of identify). So, you need to decide between using the items to buy new weapons/armors or to improve the ones you already have.In conclusion, this game is a must play for fans of hack and slash action-RPG, like myself. But being a free-to-play game, I recommend everybody to give it a try. I'm sure you're going to enjoy it.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												You probably thought this would be another pros and cons review. Well, you were right, but first, let me tell you some general things and I'll end with my opinion at the end of the review.PoE is a hack and slash ARPG that has an incredible amount of depth. It has so much depth that it was the main reason for me to switch from Diablo 3 to PoE. Apart from the many, many uniques there is a huge passive tree, so extensive that it gives you nearly endless possibilites to customise and direct your character build. It is responsive in terms of casting abilites, skills, attacking, moving, etc, much like Diablo 3. The graphics are great in my opinion, the game uses less bright colors compared to diablo 3 and is less prone to giving you epileptic seizures.Let's first get rid of the cons:-inconcsistent FPS --> really demanding game in terms of requirements, it will run smoothly and then some cluster♥♥♥♥ of spells and abilities will produce an fps drop (maybe it's just me though, but I think I have a pretty good pc)-server crashes sometimes appear, altough it's not that often to really undermine the game. It's rare but it's there-if you are playing on an EU server it is possible to enter groups with NA players (for example) that will switch you to their server and consequently increase your ping to ~500ms-the start of the game is really slow, meaning that you will not have that start as in Diablo 3 for example where you start hacking and slashing furiously at lvl1, PoE requires higher attack speed/cast speed to achieve that level of speed/responsivnes. Meaning you will have the fast game in the late game.-it's a grinding gameNow for the pros:-free to play (not pay to win, don't worry, all microtransactions are merely cosmetic apart from the stash extentions)-huge depth: a really high number of different builds that are all viable in some way and customisation of everything (from your gear and hideouts to the maps that you will be tackling on in late game)-responsivnes-a massive amount of late game content-races where you can earn unique rewards-fun leagues with unique rules that last for 3 months each: new economy, fresh start and rewards-permanent leagues-it's hard as ♥♥♥♥ to reach lvl100-it's a grinding gameAll in all I recommend this game. Why? Because you have stuff to do. Yes it's grindy but at least you have the satisfactory soul fulfiling skills/abillities that destroy enemies to your hearts content in many more ways than one. My point is you will never get bored because you can always make a unique build that you will enjoy. A build tailored for you, by you, not by external sites. My only recommendation is that you plan and learn in advance. Well, those are my main reasons why I switched to this game. It's excellent, really, and I would recommend you try it, after all, it's free to play. I'd rate this game 9/10.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												In my opinion, Path of Exile is the best action RPG ever made, and the best FTP game, and most certainly the best game ever made in New Zealand.If you know NZ, it's a pretty small place, and not a place where you'd think an epic game could be made. I knew one of the lead devs before this game was created. When I heard he was trying to make a game similar to Diablo II, I was shocked at the idea of it. I didn't think it would be possible to make an indy game in New Zealand that could possibly rival the king of action RPGs. Well ... the king was dethroned, long live the new king of action RPGs! PoE is simply an awesomely epic game that I will no doubt be playing for many years.I have been playing since closed beta and I love how PoE keeps getting more great content. The community is active and the devs pay attention to feedback. I say that having witnessed it many times after feedback was given during beta.I was a big Diablo fan and a massive Diablo II fan. After Diablo II, there was  a void left in my gaming life, until PoE came along that is.The creators of this game are gamers too, and took the best parts of some games, added a cool story, and meshed it all into this amazing game. They did some things that are really unique, and a massive change from most aRPGs. For example, there is no gold! Instead, scrolls and orbs are the currency that PoE uses. It makes sense, too; what use is gold to an exile who is fighting for their life?The modest system requirements and the fact that this game is Free to Play lets almost anyone play the game. There are no "Pay to Win" options, which keeps everyone on a level playing field. Many of the options available for purchase are cosmetic options, like the ability to make your favourite gear look different. Other options allow you to purchase more tabs in your shared stash, more for your guild, and similar things. The only in-game benefits you will get is the ability to store more items, or sometimes more light radius that can help out a little when you're in a dark place.This game works well with both multiplayer and single player. It's a hard game, but very rewarding. The skill tree is simply massive, and can be overwhelming at first. But the skill tree is what makes so many interesting builds possible.The atmosphere of this game is amazing. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is great, and the extra sounds were very well done. The first time I heard the screams in one particular area, I got chills up and down my spine. If you liked other action RPGs, you will most likely love PoE. Give it a go, there's nothing to lose other than a bit of your time and a few gigs to download.

Posted: January 25, 2014
												Now Path of Exile is a game that I have followed since it's early closed beta days and I've played since then too. This is one of the best Hack 'n Slash Action RPG games that you will find this year and what's more it is entirely free to play (yes a real free to play the only thing you pay real money for are cosmetics like extra gore, different skin on items so that you look a little unique, pets that do nothing but follow you or more warehouse slots etc). The gameplay it self is pretty much Diablo 2 style. One amazing thing about the game to note is the skill tree and the way you can develop it... the possibilities are endless! Basically the skill tree is just passive skills while the spells and similar that you use to fight are "gems" which you have to embed in your weapons/armors, what's more is that there are no class bound items so basically you can make a Ranger use staffs and use magic, a Marauder use bow and a Witch use a giant sword and that's not all, every single class has the same skill tree with the class being just the way you character looks and the starting possition in the skill tree. The skills in this game are amazing. To use a skill you have to find a gem with that skill, meet the level and stat requerments and put it inside a gem slow in your weapon/armor. Each weapon/armor can have up to 4/6 slots with 3 different color and skill gems also have 3 different color types (based on Strength, Dexterity and Intelligence) and those slots on the weapon can be linked together so you can merge 2 or 3 different skills effects (using support gems with normal skills gems) to add new type of effects to your skills and make them even stronger.The crafting and currency systems in the game are really unique and awesome the normal currency used in other games like gold for example is totally removed and everything revolves around trading items and the currency items are the same as upgrade items (adding new options to you armor/weapons, socketing, changing their type from normal, magic, rare ..etc)PoE is definitely my favorite Hack 'n Slash game together with the classic Diablo 2. It's a must try game for RPG fans and I would recomend it to all of you ;).

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												You probably thought this would be another pros and cons review. Well, you were right, but first, let me tell you some general things and I'll end with my opinion at the end of the review.PoE is a hack and slash ARPG that has an incredible amount of depth. It has so much depth that it was the main reason for me to switch from Diablo 3 to PoE. Apart from the many, many uniques there is a huge passive tree, so extensive that it gives you nearly endless possibilites to customise and direct your character build. It is responsive in terms of casting abilites, skills, attacking, moving, etc, much like Diablo 3. The graphics are great in my opinion, the game uses less bright colors compared to diablo 3 and is less prone to giving you epileptic seizures.Let's first get rid of the cons:-inconcsistent FPS --> really demanding game in terms of requirements, it will run smoothly and then some cluster♥♥♥♥ of spells and abilities will produce an fps drop (maybe it's just me though, but I think I have a pretty good pc)-server crashes sometimes appear, altough it's not that often to really undermine the game. It's rare but it's there-if you are playing on an EU server it is possible to enter groups with NA players (for example) that will switch you to their server and consequently increase your ping to ~500ms-the start of the game is really slow, meaning that you will not have that start as in Diablo 3 for example where you start hacking and slashing furiously at lvl1, PoE requires higher attack speed/cast speed to achieve that level of speed/responsivnes. Meaning you will have the fast game in the late game.-it's a grinding gameNow for the pros:-free to play (not pay to win, don't worry, all microtransactions are merely cosmetic apart from the stash extentions)-huge depth: a really high number of different builds that are all viable in some way and customisation of everything (from your gear and hideouts to the maps that you will be tackling on in late game)-responsivnes-a massive amount of late game content-races where you can earn unique rewards-fun leagues with unique rules that last for 3 months each: new economy, fresh start and rewards-permanent leagues-it's hard as ♥♥♥♥ to reach lvl100-it's a grinding gameAll in all I recommend this game. Why? Because you have stuff to do. Yes it's grindy but at least you have the satisfactory soul fulfiling skills/abillities that destroy enemies to your hearts content in many more ways than one. My point is you will never get bored because you can always make a unique build that you will enjoy. A build tailored for you, by you, not by external sites. My only recommendation is that you plan and learn in advance. Well, those are my main reasons why I switched to this game. It's excellent, really, and I would recommend you try it, after all, it's free to play. I'd rate this game 9/10.

Posted: November 9, 2013
												Poor man's (free to play) Diablo. The gem/skill system is interesting, which is reminicent of Final Fantasy 7's materia system. The graphics are decent enough and there's plenty of loot to be had and depth in combining skills by linking slots together (ala support materia in FF7). However...The always-online aspect of this game is not so great, though. Rubberbanding is fairly consistent, even with a low ping. The game itself is the gatekeeper for your fun, dictating how viable you are by not only gear drops, but what skills you have access to. The time-sink basis of the game is a bit of a turn off. Expect to carefully plan a character and have it nerfed to bejesus, thereby ending your character as many have been so vocal about online, since resetting a character's skills is basically impossible. The currency system favors NPCs at every level, and the loot system is a free-for-all grabfest, so play with people you trust.If you play this game, play with a group. Play with friends. Solo I can imagine is a nightmare considering how tempermental drops can be, but crushing things in a group and splitting loot means there's fun times for those seeking them.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Long story short, this is one of the most engaging games I've played in many years. Path of Exile is a nearly perfect blend of intelligent complexity and mass destruction. It's probably not so intricate that a disinterested player wouldn't be able to find enjoyment, but it's certainly geared toward those who are inclined to plan, research, experiment, and occasionally fail in order to really flesh out their experience with the game.And, as you've probably noticed, Path of Exile is completely free with no strings attached; the download is free, there's no subscription, expansions and patches are free (and frequent), and will remain so until the Earth burns up in a few billion years. The only things you can possibly buy with real money are almost exclusively cosmetic features, such as different visual effects for certain spells, visual affects for your character/gear, passive pets, etc. The only two non-cosmetic exceptions I can think of are increased and customizeable storage space in your "stash" that's shared between characters (you start with four pages in the stash, which is not at all restrictive), and extra character slots (I don't even know how many character slots you start with, but I think I have eight characters and haven't yet seen the cap). If there were ever a situation where you get to "vote with your money," it's this. Ever bought a game and been disappointed but you already spent your cash? Ever wish you could have just played for hours on end without paying a dime just to see if the game is worth your time? This is part of what I love about Grinding Gear Games and their Path of Exile. Now that I've played a significant portion of the game I'm completely in love, and I'm fully justified in paying for some of the cosmetic features just so that I can help support the game and the dev team. I actually WANT to hand them my money at this point. And the best part is that I can pay however much I want, anything from $5 on up in exchange for microtransaction currency/coins, and even still get something extra for that money, like a mohawk made of spiked daggers or a crazy new look for my primary spell. Play for free, completely, forever, and if you do ever decide to give them some money you'll still be getting bonus stuff for a game you already love. It's simply amazing.The passive skill tree can be a little daunting even after a serious investment in the game, but it also becomes rather intuitive and you just get a sense for how to operate within it. Grinding Gear Games' Path of Exile website has the complete interactive skill tree on it so that you can play around and experiment without having to risk your character to do so, though you will have to (really easily) copy-paste the link to a seperate website to get a list of how it all translates in terms of your hp, increased damage, resistances, and so on.To describe the systems far more simply, and probably more boringly, than they deserve, Path of Exile essentially works like so, from my perspective. 1) Pick a class.Classes only differ in terms of their appearances, their starting stats, and where within the web of the passive skill tree they start, but not in terms of what abilities they can acquire or what parts of the skill tree they can reach.2) Work the Skill Tree.This passive skill tree seems to be a pretty significant divergence from your standard fare where one would usually expect to be able to specialize by putting points into certain abilities; instead, as you level up you put your points into qualities and abilities that work in the background of your character. Most of these passives are individually fairly mundane, but many of them can single-handedly change the way your character will function.3) Use your skills.Your abilities come in the form of specialty items that you can acquire through quests, random drops, or player trades, just like your equipment, and there are tons of them. Further, these ability items (gems) get placed on your armor essentially in sequences of your choosing such that they can have their effects altered.4) Horde, and use, your currency.There's no gold in this game, which also means you won't find any gold farmers. The items that get used as currency are all things that you can actually use in the game to do stuff, not just a medium for transactions like gold would be. Each currency item does something different; among others, some of the currencies (orbs) can be used to upgrade a common item to a rare item, reroll the stats on a rare item, change the socket colors or socket links on an item, improve item quality, and so forth. These currencies are random drops as well as acquired by selling your gear or trading other currency items to NPC vendors, as well as by trading with players.4) Rock your gear.The equipment is far more interesting than most any game I've played for two reasons. First, you can change any item in any way, though doing some of this can be quite difficult to achieve, such that you can take a perfectly common item and turn it into an amazing piece of equipment with your currency orbs; this significantly changes the standard "farm until it drops" scenario that these types of games usually run into. Second, the ability gems have specific colors and they go into the same color sockets on armor such that blue gems go into blue sockets, green into green, and red into red (there are only three color types); the number, color, and connections between the sockets can do everything from simply allowing you to use multiple skills to significantly changing the way one or many skills operate. Equipment also has all the normal stuff you'd expect in a game like this, like various defensive or offensive stat bonuses, the occasional skill bonus, or whatever else. And, again, you get to alter all of the elements of your items, like taking a common item that has the sockets you want and upgrading it from a common item to a rare item, then if you don't like the random stats on your new rare item you can reroll the stats, or change the colors and orientations of the sockets, and so on. You're never, ever just stuck with whatever equipment happens to be dropping for you. Putting these qualities together makes for the least boring gearing system I've seen.Now you roll all this stuff into one game and you get a really complex and compelling experience with a massive amount of customizability and replayability. Each aspect influences the others and there are absolutely no restricting ways to play your character. Spread yourself across the passive skill tree, then put abilities on your gear to compliment your spec; or find abilities you really want to use and then spec in the skill tree to augment or alter how they work. Define the type of character you're going to play ahead of time and restrict yourself to just those types of items, abilities, and passive skills; or flow through the game and define yourself as you go. There are definitely many specific paths that some people prefer, or some that are easier, or more defensive, or more offensive, pet based, supporting, etc., but you will find absolutely no shortage of wild and crazy speculative or even wildly divergent safe/noob-friendly specs on the forums or elsewhere online.But all of these intricacies mean that you'll get the most out of Path of Exile by spending some time researching, whether it's scouring the forums or just watching some YouTube vids of people playing and explaining their particular character build. The more you learn, the more the game opens up and starts to seem even more and more exciting. I've put over 100 hours in at this point and, no matter how much I think I know, I search for something I'm uncertain about and find a whole new aspect of the game that I hadn't even considered yet. I see myself playing Path of Exile far into the future, and will support the game and the dev team with my money by choice, at my own

												In my opinion, Path of Exile is the best action RPG ever made, and the best FTP game, and most certainly the best game ever made in New Zealand.If you know NZ, it's a pretty small place, and not a place where you'd think an epic game could be made. I knew one of the lead devs before this game was created. When I heard he was trying to make a game similar to Diablo II, I was shocked at the idea of it. I didn't think it would be possible to make an indy game in New Zealand that could possibly rival the king of action RPGs. Well ... the king was dethroned, long live the new king of action RPGs! PoE is simply an awesomely epic game that I will no doubt be playing for many years.I have been playing since closed beta and I love how PoE keeps getting more great content. The community is active and the devs pay attention to feedback. I say that having witnessed it many times after feedback was given during beta.I was a big Diablo fan and a massive Diablo II fan. After Diablo II, there was  a void left in my gaming life, until PoE came along that is.The creators of this game are gamers too, and took the best parts of some games, added a cool story, and meshed it all into this amazing game. They did some things that are really unique, and a massive change from most aRPGs. For example, there is no gold! Instead, scrolls and orbs are the currency that PoE uses. It makes sense, too; what use is gold to an exile who is fighting for their life?The modest system requirements and the fact that this game is Free to Play lets almost anyone play the game. There are no "Pay to Win" options, which keeps everyone on a level playing field. Many of the options available for purchase are cosmetic options, like the ability to make your favourite gear look different. Other options allow you to purchase more tabs in your shared stash, more for your guild, and similar things. The only in-game benefits you will get is the ability to store more items, or sometimes more light radius that can help out a little when you're in a dark place.This game works well with both multiplayer and single player. It's a hard game, but very rewarding. The skill tree is simply massive, and can be overwhelming at first. But the skill tree is what makes so many interesting builds possible.The atmosphere of this game is amazing. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is great, and the extra sounds were very well done. The first time I heard the screams in one particular area, I got chills up and down my spine. If you liked other action RPGs, you will most likely love PoE. Give it a go, there's nothing to lose other than a bit of your time and a few gigs to download.
