content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Long story short, this is one of the most engaging games I've played in many years. Path of Exile is a nearly perfect blend of intelligent complexity and mass destruction. It's probably not so intricate that a disinterested player wouldn't be able to find enjoyment, but it's certainly geared toward those who are inclined to plan, research, experiment, and occasionally fail in order to really flesh out their experience with the game.And, as you've probably noticed, Path of Exile is completely free with no strings attached; the download is free, there's no subscription, expansions and patches are free (and frequent), and will remain so until the Earth burns up in a few billion years. The only things you can possibly buy with real money are almost exclusively cosmetic features, such as different visual effects for certain spells, visual affects for your character/gear, passive pets, etc. The only two non-cosmetic exceptions I can think of are increased and customizeable storage space in your "stash" that's shared between characters (you start with four pages in the stash, which is not at all restrictive), and extra character slots (I don't even know how many character slots you start with, but I think I have eight characters and haven't yet seen the cap). If there were ever a situation where you get to "vote with your money," it's this. Ever bought a game and been disappointed but you already spent your cash? Ever wish you could have just played for hours on end without paying a dime just to see if the game is worth your time? This is part of what I love about Grinding Gear Games and their Path of Exile. Now that I've played a significant portion of the game I'm completely in love, and I'm fully justified in paying for some of the cosmetic features just so that I can help support the game and the dev team. I actually WANT to hand them my money at this point. And the best part is that I can pay however much I want, anything from $5 on up in exchange for microtransaction currency/coins, and even still get something extra for that money, like a mohawk made of spiked daggers or a crazy new look for my primary spell. Play for free, completely, forever, and if you do ever decide to give them some money you'll still be getting bonus stuff for a game you already love. It's simply amazing.The passive skill tree can be a little daunting even after a serious investment in the game, but it also becomes rather intuitive and you just get a sense for how to operate within it. Grinding Gear Games' Path of Exile website has the complete interactive skill tree on it so that you can play around and experiment without having to risk your character to do so, though you will have to (really easily) copy-paste the link to a seperate website to get a list of how it all translates in terms of your hp, increased damage, resistances, and so on.To describe the systems far more simply, and probably more boringly, than they deserve, Path of Exile essentially works like so, from my perspective. 1) Pick a class.Classes only differ in terms of their appearances, their starting stats, and where within the web of the passive skill tree they start, but not in terms of what abilities they can acquire or what parts of the skill tree they can reach.2) Work the Skill Tree.This passive skill tree seems to be a pretty significant divergence from your standard fare where one would usually expect to be able to specialize by putting points into certain abilities; instead, as you level up you put your points into qualities and abilities that work in the background of your character. Most of these passives are individually fairly mundane, but many of them can single-handedly change the way your character will function.3) Use your skills.Your abilities come in the form of specialty items that you can acquire through quests, random drops, or player trades, just like your equipment, and there are tons of them. Further, these ability items (gems) get placed on your armor essentially in sequences of your choosing such that they can have their effects altered.4) Horde, and use, your currency.There's no gold in this game, which also means you won't find any gold farmers. The items that get used as currency are all things that you can actually use in the game to do stuff, not just a medium for transactions like gold would be. Each currency item does something different; among others, some of the currencies (orbs) can be used to upgrade a common item to a rare item, reroll the stats on a rare item, change the socket colors or socket links on an item, improve item quality, and so forth. These currencies are random drops as well as acquired by selling your gear or trading other currency items to NPC vendors, as well as by trading with players.4) Rock your gear.The equipment is far more interesting than most any game I've played for two reasons. First, you can change any item in any way, though doing some of this can be quite difficult to achieve, such that you can take a perfectly common item and turn it into an amazing piece of equipment with your currency orbs; this significantly changes the standard "farm until it drops" scenario that these types of games usually run into. Second, the ability gems have specific colors and they go into the same color sockets on armor such that blue gems go into blue sockets, green into green, and red into red (there are only three color types); the number, color, and connections between the sockets can do everything from simply allowing you to use multiple skills to significantly changing the way one or many skills operate. Equipment also has all the normal stuff you'd expect in a game like this, like various defensive or offensive stat bonuses, the occasional skill bonus, or whatever else. And, again, you get to alter all of the elements of your items, like taking a common item that has the sockets you want and upgrading it from a common item to a rare item, then if you don't like the random stats on your new rare item you can reroll the stats, or change the colors and orientations of the sockets, and so on. You're never, ever just stuck with whatever equipment happens to be dropping for you. Putting these qualities together makes for the least boring gearing system I've seen.Now you roll all this stuff into one game and you get a really complex and compelling experience with a massive amount of customizability and replayability. Each aspect influences the others and there are absolutely no restricting ways to play your character. Spread yourself across the passive skill tree, then put abilities on your gear to compliment your spec; or find abilities you really want to use and then spec in the skill tree to augment or alter how they work. Define the type of character you're going to play ahead of time and restrict yourself to just those types of items, abilities, and passive skills; or flow through the game and define yourself as you go. There are definitely many specific paths that some people prefer, or some that are easier, or more defensive, or more offensive, pet based, supporting, etc., but you will find absolutely no shortage of wild and crazy speculative or even wildly divergent safe/noob-friendly specs on the forums or elsewhere online.But all of these intricacies mean that you'll get the most out of Path of Exile by spending some time researching, whether it's scouring the forums or just watching some YouTube vids of people playing and explaining their particular character build. The more you learn, the more the game opens up and starts to seem even more and more exciting. I've put over 100 hours in at this point and, no matter how much I think I know, I search for something I'm uncertain about and find a whole new aspect of the game that I hadn't even considered yet. I see myself playing Path of Exile far into the future, and will support the game and the dev team with my money by choice, at my own

Posted: May 29, 2014
												Path of Exile is one of the best games of it's genre and by far one of the best free games out there. Seriously, this should be a paid game because the amount of free content you get is pretty ridiculous. All story, class related and gameplay related parts of the game are accessible to everyone, and there is absolutely no element of "pay to win". Yes, there are microtransactions, but these are all for either cosmetic things like weapon effects or skins, or stash tabs which means you can store items. The story itself is pretty decent, but the depth of gameplay is where it shines. The passive tree is huge, and opens up a ton of different build ideas based on passives. The uniqueness of these builds are further enhanced by the large number of skills and support gems that go with them, with gems adding different effects to each skills in order to change their role or strengthen them. Skills and support gems can be switched up any time, encouraging a lot of customisation, and while there are no full respec items (although usually the devs hand out full respecs when the passive tree changes), there are items which enable the respeccing of passives, point-by point.I havent actually needed to use the support for the game yet, but I hear it's pretty good with the devs responding relatively quickly. I do know however that they do keep good contact with the community and do strive to improve the game as muh as they can.There are however, two minor problems with this game. One is that you can have an infinite number of particles on screen at any given time, which means that when the spells start flying around, certain builds can get laggy fast. Second of all, is the desync that you get sometimes. It can be quite frustrating to die due to desync, and unfortunately we don't know when/if this problem will be fixed Overall, if you enjoy the ARPG genre, or games such as Diablo II and Torchlight II, this is a must play. It is not only fully free for you to try, but it has a level of customisation that surpasses that of even some paid games.EDIT 13/3/17: After playing this game fow a few hundred more hours, I can say that this game has only continued to go from strength to strength over the course of the last few years. A lot of the desync problems have been fixed and the game has run much more smoothly for me after various performance updates they've dished out. The content has continually been expanding, with a whole 6 new acts coming soon!. This is well and truly one of my favourite games to play and easily my favourite of the genre

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												If you enjoy action rpgs - especially Diablo 1 and 2, then you must give Path of Exile a try. I have been a gamer all my life, and Diablo 2 was the game I have regularly played the longest (I think around 3 years).I was very happy with PoE when I started earlier in June - it really is a spiritual successor for Diablo 2. You can play through it by yourself, although it can get pretty difficult that way. If you like Arpg's with A LOT of depth, I would highly recommend it. I would also highly recommend NOT playing it, if you value your time - as it can become supremely addicting. The nice thing about the online component is that there are leagues, like Standard and Hardcore, and even then there isn't any "true" permadeath, as dying in Hardcore league will simply transfer your character to the Standard one. You share your loot among ALL characters in the SAME league.There are also Ambush and Invasion leagues. Ambush is considered softcore because it's actually a lot easier - there are "strongboxes" that usually contain better loot but are guarded by stronger enemies. Invasion is hardcore, enemies and bosses from other areas (called "instances") will come into your current area periodically. Death in Invasion puts your character into Standard league.The nice thing about these leagues is that it only runs for 4 months. After that, your characters are put into standard league. This usually results in "junk" loot, where your standard chest will have hoards of loot. This also resets the economy, maintaining a constant level-playing field for newcomers.The PASSIVE skill map...oh dear. If you've played Final Fantasy 10, it's similar to the sphere grid. The customization of skills is absolutely ridiculous. That being said, the skill map is fantastic in that it is accessible to ALL classes. The only difference is that each class starts off in a different section of the map. For example, the Witch (mage) will be closer to intelligence-related nodes, while the templar will be close to the intelligence and strength ones (which also are elemental dmg/res and staff nodes). Near the end of the game, you will unlock the Scion, who starts off at the center of the map. In this sense, you can even have a Ranger summoner who uses a Templar staff, but it would be much less viable and efficient in terms of maximizing your area of the grid. The nice thing about your character resetting to Standard league is you get FULL respec points, so you can change up your build and experiment. There is also official (and unofficial) skill maps that let you play with the nodes and give you good feedback on how your character will look on pen and paper.Once you get a general feel for the game, focusing on one skill is very accurate - best advice for new people is to research the skills (available on the website) and decide which one you'd like to use. There are unlocked active skills when you level up, instead, all active skills come in the form of skill gems. Most equipment have skill gem sockets, and there are items that allow you to reforge/add skill gems. So, a Witch summoner would have blue gems inserted into blue sockets. There are also support gems that will affect any gems in linked sockets, for example multiple projectiles linked to fireball so you shoot 2-3 instead of 1. These also level up while you level up (dont have to keep using it), so a common technique is to equip gems you also want to level up (but not necessarily use) into your 2nd equipment swap because they still gain exp. Just like the passive skill tree, any class can equip any gem, so long as you meet the requirements (level and intelligence/strength/dex depending on the type of gem).It is totally possible to beat the game playing casually and not worrying about both the passive tree and skill gems too much, but after that, the next two difficulties will probably be next to impossible (especially if you're running solo). Players can only join your instance if you are partied up, so you don't have to worry about people coming to your game and aggro-ing you suddenly.EVERYONE will make a mistake on their first character. The goal is to experiment and see how you like to play. My good friend that introduced me to this quit on his level 60+ character because he realized he screwed up. I really, really love planning out my skill trees and deciding which one to use.Storywise. . .I'll be honest - I only have a vague idea of what was going on, and I've beaten the game. Granted, PoE was originally a 2 chapter game with 4 difficulties - now it is a 3 chapter game with 3 difficulties. The story seems very tacked on, and the flavor comes in the form of these stones that you can find throughout the game and read. There have been suggestions to let the lore read aloud as you move around (ala Diablo 2 {unless I'm remembering incorrectly}), but instead you have to stand still and read it (or not). Not the best, engaging story IMO.Races. Omg races. I have stayed up til 2am just to see what the next sales on steam will be. I have also stayed up til 2am just to participate in a race. A race is a short game where you make a character and try to complete goals (most commonly attaining a certain level tier), before the time (ex: 1 hour) is up. You get points, and after receiving enough points, you unlock an item that can be retreived by any character in any league (once). I'm saving all of mine for the next Ambush league (ends and restarts in July).The gameplay - very, very fun. Reminds me so much of D2. The aesthetics are very good, armor is cool to see. Not at all P2W, all microtransactions are completely aesthetic, although you will probably want to buy more tabs for the chest.Definitely recommend!

												Now Path of Exile is a game that I have followed since it's early closed beta days and I've played since then too. This is one of the best Hack 'n Slash Action RPG games that you will find this year and what's more it is entirely free to play (yes a real free to play the only thing you pay real money for are cosmetics like extra gore, different skin on items so that you look a little unique, pets that do nothing but follow you or more warehouse slots etc). The gameplay it self is pretty much Diablo 2 style. One amazing thing about the game to note is the skill tree and the way you can develop it... the possibilities are endless! Basically the skill tree is just passive skills while the spells and similar that you use to fight are "gems" which you have to embed in your weapons/armors, what's more is that there are no class bound items so basically you can make a Ranger use staffs and use magic, a Marauder use bow and a Witch use a giant sword and that's not all, every single class has the same skill tree with the class being just the way you character looks and the starting possition in the skill tree. The skills in this game are amazing. To use a skill you have to find a gem with that skill, meet the level and stat requerments and put it inside a gem slow in your weapon/armor. Each weapon/armor can have up to 4/6 slots with 3 different color and skill gems also have 3 different color types (based on Strength, Dexterity and Intelligence) and those slots on the weapon can be linked together so you can merge 2 or 3 different skills effects (using support gems with normal skills gems) to add new type of effects to your skills and make them even stronger.The crafting and currency systems in the game are really unique and awesome the normal currency used in other games like gold for example is totally removed and everything revolves around trading items and the currency items are the same as upgrade items (adding new options to you armor/weapons, socketing, changing their type from normal, magic, rare ..etc)PoE is definitely my favorite Hack 'n Slash game together with the classic Diablo 2. It's a must try game for RPG fans and I would recomend it to all of you ;).

												For a F2P game, I am more than impressed.  This can easily compete with AAA titles in terms of gameplay, fun, graphics, sound, and story.  The main campaign itself took me 40+ hours which is quite impressive!  Though you can purchase items in-game, this is in no way a pay-to-win game as the items for purchase are all vanity items.  You obtain everything you need to actually play the game by guess what?  PLAYING.  THE.  GAME.  Take note, other supposed F2P releases: I will buy items for this game.  Not because they're required to finish it or make it significantly easier, but because the devs deserve my support for creating a fun, immersive, addictive game.  For free.  As to the gameplay itself, it's a pretty typical action adventure RPG a la Diablo with a complex and satisfying talent grid.  It looks overwhelming at first, but it's fairly easy to pick up after a little study.  It reminds me of the sphere grid from FFX, and is a system I personally like a lot.  It's possible to create just about any build with any class, which is fantastic.  My biggest complaint is that the classes have set genders; I would prefer to create a female marauder or duelist.  Multiple difficulty levels and distinct differences in the classes make this quite replayable.  Of course multiplayer is always fun and the challenges are a nice touch.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Path of Exile is clearly a labour of love. It's a wonderful game with some fresh ideas and good mechanics that breaths some more life into the traditional ARPG format.It is similar to Diablo 3, Torchlight 2 and Titan Quest in general gameplay. All your standard things such as levelling up, loot, random levels and monster slaying are here. Where it differs from the aforementioned games is the skill and level-up system, which is an interesting change. As you level up, you gain passive skill points to spend on things such as damage, armour, critical chance etc. You gain your active skills from a variety of different gems, which can be freely plopped into items you find - and taken out without a fuss. This allows you to quickly swap skills in and out - completely changing your play-style in a matter of seconds. These gems also level-up with you and become more powerful. You can create powerful combos by linking support gems with active skills to augment your favourites.This balance between "permanent" passive skills and changeable active skills is actually really good and works well together. You can still build a character to exactly what you want - and the passive skill "tree" is absolutely huge.Different classes start the game at different points in the skill tree, meaning they can gain access to abilities that suit them best earlier than other classes, but it also means, with a bit of work, you can turn pretty much any class in the game to do something different. It's unique and very well rounded.As a free-to-play game, it's a must try for anyone that likes the format. It's a great game, made even better by being free to play. At no point does it feel like you *have* to pay to get the most out of it, like some other FTP games I have tried in the past.Go on, give it a whirl, it's free!Jimbo Rating: 7.5/10

												This is among the most fun f2p games i've ever owned, and the only hack and slash that I truly enjoy. TL;DR: A very fun game with amazing developers and community that's full of content and gets updated regularlyPros:-Truly Free to Play model: I'm sick of all of the f2p games that ended up costing money to get somewhere, and I thought this would be another one of those, but surprisingly it wasn't, you don't need any money to do anything important in the game. All you can buy with money is cosmetic items. I love games that do this.-Abundant content: There is no lack of things to do in this game, you can play it for 1000's of hours and not get bored, and the multiplayer aspect just adds to it (more on that later)-Multiplayer: This game has an amazing multiplayer scene, and it grows more and more every day, I have little doubt this will be one of the biggest ARPG's every if it isn't already, and the PVP and Party systems work really well, and I love how the noticeboards (places to recruit party members) are implemented.-Community: This is one of the few games on steam that doesn't have an incredibly toxic community, the people i've met have all been very helpful and hackers might as well not exist because they are so hard to find, I have yet to find one.-Developers: The developers of this game are the thing that surprised me the most, they constantly update the game with free content and are very good at upkeeping the game, good devs are almost impossible to find nowadays.-Atmosphere: The atmosphere of this game is very dark and gritty and it fits the story very well, not to mention the 5 hour soundtrack that is very well done, I like to spend many hours of this game just walking around-Leagues: Every season the game gets updated with a new league to keep it new and exciting, not much to explain here but it's one of the main reason why you can spend so much time in this game.-Runs well on minimal specs: self explanatory-Trading system: The trading system of this game is very fast and efficient, and the trading economy is very much alive.-Skill tree: The skill tree in this game is very large and there are no lack of new things to learn for your character, the skill tree is massive and you can go down any route you want based on what your character is.Cons:-Eats up your free time-Guilt from the fact the game is free-Giant learning curve-Skill tree can be scary for new players-Lack of mod support (that I know of) Final score:	 9/10, The only thing stopping it from being a solid 10 is the learning curveAll in all i'd say that this is a very good game and one of the best games on steam. Every minute of playing it was extremely fun and I would recommend it to anyone. It's free so why wouldn't you try it!

Posted: January 15, 2014
												Path of Legends is another great indie game to add to EA's records of acheivement. You start of with a selection from various characters, these include lulu the dark witch, taric the holy one, and lastly master yi the forgoten avanger. I myself played as yi and the story is great although it does have a few plot holes here and there. In any case you find yourself on a beach after the summer cruise ship you were on got assaulted by the deadswamp pirates. Yi was engaged to be married and had all of his family onboard the cruise at the time. unfortunately the pirates were ruthless and slayed every man woman and child. Yi tried to resist but was overpowerd by a surge of lightening on the stormy night that accompanied the deadswamp pirate assault. Amongst the wreckage of the ship he eventually floated to the island in which you start the game. Theres nothing much to it at first, you are lying face planted in the dirt. You learn to survive as you craft with various tools. Immersion breaks here because you cut down trees with your bare hands, but i suppose this could be attributed to Yi being a badass and so it can be justified.Eventually you can build yourself a nice hut, and after you do some rather grindy farming you can establish a good forward outpost. You get promted mid game to purchase station cash from the soney online entertainment website to speed things up, but i never was a fan of DLC so i dont support EA's decision to monetise indie games like this. After you build the foward outpost you get to fight the first boss, a giant enemy crab which is symbolic of Yi's personal struggles from his japanese heritage. the crab is symbolic of real historical battles in ancient china and for the little historian in all of us i found this quite compelling as a plot twist. beating the crab allows you to advance to the next section, where you meet rico from just cause 2.    Rico gives you the grappleing hook as he too was on the cruise ship but took a bullet to the hip and just cant do what he did in the previous game. Fortunately for us, Yi gets to swing around the area pretty quickly. the hook allows you to make it to the central island, where the plot thickens once Yi discovers theres an american military base centred in the area that has been testing equipment. Yi appraoches the base in a freindly manner, but is instantly gunned down and escapes within an inch of his life. The game turns toward gurrilla warfare fromt his point on. You need to take out key military instillations over the island (such as propaganda stations and fuel depots) to try and win over the local populus. Once youve garnered enough strength you can take the military hq head on to liberate panaoa from the terrorist organisation that has rooted itself in the heart of the island.THe final stages of the game involve strolling the halls of the HQ, which span deep underground. Yi uncovers the secrets this place holds. the organisation were responsible for the pirate attack on the ship, hired mercinaries trying to obtain a rare artifact being transported on the cruise that nobody knew about. This clearly explaines why rico was onboard and this was certainly no ordinary cruise. The artifact was being used to reanimate flesh to create necromongers to satisfy some weird cult called zoology established by Tom ultman. From this point on Yi knew what he had to do and where he needed to go... space... THe game ends with Yi having a choise to destroy the evil facility, or instead render it inert for future research by the alliance which hope to harness this power against the bretheren moons. Once you make your choice you can hitch  a ride on the ebon normandy, a test vehicle in the hanger which is fully developed and primed for space flight. YOu can take with you some local aquaintances you met on the island, or just go solo. In any case, you leave the island and make your way to eden prime, and this is the basis for the second installment of league of exiles which we here at indieholic ardently await to get our greasy little hands on.until next time, stay snazzy gamerz!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E12 Path of Exile 

			Views: 1,378		

			Grinding Gear Games have done a fantastic service to lovers of action RPGs. Path of Exile is a great piece of the genre and everything a great ARPG should aspire to be.		

Path of Exile: An action RPG similar to style and feel of great titles like Diablo 2. Path of Exile is a true marvel in its approach and achievement. Everything in the game is solid and simple but with a lot of its own ideas to make it different from most other ARPGs. From the colossal sized skill tree and open ended character building to skill gems and support gems and to the land of Wraeclast itself, it’s a unique enough experience that I haven’t encountered anything quite like Path of Exile before. Its non-standard approach is a nice breather from typical tropes of ARPGs and the fact that it works so well is a great achievement.  The game not only looks great but its sound design and overall ambiance is dark and dreary and very fitting of the setting. The story and lore of Wraeclast is quite disturbing and is quite interesting to unravel although, like most ARPGs its story is more akin to a movie rather than a true role-playing experience, where you make hard decisions and live out consequences of those choices. The game also suffers a bit with regards to its own character system, in that each character can potentially be the same, it loses its replay-ability a bit when compared to other ARPGs where characters are a class unto themselves with their own unique skills and spells and the skill tree in general will take a lot of careful planning and getting used to. Overall the experience of Path of Exile is solid and fun with the most frustration coming from the fact that it is an online game and with that comes some technical issues such as lag and issues from other players themselves. Personally, I would have gladly had paid whatever the asking price for this game, for it to be single player and online as optional. As a free-to-play title it does come with its own store which thankfully I can report does not have any content within it that feels like it has to be purchased in order to enjoy the game. Items in the are generally either cosmetic items, purely for looks or things like stash or character expansions, but they give you so many to start out with that these won’t feel like immediate needs or purchases ever. Path of Exile is a great ARPG, everyone can enjoy this game and it is simple and easy to get into and play and it at least offers 20+ of content for a first time through the entire game and it’s all completely free without any extra game content being behind a paywall. -Double Thumbs up from RoyialVideo Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

Posted: November 24, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E12 Path of Exile 

			Views: 1,378		

			Grinding Gear Games have done a fantastic service to lovers of action RPGs. Path of Exile is a great piece of the genre and everything a great ARPG should aspire to be.		

Path of Exile: An action RPG similar to style and feel of great titles like Diablo 2. Path of Exile is a true marvel in its approach and achievement. Everything in the game is solid and simple but with a lot of its own ideas to make it different from most other ARPGs. From the colossal sized skill tree and open ended character building to skill gems and support gems and to the land of Wraeclast itself, it’s a unique enough experience that I haven’t encountered anything quite like Path of Exile before. Its non-standard approach is a nice breather from typical tropes of ARPGs and the fact that it works so well is a great achievement.  The game not only looks great but its sound design and overall ambiance is dark and dreary and very fitting of the setting. The story and lore of Wraeclast is quite disturbing and is quite interesting to unravel although, like most ARPGs its story is more akin to a movie rather than a true role-playing experience, where you make hard decisions and live out consequences of those choices. The game also suffers a bit with regards to its own character system, in that each character can potentially be the same, it loses its replay-ability a bit when compared to other ARPGs where characters are a class unto themselves with their own unique skills and spells and the skill tree in general will take a lot of careful planning and getting used to. Overall the experience of Path of Exile is solid and fun with the most frustration coming from the fact that it is an online game and with that comes some technical issues such as lag and issues from other players themselves. Personally, I would have gladly had paid whatever the asking price for this game, for it to be single player and online as optional. As a free-to-play title it does come with its own store which thankfully I can report does not have any content within it that feels like it has to be purchased in order to enjoy the game. Items in the are generally either cosmetic items, purely for looks or things like stash or character expansions, but they give you so many to start out with that these won’t feel like immediate needs or purchases ever. Path of Exile is a great ARPG, everyone can enjoy this game and it is simple and easy to get into and play and it at least offers 20+ of content for a first time through the entire game and it’s all completely free without any extra game content being behind a paywall. -Double Thumbs up from RoyialVideo Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

Posted: April 24, 2015
												At the time of the review I have about 700 hours logged on steam version. Path of Exile is  a hardcore action RPG with a lot of depth. It will most likely take a while to get in to and it is not suited for quite a lot of gamers. However, this game is absolutely fantastic. Pros and cons can be subjective, so I'll just point out main points.-Hardcore. Can be a heaven for hardcore gamers and a nightmare for casuals. Not recommended for your first ARPG.-Free-to-play but not pay-to-win. GGG's microtransaction system is very fair. Almost everything is cosmetics and nothing in microtransaction store gives anyone an advantage.-Realistic gritty graphics. I personally love the graphic and art style, but it is highly subjective.-Music varies from "meh" to absolute blasts. From boring lullabies to beautiful symphonies. -Sound design is pretty solid. Good voice acting and realistic sounds.-Support is great and quick. I personally had great time using it.-Game has classes, however, the class only changes how your character looks and from where he/she starts from the skill tree.-Characters can use any skills or items if they have required stats. Skills are skill gems that can be socketed in to items.-Ridiculously flexible and huge skill tree. You can make thousands or possibly even millions of builds with the tree provided. Skill tree consists of little upgrades (For example, 0.3% life regeneration or 12% more physical damage.)Some people don't like this, but those small upgrades stack fast, I personally love the freedom of the skill tree.-Game is based on leagues, so there will be different leagues where you can create a new character and try new things.-Lot of equipment variance, you can find, buy or craft items perfect for your build or even multiple ones.-Trading is decent but should be worked on. You either need to yell to chat or use 3rd party websites to make trades. Game has no auction houses or player shops in-game.-Leveling can be quick or slow, depending on build and skill. Max level is 100 and you can reach level 70 in 10-15 hours.-The game has 3 difficulties, Normal, Cruel and Merciless. You will move to the next difficulty after completing storyline. Story currently is composed of 3 acts (4th one is coming soon) and you complete those acts in each difficulty. This can be very boring, since it can feel like the game is repeating.-The endgame is a map system. You can craft mods in to your maps to make them fit your build or your needs. I personally love this system, since it offers a lot of variance, varying difficulties and different experiences.-The D-sync (Should be fixed in the Awakening expansion). Basically, you will be off sync from the game and you might in a different position than your character seems to be on your screen. This can and probably will cause a lot of deaths and frustration, but should be getting fixed soon. (Only thing that has really caused me frustration in the game. Glad to see it going)I might have forgotten some main points...Overall, I think Path of Exile is a fantastic game by a fantastic company and I recommend it whole heartedly.Edit: Now at over 3k total and the Atlas of Worlds expansion is fantastic.

												Current state : if you can get pass the performance issues it's a great game, i still wouldn't recommend it until they fixed that side2016 update:i wanted to write a full breakdown of changes between the last 2 years but i don't have enough space so i'll go fast on each point :1) desync fixed2) performance still sucks3) the last expansion was released too early full of bugs4) challenges can be completed with less farming and got improved5)trading got improved a bit , but idd still love a Self Found League6) balance : powercreep is of the charts expecting changes in next league7) no one cares about PvP so they aren't gonna focus on it anymore, not surprised here------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------original review:First thing i should mention is that this review doesn't takle what Path of Exile does best, but what a released game should be and shouldn't.   -> 1) Desync there is no need argue about it's presence in-game, we know it's in the game on a daily presence and that it will affect your gameplay.     ->* skills that will make you desync : flicker strike , cyclone; since you move when you use these skills usage of "shift"(to stop you from moving on server/client side) will not help       ->* gameplay that will make you desync : even though it's present overall in the game the most desync part of the game is Dominus fight especially his first part, if you try to kite and move behind cover you will desync at least once per fight , it won't kill you in 90% of the cases but nevertheless is still annoying as hell . Desync is responsable for many hardcore deaths every day     ->* server side problems combined with desync, last time this happened 4/6 players died from a hardcore party, one of them was level 90 ->2) Performance :    ->*depending on your playstyle:      ->**if you play alone : in town, eternal laboratory or any other empty place i manage to get 170+ fps when you start playing the game it will go to 60-70, if you are doing a end game map with some special mods it will drop to 30-50       ->** if you play in a party: the performance will be lower because there is more stuff going on but some times it will go to "1" when certain skills are used   ->* Death animation will make you drops fps if you kill large packs of monsters   ->* range attacks and spells : discharge, lightning arrow, fireball, freezing pulse, ice spear, poison arrow... will lower your framerate but only in end-game or when used in a combination with cast on crit   ->* the game will just not work properly if you have a " creative sound card"    ->* cpu bound : changing your graphics options will  not make a big difference in fps gain or loss during fights, even if you have 1 fps the game will not use more than 30-40% of your graphics card (depending on how powerfull it is)  ->3) Bugs: yes we know that every game has bugs but     ->* in a end game focus on map drops you should work on fixing them first :      ->** monsters stuck behind walls and cannot be reached : this happens a lot on Shipyard map (level 77 top tier map, 1 level below max map level) and if you didn't kill last 5-10 monsters you might just not get a map drop, when you didn't get any map last few monster have a good chance of droping 1 or even more maps      ->** you are kicked from the server and cannot join the map again, these happened twice in a almost half year period     ->* every patch is plagued with game breaking bugs, last time they had to roll back because more than 1000 chars died on hardcore. Even the devs will tell you not to play soon after a patch is released especially on Hardcore  ->4)Challenge system and how it affect the gameplay and drops :   ->* since they added the "challenge system" we saw a change on where the unique item required to complete a specific challenge drops : you have Kaom's heart and shavronne's dropping only from level 76+ maps, before you could get them by just farming level 66-67 content for a few months, the price was also lower.    ->* the only reason they added map only unique item drop is because they had 61 people completing challenges before so they wanted to lower that number    ->* only challenge in getting 8 out of 8 challenges completed is getting all the unique items, to get them all you will need at least 250 exalted orbs, let's say you are playing like 7 hours a day 7/7 days a week even you make 10 exalted orbs a week it will take you at least 25 weeks (keep in mind that the first few weeks you will invest most of your currency in upgrading your gear and progressing rather than storing it)   ->*this is not something skill based, if you speak about skill it's not even rewarded in or outside the game. Chris will go and interview "popular" streamers instead of "skilled" even though they are pretty popular in the Path of Exile scene, not even when we had the first player reaching level 100 (max in Path of exile)   ->* there is a frequent joke made on forums that the only hard part of this game is the Magic Find slider, how much can you get without big drawbacks  ->5) Trading :  ->* you hated action house in other games? well you will hate this trading system even more, there is no proper way to search on forums, both forums and trade channel is filled with spam , people just stay in town and buy/sell both currency or items, this is the same problem Diablo 3 had where people played "the action house" instead of the game because it was the best way to get best gear in-game ->6)Balance :   ->* the new monsters hit harder compared to older monsters even though they use the same skill: a monster made before does 5% the monster does 20-40%   ->* moba style of balance changes to skills    ->* even though it was promised in different interviews that there will not be nerfs when someone found a cool builds, that does seem the case, and it went as far removing a skill from in-game (Phase Run) even though it's still on the webpage and a  flask , which was later added back with a nerfed version   ->* at the release 9 unique items were nerfed    ->* every new unique item or skill gem has a drawback, you can say that unique items have at least 2 drawbacks now   ->7) Promises for the release:  ->* we where promised that they will take feedback from players on their forums , but the respond more on Reddit rather than on the main forum, and even with all the feedback they still will do whatever they want, making you just waste your time, it's not just me saying this there are a lot of people that playes  this game since Closed Beta and have the same opinion ->*Private leagues : still waiting on news , it seems they completly forgot about it ->* PvP : might be delivered in next patch , was promised in the release patch like it was for Diablo 3 ->* Trading system revamp : again pushed back to god knows when ->* Act IV : pushed back to march 2014 ->* weekly updates : now updates will be made every 2 weeks ->* optimization : still waiting on it ->* Clans/guilds : you have a guild tag and a chest that lags every time you put or take something out of it, there is 												Basically this excellent game is a free to play Diablo 2 with a character improvement system that is QUITE REMINISCENT to the Sphere Grid  from Final Fantasy  X. Except that the grid itself is... ridiculously big. And if you are just playing casually, you can use it to develop your character in ways you want.But if you are fairly serious, you will need to find out  ways to actually build effective and efficient characters, having entire trees planned beforehand.And then you will need to get quite lucky or trade successfully, because skills are not bound to a character. That is both the game's greatest strength and greatest weakness, in my opinion. The skill system is  INCREDIBLY flexible, being more similar to FF7's materia system than anything else. Skills come in the form of "virtue gems", which you get to slot into items with the appropriate colored slots.Said gems mostly come in rare, random drops. You either need to trade for them (easier now since there are vendors that do sell some useful gems now), win  many of them on quests, or trade with the community.Extremely flexible, and if diablo 2 gameplay mixed with FF7 skill systems and FFX sphere grid character growth sounds interesting, you will probably devote many many hours in this title.The ingame shop is only for cosmetic items, storage space and character slots, as far as I know, so there is no such thing as a pay to win scheme in this game.EXTREMELY recommended.

Posted: May 20, 2015
												Stunning visuals, addictive mechanics, and neat functions. Path of Exile, at first, is a solid experience, especially since the game doesn't cost a dime, and sports ethical microtransactions. No pay to win here, which is a big plus in my book. Path of Exile was meant to be the Diablo 2 successor that I've always dreamed of... but is it?The first playthrough, as previously stated, was solid. The character progression tree is intimidating at first, but can be mastered over time. Skill gems offer a neat twist to the tried and true "Diablo" formula. There's plenty of strategy to implement here. I thoroughly enjoyed the standard difficulty.But where did it all go wrong?The second you beat the first playthrough, it all goes downhill. "Cruel" difficulty is terribly unbalanced. You will breeze through regular enemies, but once a rare or unique enemy appears, you are promptly one-shot-killed. Heck, even a select few normal enemies can one or two shot kill you. Regardless of how you die, you will lose 5% of your experience on this difficulty. This function is archaic, and fundamentally flawed, completely and totally. Diablo 2 did this, except the game is 15 years old, and 15 years is enough time for game developers to realize "yes, players hate this, and it kills progression, and thus, the entire gameplay experience". Grinding Gear Games didn't get the memo, it seems. Regardless, once this penalty kicks in, the game becomes a sluggish, boring grindfest where you struggle to level up in the face of unbalanced enemies and "cruel" penalties. My desire to play was crushed once I was met with this awful formula. As an insult to injury, your elemental resistances are reduced by 20%, which makes one-shot deaths even easier.Due to this massive difficulty boost, you REQUIRE a build to survive. There is no free reign to design your character anymore; you must now look to the net to guide you. Unlike the first playthrough, progression is limited to this, and the experience is totally drained out and dried up because of it. Progression is a massive part of what makes this game and others like it fun, and with this unnecessary and poorly implemented slippery slope added, it becomes entirely tedious and stale.... a grindfest (and it isn't even a traditional MMO). It essentially becomes a game like Dark Souls - a game for masochists. A game where you have to throw an unnecessary amount of time, effort, and research into it to enjoy the bare basics of the game. To even scrape by.These are the reasons why I do not recommend this game. The beginning showed LOTS of promise, but once your first playthrough is up, there's no point in continuing. There's no compelling story, no memorable characters, and the first playthrough,the Dark Souls-like gameplay is mediocre at best, and rage-inducing at worst.Thankfully, I didn't spend a dime on this gameplay-flawed package. I hope you don't spend any on it as well.

												Unlike some "free to play" games here on Steam this one is actually 100% free. The game is huge and using real money on microtransactions offers no gameplay advantages. No pay-2-not-grind ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here. This alone makes Path of Exile worth checking out.Rise, why are you giving this game a negative review then? Excellent question. To start with, the game took five minutes to start up every time. My friend's game took around 2-3 minutes and his PC is top notch. So you're looking at very high startup times unless you're running an SSD. Also, changing graphic settings might freeze or crash the game. This happened when trying to use windowed fullscreen or turning anti-aliasing on. I ended up having to play just plaing old windowed mode. High startup times are a problem for this type of game.The game itself is like Diablo 2 on shrooms. The combat felt slow and unresponsive, and the animations were clunky. Not something you'd expect from an Action RPG. The enemies are your classic goatmen, skellingtons, zombies and swarmy bugs. Sometimes the enemies are rare or unique. Even The Butcher made an appearance (only he was called Brutus but I know he was The Butcher), The setting is grimdark, as it should be.By the way, the graphics are amazing. Makes you wanna kill Blizzard for selling that PoS D3+expansion for 80 euros still.Now about that passive skill tree. One look at that tree and you know if you're staying or not. There is no way to know what passives are useful, no way to fully respec and I seriously doubt anyone truly knows whats going on with that skill tree. Like, come on people. There is no need to have something like that. Give me a few straight lines and I work it out from there.Overall not a very rousing experience. Check it out though since its free.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I already reviewed this game a year or two ago, saying how good it was. I started playing it again not too long ago, and decided to come back and give it a new review, in order to help keep reviews fresh and relevant.So now at the end of 2016, almost 2017, how is it holding up to the test of time?In my opinion this game is still the golden standard of how a free to play game should be run. While the game has microtransactions, the only things you can buy are cosmetic things to change how you look. There is absolutely nothing you can buy that would give you an unfair advantage over others, and there is absolutely nothing you need to buy in order to play the full game. You can play the whole game beginning to end, with every character, as many times as you like for free. There is no catch whatsoever.In terms of graphics. While graphics have come a long way in the last few years, and there are some amazing looking games out there, I still find the graphics in Path Of Exile to be more than satisfactory. The visuals are more than enough to make you feel alone and scared, as well as excited, safe, or in trouble. Leading to an immersive experience.The game has also seen significant imrpovements from what I can tell. I could be mistaken, or may have just forgotten, but there seems to be way more cool items and new loot in the game compared to before. There are also new town characters with side quests, that if you complete, allows you to buy cooler and cooler things the more you level up your relationship with them.Back in the day, the game had issues with connexion from time to time, but that too seems to have been improved, with the game playing much smoother. I have not noticed any lag so far. It could be down to there being less people playing, but I don't think that is the case because it still seems like loads of people are playing on a regular basis.The game is really good, a solid 10 out of 10 for me. If this game had launched on the first day for 60 bucks it would have been worth it, and even today I still think it is worth a good 50 to 60 bucks. Considering it is totally free, you really can't complain.All in all I would say the game is just as good as it used to be if not better.So, what can you actually do in the game?You play as an exile that has been just abandoned and left to die on a monster infested island. You then fight your way through the levels, until becoming a god-like all powerful warrior.The game has loads of powerful items to help make yourself even more powerful, as well as a skill tree that seems to offer almost infinite options on how you want to build your character.While the main missions are a little short, you can play them on many difficulties. Also the game has a very good set of end game missions, that make up for how short the main missions are.I would compare it to Diablo 2, or Titan Quest, it is one of those kinds of games, but more modern and comprehensive versions, with a few unique twists.well worth a look if you like magic, action, RPG, MMO, epic adventures, or any combination.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Path of Exile is worthy of any action-RPG's fan's attention - especially since the game is free.  If one wishes to support the game developers, money can be spent for cosmetic changes and to increase your stash size, but neither are required to play the game.While the passive skill tree is enormous, it does require a bit of thought and planning to be utilized effectively.  Active skills are socketed to items, allowing unique combinations and a large amount of variety to gameplay (although, some options are far more effective than others).  Skills are leveled through experience that your character gains as they are socketed in an equipped item.Disadvantages...two in my experience: descynchronization from the required servers, even with ample internet capability; the targeting system is frustrating for melee type characters.  Both are irritating and exacerbate each other, often leading to character deaths.  As with Diablo 3 (the only other ARPG game that I have played with a server connection requirement), this has kept me from playing hardcore characters.  It's a shame, because I enjoy the challenge.Overall, I will wholeheartedly recommend the game, despite the above-mentioned flaws.  The developer seems committed and responsive to the fans / supporters, which is a nice bonus and will hopefully ensure future changes which allow for better, more reliable gameplay.  Additionally, the amount of variety and different gameplay options (races, ladder servers, etc.) should keep long term players' attention.

												My game of choice when it comes to the top-down action RPG genre!It acts like a true spiritual successor to Diablo 2, when I started playing I was so pleased at how the game handled and looked. It's gritty and grimey and it feels like a slog through the legions of hell.Where the game really shines is the character creation and theorycraft aspects. You can spend a good hour or so deciding what kind of build you want and what sort of weapons and attacks you're going to use before even clicking that create a new character button. Thinking about how your passive stats and combination of attacks are all going to synergise with each other is all part of the fun. And yet if you don't want to do that it's fairly obvious where to go and what to get to make a successful build anyway (after a bit of practice)Highly recommended if you're a fan of the Diablo games, and even with the whole PoE vs D3 e-war I'd still try both and see what suits you, they are inherently different games. content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												It's been touted by some as what you actually wanted from Diablo 3. After playing it, I'm kind of inclined to agree. Active skills are attached to gems which you can socket/unsocket from gear at will, which can force decisions between skills and better stats when your new piece of gear doesn't have the right slots. There are passive skills awarded upon each level up that look a lot like the FFX sphere grid. It's possible to build almost any way you want using this, but each class has passive skills which you're meant to specialize in (i.e. are easier to access). Microtransactions exist, of course, but have no real impact on the game, unless you count extended stash space. Also, has perhaps the most unique health potion system I've seen which I'd like to see done elsewhere. Your potions have X charges and use a set amount of charges per use of the potion. These charges replenish as you kill enemies. Furthermore, these potions are stored in their own separate inventory.Basically, if you're interested in this style of game and have the hard drive space, there's not much reason to not AT LEAST try it out. Afterall, if you don't like it, you're out nothing but your own time. Only complaint at the moment is that like Diablo 3, it is online only, which means the servers aren't local and it's possible to run into bits of lag here and there, even with fairly good internet speeds.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												What do you get when you cross-breed Final Fantasy VII's materia system with Diablo 2? You get Path of Exile, a game which demands a great deal of theorycrafting and immense build diversity the likes of which you will never see in many ARPGs.Pros:+ Free to play+ No pay-to-win, all microtransactions are aesthetic.+ Vast build diversity+ All skills are available to use by any class+ Helpful, active community+ New take on currency and how it affects trading+ Massive, comprehensive skill tree.+ (Personal interest) Competant summoning and minion featuresCons:- Always online- Trade chat is poorly implemented- Game has terrible problems with desync- Standard league economy is horribly inflated- Not for casual gaming, requires a great deal of time and effort to get to the real fun parts of the gamePros explained:The first thing that attracted me to this game the most was the summoning system. Diablo 2 had spoiled me rotten with the necromancer, nothing was more fun for me than running around with a large army of skeletons at my back, ready to charge forward to engage the enemy. Not many ARPGs can pull off a good summoning mechanic, but when they do, its always amazing. Path of Exile not only lets you raise hordes of zombies that fight until they die, but also allows you to summon skeletons that offer support and come in larger numbers. The best part of summoning, however, comes in the form of raising spectres. Imagine fighting a monster that is very proficient at wiping out your minions, and then turning that monster into your own minion to fight for you! And there's more, from summoning flaming skulls that bypass enemies and small obstacles to animating weapons to animating a full-blown suit of armor!The next big feature I loved about this game is how they handle currency. Most games just give you basic currency like gold which you use to buy or sell things. Not in this game! Currency comes in the form of special orbs which also provide useful functions. One orb can be used to give you respecs to your passive tree for example, another can be used to turn a mundane (white) item into a rare quality item. There's lots of orbs and each orb is valued differently between each other based on rarity on usefulness. If you can find the 'mirror of kalandra', you've officially become a rich player, but good luck finding it!There are no direct skills to speak of when leveling up, but they are passive improvements. When it comes to Path of Exile, it doesn't give you a skill tree, it gives you a passive skill jungle! Those who have played Final Fantasy X will know what I'm talking about. The passive skill tree is what allows for such an amazing build diversity. Its very complicating for new players, but thankfully the forum has many build guides you can use to teach you how to build yourself. I highly recommend you try and make your own build first to understand the passive skill tree before reading a build guide.Ah, but the greatest feature of all about this game lies in the actual skills themselves. This game offers a myriad of abilities that are accessible to every player, so long as they can meet the stat requirements for them. Want to throw a fireball? Sure. How about raining fire on the enemy? Why not! Want to throw a spectral copy of your weapon at an enemy and watch it fly back to you? You can get it. The fun doesn't stop there, no. You can also augment your abilities with support gems to make them more powerful! Want to shoot more fireballs at once, or to make them split on impact? There's support gems for that! Want your arrows to bounce between multiple enemies or pierce right through them? That's possible. Want your melee attacks to attack multiple times in one cast, or to make your melee do AoE damage? You can do that. There's infinite possibilities when using skills, you just need to know what works best!Cons explained:However, this game does have some downsides you will have to deal with. The first and perhaps biggest issue this game suffers from is desync. For those who don't know what desync is, the simplest way to describe it is that the client isn't in sync with the server. For instance, you're trying to escape from some enemies in a hall and while you think you have escaped, you're still taking damage and when you die, you wind up back where the enemies were. Rubberbanding is the best way to describe desync and you will be experiencing this a lot. If you play on the hardcore leagues, its IMPORTANT that you play carefully and utilize the '/oos' command in chat to resync.This game is also not friendly to the more casual of gamers. Between build diversity, a complicated skill tree and a heavily inflated economy in the parent standard and hardcore leagues, this game demands a great deal of time and effort be invest before the game gets any fun. If you're not prepared to really sink your teeth into this game and hang on for dear life, you might want to consider playing something else.But hey, this game is free. Free, and without pay-to-win microtransactions. There are microtransactions in this game, but they are all cosmetic and designed purely to make your character stand out from the rest. There are also pets you can buy as a microtransaction, but they are also purely for visual appeal and will not give you an advantage to combat. You will never have to worry about other players buying their way to greatness, everyone is on even ground here!I really suggest you give this game a try, especially if you were a fan of Diablo 2!Helpful resources:http://www.poe.xyz.isThis site is great if you're looking to find an item in the game that you need. The site pulls information from the trade forum on the official site and if it finds a match, it will list all the items that meet your criteria. Clicking the item's name will take you straight to the player's trade thread on the forum!http://www.pathofexile.gamepedia.comThis is the wiki for Path of Exile. Everything you will ever need to know about the game can be found here. This site is very active and updates immediately when new content is released. If you ever need to know what certain skills do or what uniques do, this is the place to go.

												What do you get when you cross-breed Final Fantasy VII's materia system with Diablo 2? You get Path of Exile, a game which demands a great deal of theorycrafting and immense build diversity the likes of which you will never see in many ARPGs.Pros:+ Free to play+ No pay-to-win, all microtransactions are aesthetic.+ Vast build diversity+ All skills are available to use by any class+ Helpful, active community+ New take on currency and how it affects trading+ Massive, comprehensive skill tree.+ (Personal interest) Competant summoning and minion featuresCons:- Always online- Trade chat is poorly implemented- Game has terrible problems with desync- Standard league economy is horribly inflated- Not for casual gaming, requires a great deal of time and effort to get to the real fun parts of the gamePros explained:The first thing that attracted me to this game the most was the summoning system. Diablo 2 had spoiled me rotten with the necromancer, nothing was more fun for me than running around with a large army of skeletons at my back, ready to charge forward to engage the enemy. Not many ARPGs can pull off a good summoning mechanic, but when they do, its always amazing. Path of Exile not only lets you raise hordes of zombies that fight until they die, but also allows you to summon skeletons that offer support and come in larger numbers. The best part of summoning, however, comes in the form of raising spectres. Imagine fighting a monster that is very proficient at wiping out your minions, and then turning that monster into your own minion to fight for you! And there's more, from summoning flaming skulls that bypass enemies and small obstacles to animating weapons to animating a full-blown suit of armor!The next big feature I loved about this game is how they handle currency. Most games just give you basic currency like gold which you use to buy or sell things. Not in this game! Currency comes in the form of special orbs which also provide useful functions. One orb can be used to give you respecs to your passive tree for example, another can be used to turn a mundane (white) item into a rare quality item. There's lots of orbs and each orb is valued differently between each other based on rarity on usefulness. If you can find the 'mirror of kalandra', you've officially become a rich player, but good luck finding it!There are no direct skills to speak of when leveling up, but they are passive improvements. When it comes to Path of Exile, it doesn't give you a skill tree, it gives you a passive skill jungle! Those who have played Final Fantasy X will know what I'm talking about. The passive skill tree is what allows for such an amazing build diversity. Its very complicating for new players, but thankfully the forum has many build guides you can use to teach you how to build yourself. Posted: February 22, 2014
												Path of Exile is undoubtedly one of the best free-to-play titles in recent years. If you're a fan of eerie & spine chilling, fantasy hack 'n' slash games where fighting huge mobs of ghastly creatures and ominous soldiers are the norm, Path of Exile is for you. As many have said already, this game has a very similar feel to the Diablo series and takes a large amount of influence from it (i.e. how the game is set into Acts and once you have completed them you can move onto harder difficulties), but also adds something of it's own into the mix such as having no currency in the game. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been and totally takes the cake between the two. The amount of content in the game is astounding and sometimes I can't believe that this game is free-to-play. Of course, you have your proverbial microtransactions but unlike other games, Path of Exile offers mostly non-competitive items for sale such as more character slots and guild options. Player vs. Player is another great element to the game and from what I have seen it contains 1 vs 1, 3 vs 3 and 6 vs 6 arenas though the matchmaking is a bit buggy when joining a queue. So, if you are looking for an overly addicting, loot driven, online hack 'n' slash game with tons of gore and brutality, download this game now! You won't regret it!

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Path of Exile is worthy of any action-RPG's fan's attention - especially since the game is free.  If one wishes to support the game developers, money can be spent for cosmetic changes and to increase your stash size, but neither are required to play the game.While the passive skill tree is enormous, it does require a bit of thought and planning to be utilized effectively.  Active skills are socketed to items, allowing unique combinations and a large amount of variety to gameplay (although, some options are far more effective than others).  Skills are leveled through experience that your character gains as they are socketed in an equipped item.Disadvantages...two in my experience: descynchronization from the required servers, even with ample internet capability; the targeting system is frustrating for melee type characters.  Both are irritating and exacerbate each other, often leading to character deaths.  As with Diablo 3 (the only other ARPG game that I have played with a server connection requirement), this has kept me from playing hardcore characters.  It's a shame, because I enjoy the challenge.Overall, I will wholeheartedly recommend the game, despite the above-mentioned flaws.  The developer seems committed and responsive to the fans / supporters, which is a nice bonus and will hopefully ensure future changes which allow for better, more reliable gameplay.  Additionally, the amount of variety and different gameplay options (races, ladder servers, etc.) should keep long term players' attention.

Examples:    Who can run the fastest through the game only using melee?  Oh you're a witch?  Well, better get swinging!    Unique dungeon crawls where you can't go home and fix your boo-boos or buy better equipment.  Use what you find, son!And don't worry, the playing field is leveled for this:  to do a race you must start with a brand new character.  Only your wits will help you prevail!  ...And lucky loot drops.I recommend this game, and for those nostalgic for D2; the first goat-bleat will warm your soul.  Happy left-button smashing!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Path of Exile is the most faithful successor to Diablo 2 that you'll find, including Diablo 3. While D3 took the approach of World of Warcraft's evolution, focusing on becoming more streamlined and more accessible than its predecessor, Path of Exile leans in the opposite direction. It's difficult, it's technical, and it's awesome. Truly, if feels as if everything that Diablo 3 did wrong, Path of Exile does right.The one area that PoE really diverges from the classic Diablo formula is in the active skill system. Active skills are granted by gem items. Skill gems gain experience and level up independantly of your character, and by combining active skill gems with "support gems" in equipment with appropriately-linked sockets, the combinations are vast.And that's what's really great about this game. The enormous scope of build variety and character customization. PoE's passive skill tree has hundreds and hundreds of nodes, and over the course of your character's career you'll have over 100 passive skill points to allocate in any direction and combination you see fit. Want to build a huge, muscle-bound Marauder that casts spells and holds wands? Want to create a Witch or Ranger that uses a Cyclone melee attack with a two-handed axe? Go for it. If you enjoy theorycrafting, you're bound to love this game.It's the most technical hack-and-slash ARPG out there, and likely the most unforgiving. The path to 100 is a long, long road, and once you're on the second and third difficulties you'll start losing experience with each death. It might get frustrating, but this is not a bad thing. The challenge and longevity this game presents is a breath of fresh air.And, somehow, the game is entirely free. There is -zero- "pay to win" here. You can buy extra stash tabs (though it's not at all necessary, they start you with four for free), but all the rest of the offered microtransactions are for purely cosmetic items. There is no way to get any sort of in-game boost or mechanical advantage by spending money.As a huge fan of the genre, PoE really feels like the most compelling offering as of right now.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2013
												Path of Exile is a complex and engaging free to play action RPG set in the grim world of Wraeclast. The atmosphere is very dark and interesting. Players slowly uncover the secrets behind their exile and Wraeclast. The lore is scattered throughout the game world and really adds to the immersion.The passive tree is absolutely massive and extremely diverse, allowing for almost any playstyle imaginable. Skills can be augmented with "Support Gems" to significantly modify what they do and to create some truly outrageous combinations. The amazing unique items in the game only add to the already overwhelming amount of character customization. The result is a theorycrafter's wet dream. Another major feature is that there is no "gold" as a form of currency. Instead there are numerous items of varying rarity that modify almost every aspect of items you find. These currency items allow players to custom tailor their gear while simultaneously combating inflation of the economy since they are consumed on use.The game also features "Races", which are timed competitve events ranging from a few minutes to a couple hours. Races can have many additional features and restrictions to make them more fun and challenging. Some races are designed to be almost an entire different game mode than the base game. Races are separated by Seasons, allowing players to earn points and win limited time alternate art unique items.On top of all this, Grinding Gear Games is one of the most communicative developers I have ever experienced. They are very active in the community and take all suggestions and feedback seriously. Lastly, the game features a completely non pay to win microtransaction model. All game content is available right from the start. Real money will only buy you cosmetic effects to make your character look awesome and a few account features for convenience. I highly recommend trying out Path of Exile if you have even the slightest bit of interest in the genre.

												TL:DR – A fun, free, online, click, click, click RPG that’s light on story with enough things to do that will keep all but the most hardcore player interested (for a bit, at least).I’ll just start with the greatest selling point of Path of Exile—no selling point. Free helps as most of the flaws don’t seem quite so harsh at that price. You’ll click on wave after wave of bad guy as you roll the loot piñata dice in hopes that this time the Staff of Iwin drops. Path of Exile is a fun little game that you’ll find yourself loading up from time to time to kill a couple of waves of bad guys before your wrist starts to hurt. 7/10.The Good—Free: Only costs bandwidth and time to download.Characters: Lots of character classes.Items: Lots of stuffs with skills being placed on gem drops to make the game different. Grinding: Now with 10% less hamster wheel.Online Community: Friends need only apply. Leagues: Lots of different events and contests for frequent players.Updates: Fairly often with new expansions and drastic changes to gameplay to keep the game interesting.The Bad—Repetitive: You better like killing snakes in the forest zone, because you’ll do lots of it.Graphics: Not bad, but worse than the competition. Much worse.Online: People who are not your friend will annoy you. Greatly.In Game Purchases: Currently, this isn’t bad but things could easily be changed to bad and make the game not worth running.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												POE is like no other dungeon crawler I've ever played. The passive tree and skill gems are such unique character building mechanics that they became my favorite part of the game. The currency system has been excellently designed too; each unit of value is not only  valuable because it is money but because currency itself is expendable for varying magical effects on your items, transportation etc. The graphics are beautiful and controls are easy to pick up/remappable.  Some monsters, especially dungeon bosses can be very challenging (not to mention on higher difficulties - Cruel, Merciless) and take multiple tries to beat. The game lets you spawn back into the dungeon with damage you've already dealt persisting on the bosses so eventually you can brute force it if that's what you want to do, unless you are on Hardcore, in which case - Permadeath. Home building is mainly a neat distraction and hub for the Masters you can use to more easily craft powerful gear. My only complaint is that progressing through the whole life of a character to the end game requires that you do the same quest/storyline several times in a sort of new game plus style. The storyline is not bad by any means, in fact the world lore and theme is pretty cool but it can start to get repetitive. One of the best things about it, I've never spent a single dime and I get the same gameplay that anyone else who spends money on it does, because the majority of purchases available, other than more stash room (not necessary they give you plenty) are cosmetic only.Highly highly recommend to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers, and to anyone who hasn't tried one before, why not give it a shot? Free-2-Play after all.
