content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I was surprised that I did not have a review written for PoE, I have 2300+ hours played on the game. Let me preface this review by stating that if you know anything about the ARPG genre then you are probably already playing this game, but if you don't this review is for you. With all my experience I hope I can help you make the decision if this is the right game for you. So without further delay lets jump right in.The pros:- This game has a lot of content, more than most free to play games I have played. The developers actively and in a timely manner release new content, items and game mechanics on a 2~3 month cycle. They diligently pay attention to the continued existance of their game, I respect them for that.- The game is hard, especially for a new player. Don' listen to people who write in their reviews that the game has lost all challenge, these are usually people with thousands of hours played using the most expensive builds in the game to trivialize content like those builds are meant to. In this experience you can really fine tune how challenging the game is if you are after that.- The game has a very deep level of customization for builds, you can pick it up and play it no matter what you build, but don't expect your first build to carry you far. This game is most of all a learning experience, knowledge here really is power.- The visual design and music score are great, they really work to bring the world to life. There is plenty of lore hidden in item descriptions and places around the world. You can also build your own hideout from different items that the master NPCs in the game offer if you are into that like me.- This game is truly free, no content is held behind a pay wall. Crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥I know, but don't expect it to be given to you on a silver platter. However, no matter what you do every moment you sink into the game is worthwhile, everything you pick up no matter how incrementally leads to you reaching your goals. That is something that I can not say for most the experiences on the market.The cons:- The game is hard and unforgiving. You will die to random things while playing and have to piece back together what you did wrong if you don't want to die again. Do not get discouraged, it happens to literally everyone.- Trading is an essential skill you need to learn to get ahead in the game, but the trading community is very toxic. People trying to make a profit constantly prey on new players so learn how to use poe.trade and check it to make purchases and sales. Know what something is worth before you sell or buy.- The learning curve is steep, but there are plenty of resources to prepare you for it. You tube guides, the game forums and the amazing wiki have everything you could ever need to get started. Do not ask people in game to explain a nebulous concept to you, most of the game mechanics require several paragraphs to explain, use those other resources and feel free to ask specific questions about what you want to know.- The gap between the rich players and the poor players is truly vast, bridging it is impossible without a lot of effort. You can't pay to win and if you do to one of the illegal bots expect to get banned, the developers stay on top of that.In my opinion this is the best ARPG on the market and it keeps evolving to stay that way. I enjoy playing and supporting a game made by people who convey a level of professionalism one expects from people running a business and not just working on their game "hobby".

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Although I'm no huge fan of hack'n'slash RPGs, PoE was the first game of this genre since long ago (since D2 I bet) which managed to keep me playing for longer than just a few hours. Sure, I played D3 through but rather forcing myself than with relish, and I absolutely agree with the opinion that PoE is a way better match for the Diablo franchise than D3 itself. At least, it features the right look & feel, proper dark atmoshere, tons of customizable loot, much more interesting character development, and last but not least - appropriate size and length. And on top of all that it's completely free! "Free to play" but not "pay to win", so you can enjoy it to the full without spending a single cent.The downsides? Yeah, they exist too, but I'd describe them to be minor and inessential. Permanent connection to the server in a single-player game (but that's commonplace nowadays), somewhat bad placement of waypoints across locations which eventually forces you to replay certain (quite large) locations twice or even more times, rather sophisticated skill tree (not necessarily a bad thing). But the rich core gameplay pays it all off, I must say.In any case, I strongly recommend this brilliant game to all RPG fans and to anyone who loves good games no matter what genre they are. Despite some minor flaws, it is fully capable to carry you off the reality for some considerable time and give you bright and memorable experiences.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												After not enjoying the Closed Beta and early Open Beta (after climbing to level 36, and 29 in each) I decided that the game was sluggish and "Not For Me" while admiring the dark Diablo 1 and Diablo 2 style Art Design and attempted feel, along with the best ARPG graphic engine and shadows to be displayed in a ARPG title yet.Luckily GGC has been able to pull off an amazing development cycle since that point, I read up on it finally being released after 7 years &decided to give it another shot! I am glad I did, as all issues I had with the game are not only fixed, but changed in a way that feels perfect in all aspects - I do not see any area that they could have improved on further from the point I started playing at to the release; with that in mind some of these aspeccts and more will be altered further making the title even better. After only 22 levels as a Shadow going for a unique twist on the Dual Spike Armor/HP/Regen/HealthMana Leeching builds out there (I allocated 75 points that I thought seemed perfect; 85  "In case I grind that much out" 100 as "Pipe Dream Build" The developers stated that Magic The Gathering was the main inspiration for the Skill Web allowing any class to "Break the Rules" tactically and come up with their own vision of a build that developers may not have assumed would "Work" as cited by GGC for MTG how endless players such as I made decks in the standard rotation that nobody thought of doing as it seemed unconventional; every tournament and magic event I went to with my most recent deck right prior to Theros being released shook my hand even if I took the loss of the set stating "Thats the most interesting" or "That is one of the most amazing decks I've seen" "or Played against" - Nothing feels better than building ideas on your own with a vision of HOW it should be executed.PoE allows this My shadow is going to turn many heads and just as I "Broke" the way "WoW's Burning Crusade" end game worked (as stated by Mod on a Forum Post) by allocating a skill tree never displayed prior online (or until 3-4 months of using it, then I personally posted it so other Hunters could try it) along with a Mixture of PVP Arena Gear and Raid gear to keep the #1 DPS spot in Raids; while without switching abilities or gear be top of any battleground Leaderboard with (for example 24 Kills, 11 assists and 3 deaths.) - With that mindset...PoE allows you to not have to depend on just gear or just a build ; aside from the endless web of skills and attribute boosts that makes FFX look like Diablo 3 in "Scope, Scale and Staggering Size" The gems being socketed into gear that you alter with interconnecting slots to have multiple abilities chained with multiple support (such as three elements per Double Strike or Multi-strike with a Crit Damage Support Gem alongside the Double Strike (depending on how the sockets are connected)  New Players will feel at home but may need to check how the skill trees differentiate or do not differentiate each class. Along with how a Common item drop may end up being one of the most devestating pieces of gear you find depending on how you alter it after using an unhealthy amount of Armor or Weapon Quality Upgrades; which then allows the Gem Socket change gem to have higher % chance of adding more sockets (I was able to get a 5 socketed claw at level 22 due to this method upgraded to yellow; with stats that are mind blowing). It shows that the user is really in control.I cannot reccommend this game enough giving it an honest solid 9.1/10 *my rating scale is very very "this game needs to be perfect to be perfect* as seeon my IGN profile reviews for each title I own. - I deducted .1 points due to a rather insane 9 dollars per card drop for steam cards or else it would be a 9.2; if it was 9 dollars to initiate all card drops the score would remain the same.That's a solid 9.1/10 PLAY IT. NOW.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Path of Exile is worthy of any action-RPG's fan's attention - especially since the game is free.  If one wishes to support the game developers, money can be spent for cosmetic changes and to increase your stash size, but neither are required to play the game.While the passive skill tree is enormous, it does require a bit of thought and planning to be utilized effectively.  Active skills are socketed to items, allowing unique combinations and a large amount of variety to gameplay (although, some options are far more effective than others).  Skills are leveled through experience that your character gains as they are socketed in an equipped item.Disadvantages...two in my experience: descynchronization from the required servers, even with ample internet capability; the targeting system is frustrating for melee type characters.  Both are irritating and exacerbate each other, often leading to character deaths.  As with Diablo 3 (the only other ARPG game that I have played with a server connection requirement), this has kept me from playing hardcore characters.  It's a shame, because I enjoy the challenge.Overall, I will wholeheartedly recommend the game, despite the above-mentioned flaws.  The developer seems committed and responsive to the fans / supporters, which is a nice bonus and will hopefully ensure future changes which allow for better, more reliable gameplay.  Additionally, the amount of variety and different gameplay options (races, ladder servers, etc.) should keep long term players' attention.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Path of Exile is undoubtedly one of the best free-to-play titles in recent years. If you're a fan of eerie & spine chilling, fantasy hack 'n' slash games where fighting huge mobs of ghastly creatures and ominous soldiers are the norm, Path of Exile is for you. As many have said already, this game has a very similar feel to the Diablo series and takes a large amount of influence from it (i.e. how the game is set into Acts and once you have completed them you can move onto harder difficulties), but also adds something of it's own into the mix such as having no currency in the game. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been and totally takes the cake between the two. The amount of content in the game is astounding and sometimes I can't believe that this game is free-to-play. Of course, you have your proverbial microtransactions but unlike other games, Path of Exile offers mostly non-competitive items for sale such as more character slots and guild options. Player vs. Player is another great element to the game and from what I have seen it contains 1 vs 1, 3 vs 3 and 6 vs 6 arenas though the matchmaking is a bit buggy when joining a queue. So, if you are looking for an overly addicting, loot driven, online hack 'n' slash game with tons of gore and brutality, download this game now! You won't regret it!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Do you like action RPGS like Diablo 2, Torchlight, and Titan Quest? Yes? Then look no futher than Path of Exile.  This game is free to play in every sense of the word.  All money you can potentially spend is on cosmetics and such.  If you like it, it is worth supporting them as they have made an enjoyable game that never hounds you to spend money.  One playthrough will take around 20-25 hours, but you will likey want to go back and choose a new character to play with.The biggest difference with this game as opposed to other action RPGS is that the skill you have are tied to gems that you pick up and then slot into armor/weapons.  These gems level up by you using them.  You can unslot them and then reslot other gems as you see fit (they maintain their levels).  This allows you to really experiment with builds while not being restricted to specific skills or armor.Just give it a go. You will like it!

All the things you can spend $ on are things such as cosmetics for your character, pets, decorative set pieces for your hideout, and other petty stuff along those lines.- The game features perhaps the deepest way to create a character's build in video gaming history. You see, the game has a passives tree with over 1,000 nodes to invest in. The class you pick merely determines where in the tree you'll start. For example, The Duelist class starts on the bottom, where strength and dexterity meet.  Here is a picture [i.imgur.com] of the current passives tree. This massive tree combined with the strange way you mix skill gems with support gems to bend your spells to do exatecly what you want. For example, you can attach a fireball (skill gem) with Lesser Multiple Projectiles (a support gem). Now instead of 1 fireball, you now shoot 3. Or perhaps you want to summon a totem to shoot the fireballs for you? Or maybe your fireballs fork into two more fireballs when they hit an enemy. On top of that, "unique" items in the game can bend the normal rules for your character, to allow for even more creativity and possibilites present. - Three month leagues with special rules or permanent leagues. A multitude of various races to start a character at level 1 and reach the furthest in the game in a certain time under certain rules running every day. Softcore or hardcore. There's a lot of variety present in the game which is sure to find your niche.- Amazing developers deliver content on the regular. I took a break from the game (after about 1,200 hours) for 3 months and when I came back there were 14 new support gems, 7 new skills, a new master system, personal hideouts, and more bugfixes/quality of life changes than I cared to read in one session. Cons- *...cough...- JK, there is a learning curve. It may take you a few hours to get a real feel for the game. For people like me, that's actually a Pro, but may be a bit off putting to some.I give the game 10/10, and award it 'Best Indie Game', 'Best Crowdfunded Game', and 'Best ARPG'go play it u doofus

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												This is one of the best games ever made, and when played on hardcore it is one of the most difficult, challenging and rewarding games of the modern era, a triumph over most games of this generation, and a callback to times when every player had to learn the game they were playing in order to succeed, rather than being catered to and handheld. Except this time you have an interactive community to help you along the way, as the game features trading, partying, player housing, and an 'interesting' global chat. And what a journey it will be, the atmosphere of this game feels like a blend of Dark Souls meets Diablo. Despite the graphics being pretty simple there's a ton of heart and fantastic art direction+flavour paving every step of the way. There's literally thousands upon thousands of ways to build your character. (Despite this 90%* of the community just plays CoC builds) *hyperboleThe best part? The game is free, aside from some purely aesthetic microtransactions which look very nice. No pay2win here. (Until you need more stash tabs i.e storage space) The community is one of the most diverse (for better & for worse) communities I've ever encountered, and the depth of this game is greater than most MMORPG's, despite this genre being an online ARPG. The difficulty scales to an absurd extent, you can never truly "Faceroll" every aspect of this game,(Unless you play CoC, in which case please uninstall--you're not a good player, stop uploading twinned boss map clear videos to Reddit, nobody cares--except for other CoC players) and there's just so much depth and replayable value to this game that I really can't recommend it enough. The endgame, on hardcore, is insanely fun and often times heartracing, with immense risk and reward being omnipresent throughout the experience. The more you play this game, the more you want to play it, and that is a surefire sign of both an addictive problem and a masterpiece. On the negative side of things, the early portion of this game is a total, unintuitive mess--if you're unfamiliar with the ARPG genre, or even if you're somewhat familiar with it, the game will likely feel far too overwhelming to bother with, it doesn't even bother trying to tutorialize you, and while the exploratory independence the game gives you is ultimately empowering, it's a little too vacuous for genuinely new players. Several of the game's mechanics & character features are amazingly in depth and customizable once you begin to grasp them, but unfortunately they also come off as very hard to understand initially, and even once you begin to understand them you'll likely fail to fully realize what you can do with them for quite some time. None of this is necessarily "bad", but it could certainly be offputting to a large demographic. The pace of the game is also painfully slow early on, this is especially true if you have no gear and if you're new to the game-most new players and even several veteran players don't know how to level efficiently, and waste a lot of excess time doing certain pointless side quests, picking up every useless item, killing every mob, doing irrelevant side areas, etc. Bluntly put, combat will not feel satisfying for a while, but when your build starts to come together and the enemies start to possess actually significant mechanics, boy oh boy does the world ever turn upside down. On top of that, the "true" game doesn't kick off until merciless difficulty, by which point you'll already have "beaten the campaign" twice, and this is presently very unintuitive to newer players, so a significant portion of the "playerbase" ends up "beating" the game (in their eyes) on normal and then never returning, even though the real experience hasn't even begun yet (Although regardless, at least these people get to experience the boss fight "Malachai", which is something you'll probably not soon forget). However, I'd still implore anyone who might turn away from the game because of these reasons to *just trudge through it* because, come merciless difficulty, come MAPS, it'll all prove to be deeply worth it. Once you get your first good unique item, once you 5 link or 6 link your first item, etc. etc., you'll have nowhere to go but up. That is, until your character dies and you angrily uninstall or reroll a CoC build. Screw CoC builds they're killing the game and trivializing the content, alright GGG you caught me this was all really an elaborate ruse with the actual intent of this review being nothing more than a rant about CoC builds. CoC builds are utterly faceroll and negate all strategic thought, difficulty, mechanics, and build variety involved in this game. Also nerf lightning coil and blade vortex. GOTY.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												A triumph of the action RPG genre, a testament to the capabilities of smaller independent developers and proof that not all "free to play" is "play to win".To say that Path of Exile simply takes the Diablo formula and expands upon it would be a disservice to the work of Grinding Gear Games, who instead make their own bold innovations on the action RPG genre resulting in a true rarity in modern gaming: a deep, challenging experience that requires you to rely on your own ingenuinity and planning in order to succeed.These innovations are numerous, ranging from an enormous passive skill tree which affords a great deal of character build diversity to a slew of skill gems which are socketed into items to grant your character abilities rather than being tied to your class. These gems level independently of your character, can be traded with others, and can be augmented with support gems to fundementally change how they operate. Creative use of these gems is essential; for example, linking a "fireball" gem with a "lesser multiple projectiles" gem to turn your single fireball into a flurry of firey damage.Developer interaction with the community is notably strong: Grinding Gear Games are open and engaged developers who listen to community feedback and evolve their game with players in mind. Content updates and patches are regular and significant, with new unique items being introduced at frequent intervals, along with new skill gems. Race events are almost constantly available for those looking for the replayability that a ladder system can provide, while new acts are promised for the future to continue the story.Path of Exile is an extraordinary game, made even more appealing by the fact that it is completely free to play. Microtransactions exist in the form of harmless cosmetic trinkets that have no impact on gameplay whatsoever, something that cannot be applauded enough. This is one of the most ethical free to play titles available. Even people who paid $1000 - you read correctly - to design one of the game's unique items did NOT receive a copy of that item for themselves. They STILL had to discover the item ingame like everybody else.If other action RPGs have let you down, you'd be a fool not to try this one. Even if you're happy with the other games on offer, for no cost you really have no reason not to try this stunning addition to the genre.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												It's been touted by some as what you actually wanted from Diablo 3. After playing it, I'm kind of inclined to agree. Active skills are attached to gems which you can socket/unsocket from gear at will, which can force decisions between skills and better stats when your new piece of gear doesn't have the right slots. There are passive skills awarded upon each level up that look a lot like the FFX sphere grid. It's possible to build almost any way you want using this, but each class has passive skills which you're meant to specialize in (i.e. are easier to access). Microtransactions exist, of course, but have no real impact on the game, unless you count extended stash space. Also, has perhaps the most unique health potion system I've seen which I'd like to see done elsewhere. Your potions have X charges and use a set amount of charges per use of the potion. These charges replenish as you kill enemies. Furthermore, these potions are stored in their own separate inventory.Basically, if you're interested in this style of game and have the hard drive space, there's not much reason to not AT LEAST try it out. Afterall, if you don't like it, you're out nothing but your own time. Only complaint at the moment is that like Diablo 3, it is online only, which means the servers aren't local and it's possible to run into bits of lag here and there, even with fairly good internet speeds.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												What do you get when you cross-breed Final Fantasy VII's materia system with Diablo 2? You get Path of Exile, a game which demands a great deal of theorycrafting and immense build diversity the likes of which you will never see in many ARPGs.Pros:+ Free to play+ No pay-to-win, all microtransactions are aesthetic.+ Vast build diversity+ All skills are available to use by any class+ Helpful, active community+ New take on currency and how it affects trading+ Massive, comprehensive skill tree.+ (Personal interest) Competant summoning and minion featuresCons:- Always online- Trade chat is poorly implemented- Game has terrible problems with desync- Standard league economy is horribly inflated- Not for casual gaming, requires a great deal of time and effort to get to the real fun parts of the gamePros explained:The first thing that attracted me to this game the most was the summoning system. Diablo 2 had spoiled me rotten with the necromancer, nothing was more fun for me than running around with a large army of skeletons at my back, ready to charge forward to engage the enemy. Not many ARPGs can pull off a good summoning mechanic, but when they do, its always amazing. Path of Exile not only lets you raise hordes of zombies that fight until they die, but also allows you to summon skeletons that offer support and come in larger numbers. The best part of summoning, however, comes in the form of raising spectres. Imagine fighting a monster that is very proficient at wiping out your minions, and then turning that monster into your own minion to fight for you! And there's more, from summoning flaming skulls that bypass enemies and small obstacles to animating weapons to animating a full-blown suit of armor!The next big feature I loved about this game is how they handle currency. Most games just give you basic currency like gold which you use to buy or sell things. Not in this game! Currency comes in the form of special orbs which also provide useful functions. One orb can be used to give you respecs to your passive tree for example, another can be used to turn a mundane (white) item into a rare quality item. There's lots of orbs and each orb is valued differently between each other based on rarity on usefulness. If you can find the 'mirror of kalandra', you've officially become a rich player, but good luck finding it!There are no direct skills to speak of when leveling up, but they are passive improvements. When it comes to Path of Exile, it doesn't give you a skill tree, it gives you a passive skill jungle! Those who have played Final Fantasy X will know what I'm talking about. The passive skill tree is what allows for such an amazing build diversity. Its very complicating for new players, but thankfully the forum has many build guides you can use to teach you how to build yourself. I highly recommend you try and make your own build first to understand the passive skill tree before reading a build guide.Ah, but the greatest feature of all about this game lies in the actual skills themselves. This game offers a myriad of abilities that are accessible to every player, so long as they can meet the stat requirements for them. Want to throw a fireball? Sure. How about raining fire on the enemy? Why not! Want to throw a spectral copy of your weapon at an enemy and watch it fly back to you? You can get it. The fun doesn't stop there, no. You can also augment your abilities with support gems to make them more powerful! Want to shoot more fireballs at once, or to make them split on impact? There's support gems for that! Want your arrows to bounce between multiple enemies or pierce right through them? That's possible. Want your melee attacks to attack multiple times in one cast, or to make your melee do AoE damage? You can do that. There's infinite possibilities when using skills, you just need to know what works best!Cons explained:However, this game does have some downsides you will have to deal with. The first and perhaps biggest issue this game suffers from is desync. For those who don't know what desync is, the simplest way to describe it is that the client isn't in sync with the server. For instance, you're trying to escape from some enemies in a hall and while you think you have escaped, you're still taking damage and when you die, you wind up back where the enemies were. Rubberbanding is the best way to describe desync and you will be experiencing this a lot. If you play on the hardcore leagues, its IMPORTANT that you play carefully and utilize the '/oos' command in chat to resync.This game is also not friendly to the more casual of gamers. Between build diversity, a complicated skill tree and a heavily inflated economy in the parent standard and hardcore leagues, this game demands a great deal of time and effort be invest before the game gets any fun. If you're not prepared to really sink your teeth into this game and hang on for dear life, you might want to consider playing something else.But hey, this game is free. Free, and without pay-to-win microtransactions. There are microtransactions in this game, but they are all cosmetic and designed purely to make your character stand out from the rest. There are also pets you can buy as a microtransaction, but they are also purely for visual appeal and will not give you an advantage to combat. You will never have to worry about other players buying their way to greatness, everyone is on even ground here!I really suggest you give this game a try, especially if you were a fan of Diablo 2!Helpful resources:http://www.poe.xyz.isThis site is great if you're looking to find an item in the game that you need. The site pulls information from the trade forum on the official site and if it finds a match, it will list all the items that meet your criteria. Clicking the item's name will take you straight to the player's trade thread on the forum!http://www.pathofexile.gamepedia.comThis is the wiki for Path of Exile. Everything you will ever need to know about the game can be found here. This site is very active and updates immediately when new content is released. If you ever need to know what certain skills do or what uniques do, this is the place to go.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												A triumph of the action RPG genre, a testament to the capabilities of smaller independent developers and proof that not all "free to play" is "play to win".To say that Path of Exile simply takes the Diablo formula and expands upon it would be a disservice to the work of Grinding Gear Games, who instead make their own bold innovations on the action RPG genre resulting in a true rarity in modern gaming: a deep, challenging experience that requires you to rely on your own ingenuinity and planning in order to succeed.These innovations are numerous, ranging from an enormous passive skill tree which affords a great deal of character build diversity to a slew of skill gems which are socketed into items to grant your character abilities rather than being tied to your class. These gems level independently of your character, can be traded with others, and can be augmented with support gems to fundementally change how they operate. Creative use of these gems is essential; for example, linking a "fireball" gem with a "lesser multiple projectiles" gem to turn your single fireball into a flurry of firey damage.Developer interaction with the community is notably strong: Grinding Gear Games are open and engaged developers who listen to community feedback and evolve their game with players in mind. Content updates and patches are regular and significant, with new unique items being introduced at frequent intervals, along with new skill gems. Race events are almost constantly available for those looking for the replayability that a ladder system can provide, while new acts are promised for the future to continue the story.Path of Exile is an extraordinary game, made even more appealing by the fact that it is completely free to play. Microtransactions exist in the form of harmless cosmetic trinkets that have no impact on gameplay whatsoever, something that cannot be applauded enough. This is one of the most ethical free to play titles available. Even people who paid $1000 - you read correctly - to design one of the game's unique items did NOT receive a copy of that item for themselves. They STILL had to discover the item ingame like everybody else.If other action RPGs have let you down, you'd be a fool not to try this one. Even if you're happy with the other games on offer, for no cost you really have no reason not to try this stunning addition to the genre.

												Awesome game. Feels like the true successor to Diablo 2, as it still has a massive amount of customization you can do to a character (unlike Diablo 3's kid-friendly stat system).The skill system is ripped straight from Final Fantasy VII's Materia system. Your skills are slotted into your gear and can only be used if they are slotted. I think it's a fantastic use of the system that works great in an ARPG. This increases the customization because any class can use any skill, assuming you have the stats to back it up. It allows for some crazy cross-class builds. Combine that with the MASSIVE passive skill tree (Google it and see for yourself) and you'll be theorycrafting your perfect build for a long, long time.To top it off, the microtransactions are purely aesthetic, so the game is not even remotely pay to win or pay to get epic loot quick. You still have to earn your gear, levels, and skills.This is the perfect successor to Diablo 2.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I thought I would try and write up a few words about this game, as I really enjoy the ARPG games and played through most of them (Diablo I & II, Titan Quest & IT, Torchlight I & II, Van Helsing, and only don't have D3 due to cost - though this may change when the patch comes) and for me, the Daddy of them all has been Titan Quest. I probably sunk 200+ hrs in that and Immortal Throne (they don't show on my Steam games as I had them pre-steam and loved the game so much I rebought them on Steam) and played through the game on all three difficulty ratings. So how does Path of Exile square up to these other great ARPG's? Bloody good actually. Really bloody good.Graphics The effects on everything are superb, the gem levelling, the elemental attacks, the frozen or burning mob/player effects, the animations for mobs blinking, tunnelling, dissolving, ghosting, all of it. The backdrops for locations (towns, villages, caves, forests, battlegrounds) are lush with a huge amount of detail, the characters look excellent, with a large amount of clothing variants.Maps Excellent. How many ways can you actually put dead ends into a seemingly open ended area? You will be surprised, and they do it very well. With some much detail, the minimap adds yellow 'corridors' to show connecting areas in case the foliage or camera angle is in your way, and there are plenty of variations - cave textures are repeated more often than not, but I suppose its quite hard to come up with new ways to portray rocks, so I will let them off that.Mobs A Huge amount of variation with the usual casters, fighters and ranged mobs, and then mixed abilities, casting, teleporting, swarms, etc. There is a nice mix of normal and yellow bosses, and then end of act bosses. I think I would have liked to see more 'bigger than yellow but less than end of act bosses' like in TQ, but other than that, jolly good indeed.Skill Tree & Classes Ah, the bread and butter of all ARPG's, the skill tree. This is where PoE fails, as it has no skill tree at all! Instead, it has a freaking skill WEB. No mere tree for this game, but a spiders web that depending on class, your start point changes. You gain skill points per level and for completing some quests and you can customise your (one of 6) classes to a stupid amount of variations. I thought TQ ability to combine two classes and then pick and choose from their respective trees brilliantly varied, but this is something else.Loot Ah, the loot. You want to pour of the minute of the items found, min/maxing to gain resists/hp/regen/dps? You will spend hours doing so. You want the ability to create and improve items? You will spend hours doing so. You want to take your item as you like the look of it, wipe it, and new stats, add sockets and reforge links? You will spend hours doing so. Like most other ARPGs, you never seem to find the right item for your class, but this only makes you want to farm and then replay the whole game again on the next difficulty. There are sockets to add spells and effects to your attacks, and gems to improve the quality of the items - so the combinations of items available is staggering.Overall So add them all together and what have you got? A cracking game, and even diehard 'nothing will beat Titan Quest' ARPGers will admit that this is fantastic. The game itself is free, and you really do not need to spend a penny to enjoy it - I may drop some money on it to say thanks rather than any real need to want a shiny effect on my hat or glowing footprints (even though they do look smart) A fourth act or more locations per act may have tipped it over the edge, but this is right up there, surpassing both Torchlights and Van Helsing, and right on the tailcoats of TQ. There is simply not an excuse to not download this on Steam right now.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												This game is amazing."That's great," you say. "Another ARPG. So what?"So let me get this out from the start: I am not someone who usually likes ARPGs. I liked Diablo II quite a bit back when it was new. Torchlight was good. Torchlight II was good. Titan Quest was good. But I got bored of all of them before I hit the ten hour mark; some less than that. For the latter few games, I only lasted that long because I had friends to co-op with. I have played around 180 hours of Path of Exile. Half of that was solo. I find myself playing this over games I've actually paid for - all 200+ of them.To me, this game has streamlined the process of playing an ARPG:- Clear desirable attributes for items and the ability to socket and unsocket gems at will eliminates the tedium of sorting out loot while you're in town, allowing you to quickly get back to the business of killing everything that moves or looks at you funny.- Unique currency-barter system- The community is helpful.- The devs are active.- The gameplay is challenging but not too difficult.- This game is free-to-play powered by microtransactions so unobtrusive you would be forgiven for forgetting they were there at all.I'm trying to think of some complaints here. Something to say "this could be improved by such and such" and honestly nothing immediately comes to mind. There are no major bugs that ruin the game. Each class is viable, though some are more effective than others.All in all, if you're looking to find something to play without paying a cent, and the idea of being able to leave a trail of destruction behind you in the quest for more items and power sounds appealing, it's hard to do better.5/5

Posted: March 21, 2014
												First of all let me say that i totally recommend this game to everybody who played Diablo III and got utterly disappointed by it. Path of Exile is comparable to older Diablo titles in its atmosphere and skill level and it is of course free to play. I always use PoE as an example for one of the best f2p titles out there since there is not a single pay to win aspect in the game. All you can buy with real life money are cosmetic changes to your character or more stash tabs to store items (not to be confused with your actually relevant character inventory!). Path of Exile offers  the standard action RPG game style with serveral  acts and several playthroughs, one a little harder then the other. For the first few characters that system never gets boring, but it lacks a bit of long time motivation, especially since the late game aspect of the game (maps you can find and replay zones on a higher level through them) gets boring after some time, too. PoE has something to offer for every kind of ARPG player. Those who simply want to play a hack and slay game can do so, but also players who like to think a lot about optimizing their build will be satisfied thanks to the unique and massive skill tree.There really is no reason not to check out Path of Exile, especially since it is totally free!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												An excellent action RPG for all Diablo 2 fans out there. For me Diablo 3 was kind of a disappointment, long story short: the loot didn't feel exciting. In Path of Exile I actually expect to find useful items. I constantly find myself getting excited over a rare item dropping and even some basic white items for crafting.Another thing I disliked about Diablo 3 was the auction house, it just ruined the trading aspect for me since it completely removed any and all interaction with other people. Maybe I'm weird but I enjoy discussing prices with other people and actually doing the trading. Even with most people setting up a semi-automated shop via the use of "Procurement", you still get to interact with other people and there's bartering to be done.PoE has a microtransaction shop where you can buy cosmetic effects (armor skins, effects for your weapons, pets etc.) and stash tabs. You could argue the stash tabs affect the game in a way that could be interpreted as pay-to-win but I disagree. You can play the game just fine with the free 4 tabs you get by default, you just have to pay inventory tetris a bit more and choose what items you wish to keep more carefully. The skins you buy for your armor/weapons are also transferrable between items and characters, so you don't have to buy another one to apply the effect to another item.The skill tree and skill gem systems allow for a wide variety of builds and I find it nicely flexible to fit whatever I want out of a build at the time. It's more than just unlocking a fireball; you can divide that fireball to several fireballs each dealing a bit less damage but that way gaining more AoE, you can then add other types of damage to it or even make it a damage-over-time focused fireball instead of explosions, if you so wish.In conclusion I wholeheartedly recommend this game for anyone looking for a good ARPG experience. It starts out a bit slow but trust me, it's worth it.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Best action RPG out there right now, but not without its problems:PoE requires too much dedication for hard working students and people with jobs or a family who want to maintain a healthy lifestyle. If you don't have a lot of time on your hands, you're better off playing some other game because you won't get much out of PoE.The skill tree doesn't offer as much freedom as it first appears to. While the overall selection does greatly affect how your character works under the hood, they are still passive skills, most of which are just tiny percentage buffs and seriously underwhelming on their own.I'm not a fan of D3, but the active skills in PoE do not satisfy like D3's do. There aren't any active skills that really make me want to build a PoE character.In PoE you tend to build a character around one attack and spam that single one until you're blue in the face. Other action RPGs typically offer combined use of more active skills.PoE is a thinking person's game, challenging, huge depth in its mechanics. It takes a long time and a lot of reading to learn how to create strong characters and it takes forever to get characters to a high level. The learning process is a joy, but respeccing isn't really doable.The game changes a lot. If you leave the game and return after some months, you'll need to relearn wat makes a strong character, and all your character's passive skill trees will have been reset because the game's skill tree was likely updated. Your characters won't function until you reinvest those skillpoints. After returning to the game you likely won't know the current trade value of items.The game doesn't comfortably let you take a few months off and then come back.They went too crazy with the socket colours and linked sockets. While fun at first, the impossibly low odds of getting the right sockets and links on your gear become an annoying limiting factor to how you build your character. Specifically, part of the problem is that the type of defence stat (armor, energy shield, or evasion) on a gear item determines what socket colour is most likely to show up on it. Active kills are gems that need to be socketed before you can use them, and they will only fit in sockets of the matching colour. This effectively forces you to focus on a specific defence type based on what active skills you want to use, severely restricting the endless freedom that the passive skill tree initially appears to provide.

												Hardcore action rpg fans will love this game. If you're new to the action rpg scene(like i was), conquering this game may prove extremely difficult. The graphics are above average for a free to play game, providing a very dark world with creepy crawlers (lots of spiders) and catastrophobic caverns (lots of undead). The story is almost non existent with the game but it does try its best to add some lore. The game offers deep customisation in how you build your character, issuing one of the largest passive skill (yes passive) trees i have encountered in an action rpg (i have only played three). You can choose from 7 characters (1 is unlocked throughout the game), each differing in lore, sex and appearance. Path of exile lends it self to very deep builds and theorycrafting, which hardcore players will adore. Skills are collected from the world either from quests, drops or from trading with players. These skills are called "skill gems" and begin as your fundamental action rpg spells. You will later acquire support gems which will provide unqiue abilites to the skill gems resulting in some nice effects adding to the games fluid combat. The game offers an in game store, however this is purely cosmetics based and storage space extensions which is initially huge anyway, offering no "pay to win" bonuses. After a few run throughs (i did about three messing up all three characters after and before release) and starting a new character today, i felt the repetitive nature of the story and dungeons, and caverns overwhelm me. This is purely point subjective and will differ within the community. 11 hours of gameplay plus about 5-6hours during beta is nowhere near enough to fully enjoy and experience this game to its fullest. But i feel thats all this game will get out of me, which is a shame because i really do want to support the developers for their efforts.Path of exile is an above average free to play action rpg fans of the original diablo games will enjoy. Get your pens, papers, mathematics ready, this game's going to need it.

Posted: February 25, 2016
												Path of Exile is a very deep ARPG with a rather unusual currency mechanic and a massive skill tree. It has a steep learning curve and can be somewhat punishing, but that's also what makes winning feel so rewarding.The devs have kept their promise of making the game truly free. Most microtransactions confer cosmetic changes. The only microtransaction that actually affects gameplay is unlocking additional stash tabs (bank storage space). I found that when I only had one character, it was pretty easy to stay within the limits of the default 4 tabs. After a hundred hours of gameplay, I felt like a small payment to be able to hoard more items was more than justifiable (and a bit more to make my new character look super cool!).The game is also kept interesting by regular challenge leagues where you start a new character in a separate game world with a fresh economy and different gameplay rules. At a low low price of free, it's definitely worth a go!

content:
Posted: April 17
												ABOUT THIS GAMEYou are an Exile, struggling to survive on the dark continent of Wraeclast, as you fight to earn power that will allow you to exact your revenge against those who wronged you. Created by hardcore gamers, Path of Exile is an online Action RPG set in a dark fantasy world. With a focus on visceral action combat, powerful items and deep character customization, Path of Exile is completely free and will never be pay-to-win.Key FeaturesFreedom. Power. Revenge.Banished for your misdeeds to the dark, brutal world of Wraeclast, you play as the Duelist, Witch, Ranger, Templar, Marauder, Shadow or the Scion class. From forsaken shores through to the ruined city of Sarn, explore Wraeclast and uncover the ancient secrets waiting for you.Unlimited Character CustomizationCreate and customize hundreds of unique skill combinations from tradable itemized gems and our gigantic passive skill tree. Combine skill gems, support gems and trigger gems to create your own unique combination of power, defense and destruction.Deadly MissionsThe Forsaken Masters each have their own style of mission and each of these missions has many variations. As you explore deeper into Wraeclast, the pool of available variations increases to challenge you in new ways. All of the Missions and their variations can occur anywhere in the game, including within end-game Maps.Dressed to KillPath of Exile is all about items. Find, collect and trade magic, rare and unique items with arcane properties, then customize your character build around the deadliest combinations you possess.Brutal Competitive PlayBattle in PvP tournaments seasons and Capture the Flag events for worldwide recognition. Compete in Daily Leagues and Race Events that run as separate game worlds with their own ladders and economies to win valuable prizes.Customise Your Hideout​In their extensive travels throughout Wraeclast, the Forsaken Masters have discovered ideal locations for an Exile to use as their own secret Hideout. Once you've earned a Master's trust, you may be taken to a Hideout, where you can create your own personalised town. Masters residing in your Hideout offer you daily Missions and train you in advanced crafting options. Use your Hideout as a quiet place to craft after battle, or expand it and use it as a personalised Guild Hall with hundreds of decorations.Fair-To-Play. Never Pay-To-Win. We're committed to creating a fair playing field for all players. You cannot gain gameplay advantage by spending real money in Path of Exile.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												In a world where free titles either A) try to force you into microtransactions to win, or B) just plain suck, Path of Exile breaks the mold and is, well, neither. Every aspect of this game is polished. With the exception of some sporadic server issues, I can't find much of anything to dislike about this ARPG. You've got the whole package: highly customizable (and good) graphics, good OST for that dark ambience, tons of voice acting that isn't cheesy, online play (though it's required of course), and really fun skill customization. Think Final Fantasy 7's materia system (the skill orbs you put on your gear) and Final Fantasy 10's skill tree system (a huge web of connected orbs that give you a clear route as to what playstyle you want to go with). As for microtransactions, your instinct probably tells you this could potentially be pay-to-win. But fear not! All of the items purchased from the shop are purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra bank and character slots for those REALLY hardcore players). To me, this says the developers are confident that you might support them in the future for making such a killer game and just giving it away.Overall, PoE takes a fresh spin on a tired genre and gives it to you for free. If nothing else, just download this and keep it for a rainy day when you wanna scratch that ARPG itch.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
 IntroductionPath Of Exile is an Action RPG Hack and Slash game that is true gem within its genre. Nobody should ever pass the opportunity to try the game if they are into Hardcore games with learning curves that come out of game experience. The game offers a gigantic Passive Skill tree that will enable any sort of build you might come up with. This game will please alot of thinkers as long as they are willing to understand the rules of the game but at the same time can also please the most casual of the players that just want to be there for the action.The Pros: The Combat System: Path of Exile has a unique way of combining gems. Gems represent castable skills that can either be buffing auras , statuses , combat spells , multipliers and so on. Those gems can be equiped into sockets that your gear has, combining those spells if met said requirements can make them more powerful, for example you can add a gem that allows you to fire more projectiles with your main combat ability , or you can make the projectiles have a chain effect on the enemies. This allows for insane theory crafting and build creations and cycling through many skills you can find what you truly want to play by testing it yourself or simply following guides of other experienced players on the official forums which is what I would recommend for newcommers!  Replay Value: The game offers 4 Acts Of Story , 3 Difficulties and Endgame Maps , Races that last from hours to weeks and can reward you with Permanent Items/Skins. Two Core leagues for both Casual and Hardcore players Hardcore being the one with Permanent death as result. And season leagues that last for 3 months in which you start-over with everybody else and they have their own unique mods that change the gameplay. With the Passive Tree system and the way that Skills work you can made infinite builds on any character you like , either make your own builds or test the shared ones which you can find at the official forums of the game. Refreshing Gameplay Elements: The 3 Month League system is a great feature that more games should use. Giving the original gameplay a new taste every now and then and reseting the ladders allowing people to re-compete from ground 0 is a great way to make people enjoy the game and the better part is that if you are not interested in such a thing you can always stick with Permanent leagues. This gives a further meaning to the infinite builds you can already create because in different scenarios they may work better or worse. Aside from all this, these leagues have achievements of their own which by completion you can recieve awards at the end that you would otherwise need to pay real money for. Developer relationship with Community: If Grinding Gear Games has done anything right aside from their game itself is listening to the community and delivering. Their plan is to do a content update every 6 months and an expansion one the next cycle. The game is F2P and has no P2W elements at all , yet it works really well for them. That is a phenomenom rarely seen in the F2P market nowdays and is certainely honourable.The Cons:Difficulty Curve and Player Taste: While this is not necessarily a negative feature of the game its worth noting that the game is really punishing. That can be either the beauty of the game for some , or their breaking point to quit the game and move on to the next one. While the game can be played casually , if you are seeking to play in a Hardcore league you better get ready to die, LOTS of times and then find yourself knowing the limits of your character and the strengths of certain monsters.Monotonic Visual theme and Soundtracks: While the game itself looks gorgeous in many ways and has a decent ammount of soundtracks. If you find yourself becoming a veteran you may feel a sense of dullness because the dark theme around the game starts to feel very monotonic over many hours played. With that being said at first glance you will certainely love the game if you are into the dark theme and wont have a problem, but if you end up playing alot you will notice that in the gameplay. Aside from that, specificly for soundtracks. They fit thematically really well but I cannot personally say that anything really stands out.Co-Op cross Continent can be brutal: The game offers a big selection of servers with realtime ping check before entering in and no borders in between (Meaning you can swap to any server at anytime and keep your progress) , the grouping system makes the Leader of the Group the host of the instance so if you are planning to play with friends from a different continent (on a game like this which death could be a matter of half a second) having low and stable ping is really important , it can be really troublesome.ConclussionI do recommend this game for both the casual and the hardcore gamers. The game offers huge ammount of unique playtime whether you plan on sticking around for long and being active or hopping in the game here and there. If you are a fan to the genre this is a welcoming game as it has many elements from many popular games such as Diablo and Torchlight which has taken direct inspiration from. This is one of the games that have to be in your "Must Try" collection so if you decide on playing , best of luck to you , Exile.

												Path of Exile is a FREE 2 PLAY!! action roleplaying hack and slash game comparable to the likes of Diablo 2 and the Dungeon Siege games. You play as an exile facing the harshness of the continent of Wraeclast, fighting enemies and exploring the land but mostly HOARDING items. The game allows to experience the story through 6 classes from the start plus another one that is unlocked by completing the storyline. It uses a third person or an overhead view and combat is lucid and unstiff. The world of Wraeclast is really beautiful, the dark artstyle compliments the tone. The skill tree is very diverse allowing vast customization of your character. The weapons are very diverse through different modifiers and items are tradable amongst players. The game has a PvP and Co-op options which allows you to interact with others or your friends through your journey across Wraeclast. Let's talk about the free2play model, it is not Pay2Win. Everything that you can purchase is cosmetics or stash space which does not affect the game. The game is regularly updated and devs seem very dedicated to the game. Rating: 92/100

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Time to write a proper review this time. WARNING - LONG :) TL:DR at the bottom.Path of Exile is a hardcore ARPG produced by Grinding Gear Games (GGG). The game has 7 different classes, one of which can only be unlocked further on in the story. Don't let that put you off though. The classes simply determine where you start on the gigantic passive skill tree (more on that later) and what your base attributes are. Attributes consist of strength (red), dexterity (green) and intelligence (blue). Items and skills have attribute requirements that must be met before the item can be equipped or used, with higher level items requiring a higher attribute level. Once again, don't worry if you are a witch and need more strength to equip that one item as you can get attributes from several places (again, explained later).PoE centres around chopping, smashing, shooting, burning, freezing, shocking or poisoning your way throughout an expansive storymode campaign consisting of four Acts with three difficulties: Normal, Cruel and Merciless. Normal is a nice introduction to game mechanics and build theorycrafting and creation. Enemies are easy enough to kill and you level your character reasonably quickly. Once you have completed Act 4, you can take a portal to Cruel difficulty and start again from Act 1 with your current character. Cruel begins to test the defences of your build sich as your resistances to elemental and physical damage. Merciless is where things get tough. Even your standard skeleton WILL kill you if you let your guard down or go AFK in a dungeon (seriously, don't do this). There are literally thousands of possible build ideas to centre around and either follow or diversify. Your build however will focus primarily on a specific set of skills.Skills in PoE are your abilities. The attacks, curses, auras and spells you use to decimate your foes. They take the form of coloured gems that you socket into your equipment. Skill gems have attribute requirements. For example, red gems need mainly strength. Attack skills use base stats from your weapon(s) and likely deal a % of your base damage as either physical or elemental, sometimes both. Curses are debuffs you apply to enemies (simple enough). Auras are powerful buffs that "reserve" a defined % of your maximum mana. And spells have a flat damage that scales with % modifiers from gear, usually completely ignoring a weapons base damage. Skill gems gain experience as you do, and they will eventually level up, drastically increasing their power but also increasing their attribute requirements. Gems can be added and removed at any time, even in the middle of a boss fight (if you absolutely must). A useful piece of knowledge: At level 20 (max level for gems), it will need 155 of a specific attribute. So keep that in mind. There are also support gems. These augment your active skills to give them a massive damage boost while also increasing their mana cost. Support gems only apply if they are linked to an active gem. Links are the little golden bars between sockets on gear. For a skill to be as powerful as you can get, a 5 link or 6 link will be reccomended, but not required. These are generally quite expensive but can be bought fairly cheaply for a plain white item with no modifiers. You can then craft the item with a selection of orbs and currency items.This is where the in-game monetary part of PoE must be explained because it can be confusing for new players. There is no single currency, i.e - gold. Instead there are 24 different types of orbs and scrolls that all have different values are rarities. To save me from typing them all, here is a link to the forum page explaining what they all do. https://www.pathofexile.com/item-data/currencyYou use these orbs to change attributes on your gear, making them (hopefully) more powerful and beneficial to your character. You can also trade these with other players for items. The two trading orbs are almost always Chaos orbs (fairly easy to get) and Exalted orbs (a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get. You have a 0.055% to get an Exalt from a monster). Get a lot of orbs and you are considered "rich". Please note, in almost 350 hours of playing I have found about 40 chaos orbs, 2 divine orbs and 1 exalted orb. Don't expect to get rich quickly unless you are the living embodiment of good RNG.This is most likely a lot to take in. There are many, many, MANY more aspects of the game, however they will need to be explained by someone else or discovered on your own as my fingers hurt from all this typing. Play the game, get stuck in and you WILL gain wealth and power. Try as many different builds as you want, or stick with one character to pour all your orbz into. TL:DR - Amazingly complex and addictive gameplay and a robust and rewarding economy. And you wanna know the best part? Everything is free. All the storyline is free. No hidden paywalls to unlock high level items. Free expansions. Free endgame. The devs are so non-greedy it is almost staggering, that they would put a game of this quality for everyone to enjoy. There is a cash shop containing cosmetics, skill skins and extra stash tabs (for the loot hoarders), and never once is it advertised with a huge banner ad plastered across your screen. Or even a tiny one in the top corner. I almost felt obliged to buy some extra stash tabs (I'm definitely a hoarder) and a few skins and I still feel like I robbed GGG, like I pirated a costly game.Overall rating: 10/10 - best ARPG ever released (along with Diablo II of course)

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												You bloody kiwis, you've done it. This is the best thing that came out of NZ, since Peter Jackson. Yes, the very famous description of Path of Exile is pretty accurate. This game IS what Diablo 3 should have been. Simply because Grinding Gear made some very brave decisions that Blizzard was too afraid to make. Skill runes was on the table for D3 for a long time but Blizzard didn't go through with it. GG did and it paid off. It works perfectly and brings another dimension to looting. It's rewarding enough to make you stick with a set of skills and flexible enough to get you to try different things. Concept of linking gems is almost perfect and I love experimenting with it. Removal of gold and the barter system is a very bold decision. A big name studio wouldn't have considered this because it makes the game too complicated for noobs and people who would want to buy their way through obstacles. It breaks the cycle of loot/sell and forces you to think about what you're going to do with your loot. I mean you can trade your Orb of Chances for an item you like or you can use them to get something better. It's a quite exciting concept for a purist looter. Another bold decision which makes this game a little complicated for a newbie is the colossal passive skill tree. I think this decision is a clear indication of who GG's target audience for PoE. To be succesful, you have to study the whole skill tree and plan your route. You can't just randomly allocate points and hope to survive. Not many games nowadays, encourages players to actually "think" and "plan". These words are considered "out of fashion" and "bad for business" in today's gaming world. Yeah, these are pretty brave decisions but what is bolder than giving your precious game free and having only cosmetic microtransactions in it? As if the guys in Grinding Gear tried to do opposite of everything Blizzard did with D3. "Blizzard put a $70 price tag on the game and tried to suck even more money out of the games with their RMAH. Alright, let's make PoE free and have no way of buying success in this game." This is truly a noble strategy and because of this, first time I finished PoE during public beta, I felt that I owed these guys something. I bought cosmetic improvements for the first time in my gaming life and it felt bloody good. I will do it again as long as I keep playing the game. The game is all round well polished and very skillfully executed. All the bold decisions I mentioned above made PoE truly a great game. But unfortunately, I wouldn't give it a 10/10. There's one decision prevents me calling this game "perfect" and it's decision that doomed D3 from the start: Having to be online to play a single player campaign. You can give me the logical reasons behind this decision but none of them would be convincing enough to change my mind about this. I understand that it's a richer experience with a party and multiplayer is well integrated to the game, but, I simply do not want lag during a single player campaign session. It's not so much of an issue at the start but once you make it to 60+ maps, lag/loss turns into your biggest enemy. I mean, it doesn't make it unplayable but it's quite annoying when I lose 15 mins of experience because of 1 second of lag. I can't see why this game cannot have an offline single player campaign and my rating will stay at 9/10 until this becomes the reality.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
 IntroductionPath Of Exile is an Action RPG Hack and Slash game that is true gem within its genre. Nobody should ever pass the opportunity to try the game if they are into Hardcore games with learning curves that come out of game experience. The game offers a gigantic Passive Skill tree that will enable any sort of build you might come up with. This game will please alot of thinkers as long as they are willing to understand the rules of the game but at the same time can also please the most casual of the players that just want to be there for the action.The Pros: The Combat System: Path of Exile has a unique way of combining gems. Gems represent castable skills that can either be buffing auras , statuses , combat spells , multipliers and so on. Those gems can be equiped into sockets that your gear has, combining those spells if met said requirements can make them more powerful, for example you can add a gem that allows you to fire more projectiles with your main combat ability , or you can make the projectiles have a chain effect on the enemies. This allows for insane theory crafting and build creations and cycling through many skills you can find what you truly want to play by testing it yourself or simply following guides of other experienced players on the official forums which is what I would recommend for newcommers!  Replay Value: The game offers 4 Acts Of Story , 3 Difficulties and Endgame Maps , Races that last from hours to weeks and can reward you with Permanent Items/Skins. Two Core leagues for both Casual and Hardcore players Hardcore being the one with Permanent death as result. And season leagues that last for 3 months in which you start-over with everybody else and they have their own unique mods that change the gameplay. With the Passive Tree system and the way that Skills work you can made infinite builds on any character you like , either make your own builds or test the shared ones which you can find at the official forums of the game. Refreshing Gameplay Elements: The 3 Month League system is a great feature that more games should use. Giving the original gameplay a new taste every now and then and reseting the ladders allowing people to re-compete from ground 0 is a great way to make people enjoy the game and the better part is that if you are not interested in such a thing you can always stick with Permanent leagues. This gives a further meaning to the infinite builds you can already create because in different scenarios they may work better or worse. Aside from all this, these leagues have achievements of their own which by completion you can recieve awards at the end that you would otherwise need to pay real money for. Developer relationship with Community: If Grinding Gear Games has done anything right aside from their game itself is listening to the community and delivering. Their plan is to do a content update every 6 months and an expansion one the next cycle. The game is F2P and has no P2W elements at all , yet it works really well for them. That is a phenomenom rarely seen in the F2P market nowdays and is certainely honourable.The Cons:Difficulty Curve and Player Taste: While this is not necessarily a negative feature of the game its worth noting that the game is really punishing. That can be either the beauty of the game for some , or their breaking point to quit the game and move on to the next one. While the game can be played casually , if you are seeking to play in a Hardcore league you better get ready to die, LOTS of times and then find yourself knowing the limits of your character and the strengths of certain monsters.Monotonic Visual theme and Soundtracks: While the game itself looks gorgeous in many ways and has a decent ammount of soundtracks. If you find yourself becoming a veteran you may feel a sense of dullness because the dark theme around the game starts to feel very monotonic over many hours played. With that being said at first glance you will certainely love the game if you are into the dark theme and wont have a problem, but if you end up playing alot you will notice that in the gameplay. Aside from that, specificly for soundtracks. They fit thematically really well but I cannot personally say that anything really stands out.Co-Op cross Continent can be brutal: The game offers a big selection of servers with realtime ping check before entering in and no borders in between (Meaning you can swap to any server at anytime and keep your progress) , the grouping system makes the Leader of the Group the host of the instance so if you are planning to play with friends from a different continent (on a game like this which death could be a matter of half a second) having low and stable ping is really important , it can be really troublesome.ConclussionI do recommend this game for both the casual and the hardcore gamers. The game offers huge ammount of unique playtime whether you plan on sticking around for long and being active or hopping in the game here and there. If you are a fan to the genre this is a welcoming game as it has many elements from many popular games such as Diablo and Torchlight which has taken direct inspiration from. This is one of the games that have to be in your "Must Try" collection so if you decide on playing , best of luck to you , Exile.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Overview: Path of ExileThis game is technically an MMO, but you will seldom encounter other players unless you choose to invite them to a squad with you. If it weren't for global chat, you may or may not realize that anyone else even owns the game while you're not in a major city. The gameplay is very dungeon-crawler(esque) with a good deal of lootfest and skill tree elements. Storyline: lol didn't read it, nobody has time for that (doubting anyone has time to read reviews either, but these devs deserve the time it took to give the review). Difficulty: initially there is only a normal difficulty, but a character can access a higher difficulty (cruel, the merciless) after beating the quest line on their current difficulty. Additionally, you can create normal or hardcore characters, the difference being that hardcore characters recieve better loot, but on death, they convert to standard characters, and all their gear becomes standard gear (and cannot be traded back to a hardcore character).Pros: 1) Microtransactions aren't needed for late game.. in fact, there is nothing you can buy with money that results in an in-game advantage beyond a larger storage chest. 2) Character Balance and Variety. There are nearly infinite amounts of viable character builds and skills, not just 2-3 "use these or always lose" web builds for "op classes" - from what I've seen, the classes are surprisingly well balanced.3) Community. There are usually a lot of people chatting in global, and many people are willing to provide help either in-game or just give advice on items if you're inclined to ask. As always on the internet, there's a healthy amount of salt, and a few trolls, but such is the price we pay for gaming with other people.4) Audio. The ambient sounds and the soundtracks for the game are both excellent, and the character attack sound effects manage to avoid being irritating although you end up hearing the same ones hundreds of times in the course of an hour.5) Details. The devs clearly spent enough time in other games to understand what's annoying in an mmo, and they did their best to remove those elements. Most notably, potions don't clutter your inventory - instead, you can carry up to 5 potions, which refill as you slay enemies. The game doesn't have currency, instead players trade with chaos/fusing orbs, materials which can actually be used to upgrade items, rather than exclusively be used for buying and selling.Cons:1) Repetition. Although the creatures and attacks change, but essentially every level plays out the same. It's quite grind-heavy in that even if you progress through new areas as soon as you finish the quests, the actual gameplay remains redundant.2) Actually.. being bored by the redundancy of combat is my only complaint. Although boredom is a death sentence in most games, I think I'll still keep playing this one... and even if you do quit if you become bored, there's easily 20 hours of early-game content which you'll probably complete before reaching that point.

												Holy crap this game is addictive. If you like anything about the Diablo series, this is the game for you. While it is free to play and has microtransactions for support, most of them are only for cosmetic and convienience items. You can pick up silly stuff like visual effects for your weapons and footprints or even a pet to follow you around. The only really beneficial purchases I found were inventory expansions that would probably be boderline necessary in the later game. Speaking of late game, be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to grinding and exploring before you are anywhere near leveled up or powerful. While its farly easy to outpace the starting areas, the game has a ton of content and it wil take a huge ammount of time to level up a single character to 80. And while we are forwarning, its also not one of those hold your hand and guide you through everything kind of games. It will giive you general directions and show you the basics of controls then you are on your own. Want to know how a spell or weapon works? Read the detail screens then put it on and try it out. There is no real explination to anything aside form short decriptive texts on items and abilities. Be prepared to work to learn this game, while its not as brutal as Dark Souls, it will not hold your hand and tell you when to hit "A".Overall, this is a fantastic game but will devour your free time if you let it. I've had to cut back recently because I know that if I start a game I will feel the need to continue for hours before I find a reasonable stopping point. Absolutly worth the time though, so go try it.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
5/5 ::::: Essential PlayI've never played Diablo 3, but this game makes me not mind. Surely the best action RPG on the market, and it's free. How can you not give it a try? If you preferred the skill trees of Diablo II over the third entry's approach, you have to check out Path of Exile: certainly one of the most enormous and complex skill trees I've ever encountered in a game, though I've heard the meta is apparently much more simple.There's a fairly crazy amount of depth to this game. Passive skills are earned on the skill tree, but active skills are found in the form of gems, items that are socketed (and unsocketed) into your equipment. There seems to be a lot of complexity to the system and I've barely scratched the surface myself. Beginners will definitely want to research good builds online at some point. Then there's the player hideout which you can customize to your hearts' content, and a whole world of upper-level play I haven't reached yet; you could say that the game hasn't really even begun on your first playthrough.It plays like a single player game, but it's online. I haven't grouped into any parties or traded yet, so the most noticeable online feature for me is the global chat. The one significant edit I'm bothering to make in this review after investing 100+ hours is to say: chat is addicting, but the community is pretty toxic. Channel 1 is the worst, but every channel is full of your typical Internet nihilists. This being one of my first online games, I have no idea if this is to be expected. Luckily, there is the incredible feature to turn global chat OFF. It completely transforms the game, I recommend giving it a try! Difficulty is challenging throughout; players may well breeze through earlier sections, but find themselves needing to rethink things once the difficulty ramps up at various points, especially with the relatively recently-added fourth act. Finally, did I mention it's free? Give it a try; you may just find your new obsession.
