content:
Posted: October 24, 2013
												Path of Exile is a very interesting game. With heavy emphasis on mirroring a big portion of Diablo II's successes, Path of Exile presents itself as a serviceable and even downright appealing in a truly Free-to-Play game focusing on the idea of "Ethical Microtransactions."As an action-RPG, it naturally gets compared to the likes of Diablo III, with a lot of players touting the oft-uttered "This is what Diablo III should have been" among forumgoers. The comparison is hard to avoid since the game has similar mechanics but with a stronger emphasis on having choices with consequence.Visually, the game's aesthetic is much more dark. In line with it's inspiration for gothic architecture and a lot of depressing atmospheres. Proper use of lighting to provide contrast in dark places in junction with lighting reduction as you're damaged really brings in the sense of dread when you are outnumbered and it becomes a matter of seconds before you die.The game's soundtrack is absolutely stunning. They blend well with the environments without sounding far too similar to that of it's inspiration.  Ambient audio also adds another line of what sounds like a full range of what belongs in each stage.The passive skill tree is daunting at first, but once you manage to realize it's merely a presentation that can overwhelm you and that everything goes from point-to-point, it becomes fairly simple to figure out how to use it. Each class starts in a position and moves along the "rails" one by one as they gain levels and skill points.  Choices are fairly permanent, which is quite refreshing in an age where games continually make such decisions meaningless by offering people a chance to try again with no dedication.Active skills could be compared to things like Final Fantasy VII's materia system. Each piece of gear will have a slot, which is color-coded for gem type. Green, Blue, Red, or elusive Whites. Some are support gems that enhance active abilities. Some are trigger gems, ones that cause an effect when triggered by play.  All of which gain XP and level up when you use them.Despite being a Free to Play game, Path of Exile manages to hold fairly fast to it's "Ethical Microtransactions" platform which is to say that none of their purchasable items are to give any mechanical benefit. While people can argue that character slots (of which you start with 24) and stash tabs (of which you start with 4, and can be fine with) are a mechanical advantage, the game is very much "Free to Play" in the literal sense.  Gear drop rates are not based on cash spent. Drop quality is not based on cash spent. You can't buy better gear, and you can't buy experience potions.So, Path of Exile has so far proven itself tremendously. It does a great job keeping itself reigned in, shying away from the easy-money route that other Free-to-Play games do, while providing an experience that even the bigger powerhouses in the market failed to provide.Play this game. If you loved Diablo II, you'll be hard pressed to not enjoy this.

												If you loved Diablo II and haven't been satisfied with an aRPG since, this is the game for you. Now, I've enjoyed a few (wrote a review a couple of months back for Titan Quest which I still think is a great game), but this one is by far the most reminiscant of the greatest of them all.Where this game surpasses all others is flexibility. With the enormous passive tree and the skill gem and linking system the possibilities are nearly endless. and these possibilities exist for each class.Now I must also add, the one weakness of the game is also in its flexibility. It's entirely possible to build a character that will become useless past a certain difficulty. It can be very hard to get the correct gear in combination with skill gems that will fit in that gear. But these challenges just increase the reward when you get something that works, rather than guaranteeing you with a functional build from the get go by boxing you into a very specific path (a la Diablo 3... and no hate for D3 it's just an entirely different beast)btw... this is FREE. So even if the good only sounds okay and the bad sounds really rough, it's still worth it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												This game is so ridiculously good.  I started playing it in beta before it was on Steam after a friend introduced me to it, and the game has grown so much since then.  It has so many unique things to offer.  For those who want to know more...I will attempt to explain some of the things you will need to know from the start.  It may sound daunting, but it isn't as difficult to pick up as it sounds.A quick sidenote.  Yes, it's free.  No, it's not pay to win.  There isn't a single thing in the store that gives an advantage over other players.  It's filled with a ton of cosmetics, bank tabs, and character slots.  None of which you will actually need, they're just nice to have.For starters, there is the incredibly large passive skill tree with over 1300 passives on it.  All 7 characters are positioned in different spots on this skill tree.  The "pure" characters are positioned on the passive skill tree directly within the three core attributes.  The Marauder with strength, the Ranger with dexterity, and the Witch (my personal favorite) with intelligence.  The "hybrid" characters are the Duelist with strength/dexterity, the Templar with strength/intelligence, the Shadow with dexterity/intelligence, and the Scion (who isn't unlocked until later in the game) with strength/dexterity/intelligence.  There are also jewels which can be socketed into the passive skill tree, that grant various buffs and abilities and sometimes alter other passives within a certain radius.Next is your equipment.  Weapons, armor, accessories, and flasks.  There's a ton of possible stats you can get, and every weapon and armor piece will have a random amount of colored sockets on them, some linked together and some not (I will explain that more later as it ties in with your active skills).  As for the flasks, you can have up to five equipped and those are what you use to replenish your health and mana.  There's also some with a more niche purpose.Your active skills come in the form of skill gems.  These gems come in three colors: red, blue, and green.  And what colors are those sockets on your weapons and armor?  Red, blue, and green.  You get skill gems as drops and quest rewards, and then socket them in the apropriately colored slot on your equipment.  A piece of equipment can have anywhere from one to six sockets on it, depending on a number of factors.  And if multiple sockets are linked together, then the gems in those sockets can work together.  For example, you could have a skill gem that lets you raise a zombie, and then another one linked to that which makes your zombie do more damage.The story is great, the soundtrack is cool, the NPCs are awesome.  The game has full voice acting.  Overall things have a really dark and gritty theme to it, and it's done very well.  The enemies and bosses and even the areas get progressively more and more creepy.  There's currently a total of four acts, each with their own unique things to offer.There is so much more I could talk about, I've barely scratched the surface.  The Forsaken Masters, corrupted areas, Divination cards, hideouts, leagues/events, the barter system (no actual currency in the game), all the items that can be used to alter your equipment, plus the special maps for endgame...but you can learn it for yourself when you play.

												It was the summer of 1997, i was 11 years old; one night, at some friends of friends house, in a dark room, a bright monitor enlighted me the path, a wierd music attracted me to the PC; there i saw Diablo for the first time. I feel in love with it at first sight. When a friend told me they were making a sequel, i actually started useing internet for the first time; i never had a reason to connect before, now i was seeking every piece of information about Diablo II. It was summer, it was hot, and in my hands i had a copy of Diablo II, i was one of the most happy nerdfag ever seen. I don't know why but i started playing on-line as first experience (the phone bill was bad that summer, very bad); after that, i played for other 4-5 years that harsh evil game called Diablo II, both in soft and hard-core. It was around 2008 when i saw the website of Diablo III, a brief video of a Barbarian smashing enemies, with havok, sparkles and all. Couldn't wait so i started playing D2 again, and again until 2012, when Diablo III came out. With all my friends we were there, ready to have it. We were there, on team speak, playing hard, but the feel was kinda different, we couldn't tell what was it; we were playing the new chapter, the last piece of the story, with new mechanics and all; but something wasn't there, i played hundreds of hours but couldn't find it anywhere in it; it was passion. The passion to make every detail matter, every little piece of the puzzle match the greater design. This is Path of Exile, an artistic passionate song to a game genre that was dying; Grinding Gear Games picked their favourite game, which i guess is Diablo II, and from its ashes, they made something truly new and innovative.(I don't play PoE on steam, i play it on their original Launcher, got many chars above 85, some also HC)

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Looking for a good hack and slash that doesn't have cartoony graphics like Torchlight or doesn't have the mistakes that Diablo 3 made on release? Look no further! Path of Exile is just that. Path of Exile by no means is a perfect game, but it is a good "more modern" take on the original Diablo.The CombatThe combat is great! It is very meaty and I can "feel" the impact. All the spells have good graphical and sounds assets to them. You are also constnatly getting mobbed left and right by monsters, so you will never  have a lack of monsters to smash in the face. However one thing that does hurt their combat a bit is the latency. Most games when played on around 100 ping doesn't make a big difference, however in this game when the server decides to start running slow (which happens more frequently than I want it to), you end up getting a lot of warping monsters. This gets especially annoying when the monsters you are fighting can blink or leap everywhere. It does seems like hit detection have lag compensation, because I have managed to kill a few mobs that are no where near me due to lag with melee attacks a few times.The Graphics With all my settings on max, the graphics isn't all that great. This is mainly due to graphics on characters and monster models. They are a bit outdated. The actual terrain textures, and the graphics of the environment is "beautiful" (cause calling anything beautiful in this game would just be outrageous). The player can really see the game's doom and gloom artistic direction. Like mentioned in the combat section of the review, the special effects from skills and abilities are great.The Game MechanicsThis is hard to judge. If you are a "core" gamer, there is definately an appeal to the way passive skill tree works, and the way the vending/trading system works. However with that said, these systems do have their flaws. Selling things to vendors is essentially a horadric cube. There are crafting recipes you need to consider when selling things so that you can get the best payment for the items you get. What a bunch of scroll of identification? Sell the vendor any non-magical or rare item that is not peiced into a recipe properly. However that skill gem you don't use, or that iron ring you don't use that you just sold for scroll fragments could have properly be sold to make something much more valuable. Meaning, for people that doesn't what to wiki their way through the game, the trading can be very fustrating when you found out later on you just got jipped by the vendor. Talking about being jipped by the vendor, buying things from vendors are utterly useless. Most of the currency items you use to buy the gear with is more useful to be just used upgrading a random white superior gear that you pick off on the ground. The only time I ever find myself every buying things from vendors is when I need to convert 1 type of currency to another. Or when I have 1 really underleveled gear that I simply couldn't find a good replacement for, because I either never get a magical/rare version of that item type of the right level, or I don't have the currency items to upgrade a white version of it. The passive skill tree is massive! At first glance it seems like a core player's wet dream. Unlimited possibilities. Your OWN custom build that fits your play style. Well... that might not be COMPLETELY true. I love it because its innovative (kinda), but it have some major flaws. The shear size of the skill tree will turn average players away. There are people out there that isn't playing in hardcore league and they just want to play a hack and slash to enjoy themselves. Most of the passive skills on the tree are boring and redudant. Majority of the tree is just a flat base stats increase or flat damage increase. The amount of skills that does anything interesting is no different then that of any other passive skill tree you find in any other video games.  Also there is a "one true build" mentality within the community when you play certain subtypes of a class. So placing skill points wherever you think that seems nice? Not possible if you wish to party with pubs at higher levels. Though they don't see your build, but they will complain about you not being completely optimized.  QuestingThe questing in this game is awesome. Storywise it is really no different from any other hack and slash, but the fact that a lot of side quests needs to be "discovered" is a pretty good addition to the game. ConclusionI love this game. I definately would recommend it. It does have a few problems, but in all honesty most of it is just more because of fustration then anything else.However a word of warning. Casuals should stay away from this game, because the game hates you. The way that the health pots and mana pots work in this game may seem like a good thing for casuals initially, however because you are constantly swamped by mobs, it balances it back out to become a relatively hard game. Despite all the negatives I brought up in this review. Remember, THIS IS A FREE TO PLAY. Complaining about things that can only be fixed with a higher budget only goes to show your insensitivity. For example, a lot of people complain about lag, I even did to. However in my review I was questioning why we get warping at 100 ping (which isn't bad), instead of just simply complaining general lag, which requires money to fix. Another example is character animation. People complain that there are bad character animations. To be perfectly honest I can barely see that over all the FUN I am having. I am impressed that Grinding Gear Games is able to create a nearly triple A quality product as a free to play game.

Posted: November 28, 2014
												This is a complete head-scratcher.  It's been around too long to not have a succesful business model, but I'm astonished at how ethical the microtransactions are in this F2P Diablo-alike.No, no hyperbole, I'm truly astonished.  I mean, it's almost hard to find the microtransactions, and they come in three flavors: Extra character slots, extra equipment tabs, and cosmetic appearances.I don't know how many character slots PoE has, because playing one character is dozens of hours of playtime.  Playing two (it's nice to have a "solo" character and a "co-op" character, which you can do without paying anything) is easily over 100 hours of playtime.I still have enough stash tabs to organize my stuff into appropriate tabs.  I might need more tabs some 200 hours into the game.  Maybe?And there's a huge amount of things to upgrade.  Weapons and armor that has slots for skill gems, but also "currency" items to buy items from vendors (no gold?  Yes, no gold) that also affects your items.  This helps the "trash loot" and "RNG gods" problems so much.  If you find an item with great slots, but not enough else,  you can enchant, disenchant, renchant, add more enchantments, craft on more enchantments, etc.  If you find a great item with poor numbers of slots, you can reroll slot, reroll links, etc.  How do you get these items in this Free-To-Play game, you ask? ...from Grinding Gear Games, the answer is "NOT by paying money.  Ever."  You want those items, you find them or you trade for them.  But wait, doesn't that create a third-party economy that might sell stuff out of channel?  Maybe, but GGG resfuses to compromise the quality and feel of a game the depth of Diablo II to try and skim some profits.The skill tree (web, really) is just bananas, too, in a great way.  The selection of passive skills and abilities mixed with the equipment in this game encourages, again, Diablo II leves of creative character building, with a shocking amount of high-end viable oddball creations.  (Just be aware of the vastly larger phase-space of useless characters you can make along the way, and assume you won't get your first character right.  Really, it's okay).The difficulty level make for a fun experience for those looking for a fun ARPG romp, but challenging theorycrafting challenges at the higher levels for hardcore players.Best game I've played all year?  Maybe.  Most?  Hands down.

Product received for free
												Path of Exile is an Free to Play online action role-playing game.  The player controls a single character from an overhead perspective and explores large outdoor areas and underground caves or dungeons, battling monsters and fulfilling quests from NPCs to gain experience points and equipment. All areas aside from the central encampments are randomly generated for increased re-playability. While all players on a single server can freely mingle in encampments, gameplay outside of encampments is highly instanced, providing every player or party with an isolated map to freely explore.  The game borrows heavily from the Diablo series, particularly Diablo II.   The graphics, sound, gameplay looks pretty good.  For more info:

												Daybreak. The first rays of sunlight claw their way through the dawn and glint off my monitor like shards of glass, mocking me. I briefly see my reflection, haggard and inhuman, before I whip the curtains closed. I do not know how long I've been here; the passage of time means little to me now. My friends and family have stopped calling, their pleading voices falling harshly on my ears like a horrible, otherworldly tongue. I haven't spoken in so long that I've forgotten how to form the words. Crit chance and dexterity, skill gems and passive points. These are the only things I value. I have created a new instance in life, destroying the old. This is what I've become. This is my exile.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The best ARPG on the market today, and it's FREE! No pay-to-win BS, either; all you can buy are cosmetic effects for spells and equipment, more stash space for hoarding items, and character slots. Most people won't even need to buy the latter, though, because you start with 24 slots for free. Endless character builds to try out, regular content updates and free expansions planned, on-going series of race events where you can compete and earn limited edition prizes... If you're a fan of the genre, there's no reason not to be playing this.My only complaint with this game is the de-sync. They had to make the game always-online to prevent cheating, but then to accomodate the fast-paced, highly reactive and tactical combat, they're constantly syncing game state between your client and the server... Which, when their servers are overloaded by the huge influx of players on Steam, can often mean rubber-banding or lag in performing actions. It's most frustrating when playing hardcore, and a half-second delay can be the difference between life and death. They've been working hard to alleviate such problems, so hopefully they can make it better soon.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Path of exile is as some would say, the true successor to Diablo 2. While in reality thats not a fair comparrison as they are two very different games.Path of exile is a refreshing take on a very common genre.::Pros::HUGE Passive treeLittle to no Gear limitationsLarge RNG factorDecent graphicsGGG Updates often mixing the meta up.::Cons::Trading system ( will explain below )Support ( will explain below )Forums ( Will explain below )No end-game contentNo real reason to level past 78Flooded Economy (Will explain below )==========The Pros Explanation============--Huge passive tree-- Huge doesnt really do it justice. and Currently ( pre ascendency patch ) you have fully open class choice allowing for pretty sweet combinations of classes, Tanky casters, Squishy meat shields. etc etc. You name it, you can do it.  Note- This is said to change after ascendency is dropped. They will be adding 'Sub Class' which will extremely hamper your ability to make fun and interesting builds and will churn out cookie cutter builds. If you want to have an effective X-Skill, you have to play the class that has access to X-Subclass. IMO ruining a HUGE portion of this games uniqueness.--Gear Limitations -- Gear is purely based on STR/Dex/INT and Level. no specific class restrictions.--Large RNG-- Meaning X Weapon isnt the best because it can rolled badly or be completely missing stats. Making the game have nice replayability.--Graphics --  THey're pretty good, little dated. but they update it occasionally--GGG Mixup-- They change stats vastly, So what works today, maynot work tomorrow. which some people hate. but every day is a gamble.==========THE CONS EXPLANATION=========-- Trading system -- So, the trading system. The Trading system is how the old school gaming trades use to take place. Meet up face to face, you throw your item in, they throw thier item in and you both hit accept and the trade is done. Yay!, Now where is the problem you ask? Its the process of FINDING that buyer or FINDING that seller. You have a few Options. 1), use Trade chat : 2), Use a Thirdparty websiteDue to the limitations of trade chat ( being very little ),  there are piles of bots that sit there and spam trade chat making it scroll faster then the wheels on a slot machine. Making finding a specific piece of gear nearly impossible.Using a third party website is the best possible alternative. which creates a rough 'Item Search' if you know exactly what it is you need. which is usually priced 20 or 30% over in-game value.(side rant), If you DO by the graces of god find someone selling the item you need in Trade chat. When you ask how much he wants for it, he will respond with " Offer ". There is NO right answer to respond to this. If you offer the appropriate value, He will haggle you or insult you for whatever reason. If you undercut him, he will get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off, tell you " NOOB THIS IS WORTH (X) " very clearly telling you he knew what he wants for his item and is waiting for someone to Overpay and rip them off.-- Support --Support for this game is just as bad as dealing with the @$$hole trying to price his crap. If your account is stolen, Tough luck, they dont care and will not assist you in any way.  If your account is hacked and all ur stuff is gone? Too bad, They will send you a link on how they think you can do better at not getting your account stolen.  Did your Hardcore Charecter die because thier servers all of a suddon crashed?   Oh well your ♥♥♥♥ed, under no circumstances will they reinstate them even if the fault is accepted by GGG's staff.-- Forums --The forum Mods will move our thread as they see fit, For whatever reason they decide to get thier jollies for. And if you inquire as to the move or request it to be adjusted, you will either get banned from the forums, Muted for a period of time or threatened with account deletion for questioning a mod. There is No set rules for Muting or Banning in this game. If they feel like they dont like what you said. Banned/Muted. If the aforementioned trade guy verbally assaults you and you respond with " Jesus calm down " and he reports you for harrasment ( right click, Report - is all it takes ) You will be muted for a fairly random length of time, ranging from a minute to days. Saying any keywords no matter the context, Such as "Hitler" even in a line as " Hitler did terrible things " will result in a ban if someone so much as hits the report button. (Side rant) If you are trying to sell an item and the Trade Chat is going to fast, simply right click and submit for 'Spam' on each person that tries to list thier items. They will drop like flys and you can post your stuff. Untill your muted too that is.---End game content --They sort-of recently added thier attempt at end-game content which consists of a few bossfights. While the fight itself is ok and sorta appealing, The items that are needed to access this content are very rare, and due to the rarity, are expensive to purchase from other players. Meaning you can do maybe 1 or 2 runs a day, If you have the money to buy them. Or, you have to find the items yourself which is a extremely rare drop, from a rare random spawn location within a map. Ive personally found 2 of these items in the 300 Hours ive played since they were released. One of which i just found today. So what do you do for end-game content between those? You grind your face against maps that are WAY under ur level getting♥♥♥♥♥♥experience hoping for currency drops to pile up to eventually be able to do that content again, that will take you 20 minutes to complete. to then farm again for a day or two.-- Leveling past 80 -- No gear is past lvl 75 i believe currently, So leveling past that is merely for personal pleasure or a few passive points which isnt worth the mind numbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ exp wall.-- Flooded Economy -- The game has many leagues/seasons/races/etc etc that all lead into standard, these leagues offer increased drop rates or spawn rates which vastly increases loot, which all get sshuffled into the already increased economy, Everything is stupid expensive, currency value is garbage.TLDR: Fun game to pass time a while, dont invest too much and dont cause urself to need support. Good game, 7/10, But wont reccomend it in its current state.

												When you start playing, the game seems nicely made, and lot of nice ideas and discovering are there, but it wont last...- They limited the tabs to 4, knowing that people who get involved on this game will quickly need more.Just look at the transaction store, the most popular buys are extra tabs. People are not 'supporting' the game, they are forced to buy more tabs to play without being constantly annoyed by the limited space of storage.So, the game is free for who don't care about the game, the others will have to drop the money,And do not expect nice prices, everything on the store is overpriced. Want 6 more basic tabs ? +-14€Want a cosmetic skin that looks cool? Don't be surprised if most of them costs like 20€...- Remember the bumblegums that were containing stickers to collect? The makers were making one of the sticker extremely rare to find, on purpose, to push kids to buy more and more bubblegum, wasting their money, until they gave up since the missing sticker was almost never found.The authors of this game are doing the same BS here, all items SEEMS to drop randomly, but there are some internal rules that will make some drop EXTREMELY RARE, making the game frustrating and never ending quest to the desired item. Some items are so rare that they totally lost the purpose of being there...Some little examples:* There are items that are so ridiculously rare, that you will never dare to use them (exalted orb for instance, I found ONLY 1 after 350h)* After 350 hours of game, I NEVER  find any 5 linked socket item, and ofc 6 linked remains an unreasonable dream. And if you want to link 5 or 6 sockets. Good luck, you will need it (and a LOT of orb of fusings, which are also extremely rare to find) One way to make this easier, is to farm... farm and farm forever (you can trade to some merchants). Once you got what you wanted, after thousand of hours playing this, will it worth keep playing even more? That is the worst aspect of this game. You may eventually the stuff you need only once all the battles are behind... Seriously...* (trying to not spoil here) you will need 4 items to collect to activate it (Sacrifice of X), but the 4th part is extremely rare compared the others, which means you will have to play a lot to find it (I never found it myself)- The difficulty: I ended the game after dying like 300x at the boss of act4 Merciless. My little witch with her 1500hp and her commons and spectres could not do anything, and it took ages to kill the guy (1M hp or what ??)Maybe they expect the game to be played for years by people, but for the first run, the game feels just dumb and the difficulty badly set (walk in the park the whole game, rarely dying, even getting boring, since its just basing hack  nslash, then suddently bosses from Apocalypse that can kill you in 1 hit...)- Read popular negative reviews for more details. No need here to repeat other cons here.I could write more, but got enough of this game. After 350 hours, still dont get the point of the game. Maybe its just not for me...- Maybe ill return and will keep playing again some other year, since the game does not have really an ending. But too much BS for now.

												I immediately fell on love with this game! I'll break it down into pros and cons. But the cons really aren't enough to make it not worth playing.==PROS==- First off, it's FREE! Running looks odd. content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Are you crazy about ARPGs? Did you spend counteless hours playing Diablo 1 and 2? have you tried any other ARPG out there just to find that one that hits the spot just like Diablo did? If the answers to those questions is yes, then you have found your game.Called, by many people, the true Diablo 3, although I have not played the 3rd, from what I have seen I tend to agree with those people.So what is it about? Same as any other ARPG, kill♥♥♥♥♥♥and get loot. But unlike the other ones this one has a few twists. Features: 7 character "classes", and I use quotation marks because the classes are only defined by their starting point on the huge passive skill "tree". which brings us to our nest part, the huge♥♥♥♥♥Skill "Tree", or web, or galaxy, whatever it is it is not a tree >.>. The "Skildrassil" as it is often called, consists of a thousand and something (can't remember the exact number) passives, ALL PASSIVES.Active skills in form of socketable gems. You basically take a skill you like and put it in your equipment, with the ability to add supports to it moddifying it according to your taste.Hard♥♥♥♥♥game, yes this is a feature. Hard, somewhat difficult to learn, and extremely hard to master. And this is where most peiople that play it find the appeal.And it's FREE TO PLAY. Only cosmetic MTX available. Best F2P model you'll ever encounter. The game is soo good you'll want to pay, not feel forced to do it, you'll be the devs to take your money.And finally the "bad parts". Desync, yeah it sucks at times, although I haven't had major problems with it. Also some people hate that it's too RNG focused, but I think it's needed for replayability. And it's too damn hard at times, some people find that as a minus.In conclusion, if this review has piqued your interest, and you're a fan of ARPGs, you have no excuse of not playing this one. It's FREE anyway so might as well try it.Update: 10/10Update 2: 2000 hours after; would sell kidney for more.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I have played this since 2011, and I cannot recommend it enough. If you liked Diablo 2 and other games like it, I don't think you will be dissapointed with this game, and since its free to play I don't see any reason why you shouldn't at least try it. There is a permanent softcore league, permanent hardcore league. There is a 4 month softcore league, a 4 month hardcore league if you want ladder resets like in D2. And on top of that there are several race leagues daily if you want to compete on a very hardcore level.You are very free in how you want to shape your character. The passive tree is gigantic and you can go anywhere you want on it. The only restriction to the class you choose is where you start on the passive tree. The builds are almost limitless, but if you want to do well in end-game you need to think about what you're doing.This F2P game is actually F2P. There is no P2W or anything like that in this game. The shop consists of almost only cosmetic items. There is ONE thing in the shop that could "help" you or at least make your time go a bit smoother, but again, it is not "NEEDED" to play the game. The item I'm talking about is Stash tabs. Yes, you have an in-game stash much like in D2/D3. The stash consists of 4 tabs, but you can buy as many tabs as you want from the shop. So if you are a hoarder like me, you probably want to buy a lot of tabs.The good thing though, is that the game is go good that I doubt you will think twice about buying some tabs and at the same time give them some support for making this awesome game. They are also expanding the game with content patches, new acts, new gems, items and what not on a regular basis.Again, I can't recommend this game enough, I urge you to at least try the game out if you tend to like these kind of games. HF

												a dungeon crawler like diablo yet so very different. the mechanics of this game are very complex and the versatiliy of each class is very vast. there are so many different ways to build each class the possibilities are endless. how it works is you get all of your abilities through socketing skill gems into your gear. there is no penalty for removing gems from your gear though, all you have to do is right click the gem. the passive skill tree is very large and confusing at first and can be very overwhelming but once you understand the basic mechanics of the game it's fairly easy to understand. the idea is to have your skill gems, passive skills, and support gems all working together in synergy to unlock the full potential of your build and your character's abilities. i recommend for your first character play something tanky or maybe a summoner witch. playing a glass cannon as your first character really is not the best idea.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												This is hands down the best Jew/Trading simulator out there. Definitely beats Recettear by a long shot. What makes it different from other Jew/Trading simulators out there is how there's no in-game money. Everything is valued in orbs, and the focus of the game is to get as many Chaos and Exalted Orbs as possible within a 4-month league. Sure, you can simply say, "but in that case, gold is basically chaos!" and you wouldn't be too far off. However, the items you trade in-game have no fixed value, can be negotiated for fractions of a Chaos/Exalt(which exist as other currencies), are negotiated by the players. Oh yeah, did I mention you trade with other players? That also makes it vastly different from Recettear.It's kind of hard to explain the nature of this game, you just have to trade to figure it out. 90% of unique items are valued at 1 chaos, which is pretty much as low as you'll want to go. Different currencies are available to split Chaos and Exalts, but pretty much do not have a set value themselves, aside from 8 Chance = 2 Scouring = 1 Regret and 8 Alteration = 4 Jeweler's = 1 Fusing. Again, the point of the game is to convert these currencies to Chaos, and eventually Exalts. Pro-tip: Convert your Exalts to Chaos within the first 2 months of a league, then buy Exalts within the last month/last 2 weeks.The Jew/Trading Simulator involves an ARPG minigame, but its not really worth noting compared to the depth of the Trading game. It's basically mind-numbing, "attach main attack/spell skill to a button, attach debuff(curse) to another button, spam both buttons" gameplay. This is due to the fact that BiS items such as Kaom's Heart and Bringer of Rain effectively drop the amount of usable skills by 1. Not only that, but gemslots and links also severely limit your amount of effective usable skills. Focusing on 1 skill is mandatory if you want effective DPS. The ARPG minigame gameplay focuses mostly on passive effects, so its not really that great. The drop rates for gaining items are terrible, so to succeed in this game, you buy good items at really low prices from players desperate to beat the gearchecks of the ARPG minigame, and you sell them for as high as people are willing to buy them.tl;dr 9.5/10, definitely worth your time. Best Jew/Trading simulator of all time.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I've played POE for a few years on and off.  It is a fine game with very well thought out mechanics, skill trees and visuals.  The developer really knows what they are doing for the most part.  They also know that unlike D3, they need to be stingy with the drops so you don't run out of stuff to do.Anyway, I spent $20ish in extra stash tabs which is absolutely necessary if you want to play the game "semi-seriously" and it isn't a bad "donation" to the fine folks at Grinding Gear Games.  I do wish they would cave and put in a non cash auction house so I wouldn't have to dicker with the idiots, but the trading is far less painless then it used to be with most folks using POE trade which is a nice 3rd party site.All together I enjoy it more than D3.  I'd say that D3 is smoother running, slightly better graphics.  Path of Exile is a thinking person's game, I am very impressed with how the developer really thinks about the small things and is always trying to make the game better.  I highly recommend this game if you like the Diablo sort of play.  If you are going to try it I recommend giving POE a reasonable try since it is a slow starter and really only kicks in when you "invest" time and increase your knowledge base.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												After having played path of exile for over 300 hours on many characters I have come to love this game. The depth of it's character and item customization is phenomenal. I find myself spending time outside of the game planning builds and discussing ideas with friends.I started playing the game in softcore leagues. I was too afraid of dying and losing all of the work I had done in the league. After I became comfortable with the game and started to improve my skills I moved into hardcore leagues and haven't looked back. At the time of this review my current character is level 67 and just getting ready to move into doing maps.Path of Exile's passive skill tree can be very daunting for a new player. It seems like you will never figure out what to do and feel overwhelmed. Many players use a guide on the forums from other players to learn how to play a certain build for a character and how to progress throughout the passive tree. Some people may say that having to look up how to play is bad but in my opinion it gets players to get more involved in the forums as well as into researching more about the game rather than just diving in and getting frustrated about not knowing what to do.The economy of the game is kept balanced through the fact that the currencies commonly used for trading are also used by players to try and upgrade their items. This keeps the game from flooding with currency and having tons of inflation. Hardcore leagues tend to have a better economy since players dying takes items out of the league and puts it into standard. Causing the number of items that are good in standard to rise constantly, hurting it's economy some.Even though Path of Exile has a limited number of classes and only 3 acts that are repeated multiple times per character and on every character, the passive tree, skill gem customization, and items cause people to want to keep playing the game and make new characters.My advice to new players is to not give up too fast because you feel overwhelmed. Take a few minutes to browse the forums or watch videos to learn about a build or how to play the game well. If you put in the time to learn about the game you will be glad you did and enjoy the game. There may be desync issues which can be frustrating but they are being worked on and they are not as bad as people make them out to be. You can easily play the game with those small issues and be fine.I am willing to help out new players with the game or questions they have about the game. Feel free to add me on steam or in game using xHamsterHunter.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												IF YOU ARE NEW TO THE GAME AND WANT TO LEARN MORE, below is a link to a basic mechanics and beginners guide to Path of Exile.-----------------------http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=188353339-----------------------Absolutely fantastic. I can't speak anything but good words about this game and it's developer. GrindingGearGames is constantly adding new content, fixing bugs, and balancing the game. They communicate really well with their playerbase through the official forums as well as player-created communities like the Path of Exile subreddit.I find the game incredibly addicting. It always feels like there is more to do, more to explore, and new thins to try. With the immense skill tree, accessable by any class, I find that there is always new things for me to discover. The skill tree, which some might call a forest, allows for an extreme amount of customization and an insane variety in builds.The skill system is ingenius as well. Skills are obtained by putting a Skill Gem in sockets on your gear, so skills aren't limited by class, further diversifying the build possibilities. Wanna run a 2h Mace Ground Slam Witch? Go for it. Wanna make a Power Siphon wand Marauder? Have fun. There are so many options, and that isn't even taking support gems into the calculations.Then there's the end game to consider. After you've beaten Act 3 Merciless, you reach the ultimate end-game goal; MAPS. Maps are items that are dropped by monsters, and you can use them to generate instances where you can fight monstors of higher levels and get sweet sweet loot. There are many levels of maps, starting at level 66, and continue to scale in level and difficulty. To make these maps interesting, you can enchant them with most currency items to roll Mods on your maps, which increases the Item Quantity generated by mobs, or the number of items dropped meaning better loot. These mods, however, work against you and serve to make it harder for you. Some mods include more monster life, higher damage, multiple projectiles, -max resists, etc. These mods make people band together to do harder maps, which is why you'll usually see people doing maps in parties. GGG has found a solution to something that I've always had a problem with in ARPGs, which is end game content. In most ARPGs (Torchlight 2, Diablo 3) after you reach a certain point, there ceases to be any reason to keep playing and farming. Maps also adress the issue of a lack of social interaction in a game, which has proven to be a problem in recent titles. Maps encourage people to work together.Overall this is a fantastic game, although it isn't perfect. It's really hard to get into, with so many nuances that I can see how it would be really hard for a casual player to immerse themselves. The game also doesn't have the best optimization, and desync is a major issue, but it definitely has its good points.If you were (or still are, who nows?) an avid fan of Diablo 2 or are just a hardcore ARPG fan, then this is a great option for you. If you're looking for a hardcore game, look no further for you have found one. If you want a more casual experience, Diablo 3 might be more to your tastes. However, Path of Exile is a FREE TO PLAY game, so you might as well try it out and see what you think!I myself have sunk over 500-600 hours into this game (I only have ~220 hours logged on steam, but I spent a lot of time playing it during open beta before it was on Steam. I imagine I have around 300-400 hours on that.) and I'm sure that I will play more for quite a long time.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Just as Din's Curse fills the role as an inferior clone of Diablo II, Path of Exile is actually a superior version. It's not often that a game comes along that I will skip sleep for. Especially on a work night, but PoE is one of them. Just like its Blizzard-created cousins, it is an ARPG (Action Role Playing Game) that has an isometric view of the world. The graphics are the usual 3D rendered artifacts - allowing that bit greater resolution and naturalness to the character's animation.The depth of the game is phenomenal for a free title. It almost begs the question of what exactly is its creator's (Grinding Gear Games of New Zealand) business model. How can they make money on something that is free? During the first few weeks, I suspected that they would bring out some of the usual products for those cash-rich, time-poor players who prefer to buy high level items - a la World of Warcraft. This hasn't occurred yet. Most of the upgrades from the store are merely visual enhancements that make your character look cooler. The player community is much better than a few other free-to-play's out there. They are helpful, and there are many tutorials and guides for the cautious player that prefers to know what is coming up. The economy is fairly stable too. Gone are the usual gold, silver and bronze monetary units. Instead it is magical scrolls and items that vendors pay players with. The most common payment is a Scroll of Wisdom - used to identify any magical, rare, or unique items found. Most non-magical items will get you a twentieth of SoW - called a Scrap of Parchment. Another welcome addition to this game is the use of item experience - similar to the style found in Guild Wars 2 - except here it is only applied to gemstones, that can attached to any socketed weapons or armour found. These will grant you spells or abilities.The character progression in this games is much more simplified than many games these days. Instead of having a dozen attributes to manage, there is just three. These are intelligence, dexterity, and strength. These can be increased through character accessories, or using certain abilities in your Passive Skills section tree. Conversely to the character attributes, the Passive Skills appear incredibily complicated. You gain a point to spend here every time you level up, and more can be earned from completing certain quests. Only neighbouring skills on the tree can be activated, and it is this controlled incremental improvement that will have send most people shrieking from the game to Google for access to the all-important Wiki's out there.At the moment, the game is still in early release and this means lots of patches. Each patch will gank, nerf and buff different passive skills. This means that certain builds that are over-powered leviathans one day, become mewling kittens the next. It can be frustrating, especially as there is a definite lack of ways to re-spec your build.It's a small price to pay for this gem of a game. I've a few Steam games in my collection, and it is with some irony that I find a freebie to be the best, but it currently is. Nothing else comes close. I constantly find myself thinking "just one more hour / level". Everyone should get this game and play it. In fact, I think I'm going to go now... Laters!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												(I need to point out that, at the time of writing, I had played the game on steam for 13 hours. I had played the game off steam for a much longer period before moving over. Just thought I should share.)Normally I write dumb joke reviews, but I feel like I owe this one some seriousness. I'm in a similar boat to most of the other players of this game. I loved Diablo 2, but Diablo 3 felt a little lacking (especially at launch, I only bothered to buy it recently, after most of the fixes) and thought to myself "I really wish there was a good, in-depth ARPG to fill my tim- OH HEY WHAT'S THIS?"Let's clear up that F2P concern first. Path of Exile is the most pure Free to Play I've ever seen. There's no experience or gold boosts, no overpowered weapons to buy, nothing. Only cosmetics can be bought with real money. It's something I never thought I'd see again. And oh god, it's refreshing. It's of the same quality as any game you payed once for, like Torchlight, if not higher. You may notice above, there's no 'starter packs' for sale either. Seriously, you don't have to buy jack♥♥♥♥♥♥Now, the guys and gals that made this game are fantastic. They listen to the community, and actually fix their game when problems arise. How great is that? They don't just go for 'good enough', the strive for the best. It makes you want to give them some cash.All right, now that we've gotten that out of the way, how about the game? So, you pick a class and start on a beach with zombies knawing at your friend's corpse. What do? You decide! The game has a huge passive skill system where all the classes are entertwined, so, with enough perseverence, you can turn that spell-flinging witch into a warrior if you wanted. Or an archer. Or whatever you want. It reminds me a lot of Dark Souls in that sense, classes only really affect how you start the game. Every class can potentially use any skill, which act as socketable gems. Wanna use that green trap skill? Make sure you have an equipment item to socket it into! There is also no currency in the game. Instead, you buy items with identify scrolls, adding this interesting mechanic that reminds me of the metro games. I approve.The combat and visuals harkon back to the days of Diablo 2, throwing out the cartoon-y, WoW graphics of Diablo 3 and Torchlight in favor of a darker, more mature, gritty look. The combat isn't very flashy and as 'cool' as Diablo 3 looks, but it definitely holds it's own in the ARPG genre. Don't knock it until you play it, at least.My only beef with the game is a rather small one. I'd have liked to see a bit more customization for the characters. Each class is gender locked and there's virtually no customization towards the look of your character and you don't really end up looking all too different from once you started because of new gear... Ever. To some people, this is a deal-breaker (as I understand) as one of the allures of ARPG's is to constantly get new gear and have it be reflected in that shiny new look YOU earned. I, personally, can get around that.This game is phenomonal. As someone who's been around the ARPG neighborhood again and again, Path of Exile, and Grinding Gear Games, deserves your attention.

												           Path of Exile is a divisive game, If you like you you love it, and if you don't it's a horrible disappointment. I love this game. I love ARPGs. It is complex and methodical while the combat is fast and satisfying.I will say that the combat can be a bit sloggy for the first couple levels, but I feel that the game more than makes up for it over time. The complexity and variety of builds, gear, and skill choice mean that the clunkiness can be overlooked.The game is F2P, and one of the best examples of the medium can work. The closest thing to Pay to Win is the ability to expand your in game inventory, but it's not necessary at all to do well even late in the end game, You can buy cosmetic effects, and many of them look great, and that's about it.The community for the game is amazing and the Devs are very involved with the players, often showing up on forums and in chat to discuss problems and make jokes.Long story short; if you like ARPGs give it a shot. It's free.9.5/10

Posted: September 8, 2015
												Most action RPGs are dull or simplistic, in my opinion. I gave Path of Exile a chance because of its supernatural theme and was very pleasantly surprised. The gameplay is outstanding, the maps (Acts 1 - 4 so far) each have different environments such as dungeons, graveyards, forests, caverns, the sea shore, and so on, and the item and crafting systems are very robust and engaging. There is a Guild system and also player housing in the form of Hideouts which can become very complex and unique by completing daily missions for Masters (see PoE's Hideout of the Week for some examples). Overall, Path of Exile is a carefully designed, well thought out experience with an engaging story, offering an odd blend of Gothic horror, Diablo-like gameplay, and Kiwi culture (Grinding Gear Games is located in New Zealand). Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I think having around 300 hours into the game, is enough time to say something about it. Path of exile is worth playing and it's free to play. You can create anything you want, if you have the currency for it. That's the catch though. In the beginning you will be really poor (99% of the time). Meaning the diversity is not that huge. There are a few builds that supposedly work without any gear due to abusing game's damage mechanics or using a very popular skill that outperforms other skills.The game is RNG based. And before I got around 200 hours into the game, I was really annoyed by this idea that my wealth is almost completely dependent on RNG. But then I started noticing things that the developers don't tell you and the community doesn't know. After that, the RNG factor became very minimal. Of course, that's my opinion. I got no proof, so maybe I just started getting lucky. In the end. I had a blast leveling 3 characters from around 50 to around 90. I didn't have to start over, because I had characters that had free respecs. I'd say that I recommend path of exile. I got a little off topic there, but it is worth it. There is no pay to win as far as I am aware and you can make your own luck. The only pay to win, kind of, is if you want to trade with other players more efficiently. But that's completely optional.TL:DR Just go play it. Give it 200 hours, before you decide that you don't like it. The addiction to the loot chase will get you sooner or later and when it does, you will eventually be forced away like I was, due to bad RNG. And if you don't mind, then this is one of the few games that provides infinite entertainment. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												TL;DR: Free to play, zero pay to win, developers are awesome guys that love their game. Takes quite some time to get into (complex game mechanics), insane theory crafting possibilities. It's probably safe to say that not everyone likes this kind of game, but if you're interested in this genre or already enjoyed similar games such as Diablo 3, I can only highly recommend it. ===================It's probably safe to say that Path of Exile is not a game for everyone. It is complex, it is unforgiving, and if you're really into it, you spend probably just as much time looking at skilltrees and numbers on your gear as actually playing your character. To find out whether this kind of game is something for you or not, you probably just have to try it. If you do, just one thing: Don't give up on it too early, as the full potential of a game like PoE reveals itself only through understanding game mechanics, which will take you quite some time. The developers seem to be amazing people that seriously care about their game: The philosophy of the ingame store, which seems to be their main source of income, is to provide three things: Cosmetics, which makes your character looking better without making it any stronger; Quality of Life-Improvements such as Stash tabs which gives you more space to store more items; and last but not least, Supporter packs, which give you various of the aforementioned benefits, but for serious bucks: If you truly want to support the game, you can spend hundreds of bucks for this packs to do so. But again, it's in no way essential for the gameplay to do so.Also, every few months, there are patches that improve the game and add additional content: Be it new leagues, be it new game mechanics, be it new skills and items: It's all been for free so far; no paywall'd content, no DLC nonsense, just free improvement of the game basically. I've played Path of Exile already for a few hundred hours, I've ripped countless characters in Hardcore mode already (where death is final), and yet I still enjoy the game: I can only highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												If I had played this before making my top 5 games of the year this game would have stolen 5th place from Saints Row 4.Top-down action RPGs or “Diablo clones” as many people like to call them rarely amuse me for more than two or three hours, Path Of Exile however is a different story. What makes Path of Exile so different? Well I think it is it’s character building that makes it so enthralling. I am playing as a witch, a necromantic witch using my own build; I summon hordes of zombies, skeletons & spectres to overwhelm my enemies whilst I hide in a corner & cry, occasionally raining down fire from the heavens. But that’s just one simple example of a huge number of possible builds each & every character can have.Each character starts at a certain part of the passive skill tree, it is incredibly daunting at first but you’ll soon realise that it’s one of the best thought out skill trees out there, I dare say maybe the best I’ve seen. A witch for example starts at the intelligence slice, then we have the ranger at dexterity, the marauder at strength; then three other classes with a mix of two attributes & finally the scion who will start dead centre & is unlockable after beating the game for the first time.     These classes are purely the starting point, the canvas on which you build your character.   Skills are not dictated by class but by how much intelligence, strength & dexterity you have.You will not gain them by levelling up, you will choose them from quest rewards & will find them as drops from killing enemies.All these factors contribute to a huge amount of replay-ability.There is no character creator so whilst you make look the same as every witch, ranger or shadow you may not play the same. As for the gameplay itself, it is standard for the most part for any game of this style.Kill hordes of enemies, gather tons of loot whilst completing various quests & once in a while take down a tough boss. It sounds just as tedious as any other top-down action RPG yet whilst playing as the witch it never felt like that, it felt more tactical than your standard hit attack button until all bad things are dead approach. The trading system is another great aspect of note, instead of collecting money you trade unwanted equipment for items & stack up enough of these items & you’ll get a usable or better item.These are normally things that will permanently boost the effectiveness of armour & weapons or add magical effects to them. You’ll even get items that will change normal items to rare items. If you trade three of the same flasks you’ll get a better flask that will heal more HP or restore more mana. This removes the annoyance of gold farmers & the monotony of grinding for gold.In fact speaking of removing annoyances & monotony, that seems to be this game’s goal, to remove the things that makes your typical Diablo style top-down action RPG so tedious; & they, in my opinion, have succeeded. Best of all Path of Exile is free & has the fairest free-to-play model I have ever seen, micro transactions are almost exclusively cosmetic with bank & character slot upgrades being the only exception.That’s right none of the pay-walls you would usually find in free-to-play games.Plus if you run it though Steam there is no need to make yet another account for an MMO. There is absolutely no reason anyone should not at least try this game. Fully recommended.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												This is what Diablo III should have been (at least in my opinion). It follows the tried and tested gameplay formula of this genre with an interesting character development system.Skills are based on gems that are found throughout the game.These need to be socketed into items to be used and these level up with you as long as they are socketed. In theory any class can use any skill (although skill level is limited by the appropriate stat). In addition to this there is a large passive skill matrix which is similar in style to the skill development in Final Fantasy 10 (If any of you remember that one). For those who don't, all character classes start at different places on the matrix and (in theory) can access any skill, although some skills are much easier to reach for certain classes. This means that character development is much more freeform than it is in a lot of other games of this type. I've only played three classes to level 20 or so so I don't know how the game holds up in the final stages, but it seems like an enjoyable, nicely put together game so far. It has PVP (which I haven't tried), regular events and (apparantly) a sizeable number of players. If you find yourself at a loose end one day and fancy taking a chance on an indie game, I'd recommend giving this one a try. Its free to play and as far as I can tell not pay to win, so what have you got to loose :)

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Path of Exile is one of the most engaging ARPGs I've played lately.  I'd highly recommend this to fans of Diablo or Torchlight who wish that there were a few more ways to customize their character.  The classes are diverse (and customizable) and combat is intense and sufficiently difficult.All skills in the game are contained in gems, which are slotted into equipment similar to how materia was equipped in Final Fantasy VII.  Also, character progression is done through a non-linear system that reminds me of the Sphere Grid from Final Fantasy X.  There is no hard currency (such as gold or gems) in the game.  Instead, there is a wide variety of customization orbs that can be traded as currency to either vendors or other players.I've had a lot of fun playing PoE, and find myself coming back to it whenever I want to play a good action-oriented smash-and-loot game.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												This game is hard. At least when you first play it.The Skill 'Forest', because calling it a tree would be an understatement, is overwhelming, the drop is confusing and the currency is great in numbers and not so easy to determine whether it is valuable or not.This will be an issue for the first 10-20hours of your game. You will by no means understand the game fully after that but when you've played the game for 20hours you have the basic knowledge of the 'system' that allows you to get into the more complicated stuff.The game has A LOT to offer if you wish to spend the time. Even though it is free to play I recommend getting one pack of extra stash tabs(for which you do have to pay real money). The default 4 are big. Really big. But you'll come across so much different loot that you'll fill them up in no time and with no order. Speaking of money - the game has no mechanics that can give you an edge over another player. Yes, you can buy gear and lvls from 3rd party websites but so you could in D2 and nobody was saying that D2 is broken because of that. I even think that it is a nice way for people with not so much time to spare to get some more fun out of the game within their time frame. BUT that's a matter of opinion.As for the classes - the only difference between them is where you start off on the skill tree. All skills/spells/etc. are stored in Skill Gems meaning that you can have a berserker witch running around with a bow and spitting fire. Don't forget though that even if all builds are possible not all of them are viable for the endgame content(maps). Still, creating a build is a lot of fun and it doesn't mean much if you won't get past level 50 with your character because what you'll learn in that time will enhance your latter gameplay with all the upcoming characters and builds. You either get your first build from the net(which I do not recommend)or you get ready for completely fail at making your first/first couple of builds and learn much faster how the game works.The infamous desync - yes, it's there. What is desync? Desync is basically a situation when your game client and the server do not agree on where all the stuff is. You, Monsters, Items, Activated Clutter etc. So sometimes it might appear you just smacked the zombie in the face but the zombie still is spitting rotten blood in your face. Is this a big deal? It can in higher levels. When you're not cautious enough and don't "/oos" at the right time you might die without it being your fault. This is an endgame issue though! Your first playthrough WILL be a walk in the park whatever build, character or playstyle you choose.My recommendation? Try the game out! One of the few games that has reached a very high quality level with the devs still following they initial agenda(so nothing like "We will never make a paid Map DLC" and then release one a few years later[talking to you, DICE]).It is more than worth your time. You will thank me later.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2013
												I have been playing since the original Closed Beta( yeah there's 2 since a new Act changed the game massively resulting in another beta)>Much more rewarding and challenging than D3.>Good itemization and skills along with some improved and faster levelling makes this game hella fun.>Previously people complained at how slow the game felt in the first 10 or so levels but they have worked hard on that.>The game can now be played entirely solo without ever requiring to trade/interact with other players for items thanks to new crafting and gem/item acquisation methods in masters and divination cards respectively.>The passive tree may appear scary at first but eventually you realise it is pretty straightforward.>The game does not suffer the fate D3 suffers from aka limited build viability( thanks to the class specific item sets in Diablo ). Almost all builds are viable as long as they are cohesive mechanically.>The mechanics of the game are complex similar to Diablo 2. Takes a few deaths to learn stuff the hard way if you prefer Hardcore like me. :)TL:DR I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves TL2/D3/D2. You will be pleased with the game. Also, the biggest complain that people had against this game was DESYNC(caps for visibility). It has now been fixed by introducing lockstep synchronisation(the method D3 uses. your ping decides if you desync essentially. Internet lags, client will suffer.)All these new changes made me feel like revisiting this review.

Posted: July 28, 2015
												A rather good singleplayer experience in the vein of classic Diablo. Surprisingly polished for a free-to-play title, I especially like the perk web and skill gems compared to static skill trees, and the NPCs actually have sensible things to say - at least for your first go around.No payment necessary to play and advance, as all paid content is cosmetics, which I think is rather fair.The multiplayer is okay, but PvE gets dull fast, as there is not enough variety to pose a challenge and the skills that are fun in singleplayer quickly turn into overpowered steamrollers in multiplayer. Bosses are are a little limited for a modern game, very few different stages and either the fight is over fast or gets protracted. The lenient respawn system alleviates frustration.I would definitely recommend the game for anyone into hack'n'slash, as it is free and of decent quality.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												“In my dreams I see a great warrior, his skin scorched black, his fists aflame.” Path of Exile (PoE) is an online action role-playing game (arpg) developed and published by the company Grinding Gear Games. Atmosphere & presentation: + Free-to-play game that can be completed, enjoyed and continued without spending money. + Grim and dark atmosphere is supported by appropriate background music.+ Creative level and monster design. o A permanent internet connection is required, in order to access the PoE servers.o Cosmetic effects can be bought via in-game microtransactions. Combat & gameplay: ++ The passive ability tree is massive. In combination with the creative skill gem system it provides a multitude of options for character development and tuning towards the end game.+ Replayability profits from the league system and randomly generated (end game) maps, with countless variation in form of map modifiers, increasing the difficulty with each added attribute.+ Creative currency system with elaborate item-changing properties. + In-game trade system allows the easy acquirement of high end gear from other players. + ‘Hardcore’ mode satisfies the needs of the masochistic player community.Characters & story: + Interesting side characters provide the player with entertaining information about current and past events of the game world.o Limited identification of the player with the protagonist. - No cutscenes or other means of exposition are used to support the storytelling or foreshadow future events. Summary: Overall, PoE offers offers high-quality hack & slash gameplay with sophisticated arpg mechanics that can be enjoyed from the beginning to the end on a free-to-play basis. It is a challenge to reach the end and you can definitely end up putting a lot of hours into it.Furthermore, the game succeeds in the field of long term motivation by providing an elaborated league system that maintains the in-game economic balance and replayablity.The only shortcoming of this game lies in the presentation and simplicity of the storytelling. While the different non-player characters will fill you in about the historic and current events in Wraeclast, no other means are used to bolster up the storyline. Trivia: While 60 percent of donors were in the $10 range, the ‘diamond tier’, in which someone commits to $1,000 or more, found 183 supporters.Achievements: A little advice for achievement hunters. The level of difficulty is a 10 out of 10 on the freak scale with a badass seal of approval.Estimated time for 100 % completion: +300 hoursOffline achievements: noneOnline achievements: 84Chronology: Path of Exile (PC) Action role-playing game + hack & slash (Dark Fantasy) – 2013
